questions.text: A young man falls on an outstretched hand and develops a fracture as shown in the X-ray below.  Which of the following screws is commonly used to treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray and the history of falls on the outstretched hands suggest the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture. Herbert screw is commonly used to treat this fracture.

Herbert screw is a cannulated variable pitch screw, which is used to fix unstable or displaced fractures of small articular bones such as the scaphoid. This screw helps in quick healing by providing compression at the fracture site and early return to normal activities. The advantage of cannulated screws is that we can use a guidewire under videofluoroscopy to assist in the accurate placement of the screw during surgery.

Scaphoid fractures occur most commonly after a fall on an outstretched hand. The waist of the scaphoid is the most common site of fracture. Initial x-rays are done in anteroposterior, lateral, and oblique views. Even if the x-rays appear normal, if there is clinical suspicion, a glass holding cast should be applied for 2 weeks followed by repeat imaging.

Management depends upon the type of fracture. If the scaphoid tubercle is fractured, the patient is given a glass-holding cast for 4-6 weeks. In case of undisplaced waist fractures, most people will recover with a cast in place for 6-8 weeks. Percutaneous screw fixation with the Herbert screw can be offered to those with displaced or undisplaced fractures of the waist when the patient does not want to undergo prolonged cast immobilization, or if they wish to return to work/daily activities sooner. Reducing and fixing displaced fractures also reduces the risk of non-union.

The most common complications include nonunion, avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the proximal fracture segment, and osteoarthritis. 

Herbert screw is shown below:

 

Other options:

Option A: Cannulated cancellous screws are commonly used to treat fractures of the neck of the femur.

Option B: The interference screw is a biodegradable screw used during anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction. This screw is made of polymers that increase its strength so as to improve cortical bone formation at the site as well as to ensure that the tibial tunnel is not too wide during the insertion of the newly reconstructed ligament.

Option D: Pedicle screws are used in spinal fusion surgery to provide added strength and support. They are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws, which prevent their movement and allow the bone to heal. They are also used in the correction of scoliosis.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: According to the American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification, a patient with a history of uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension, undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, will belong to which of the following classes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presence of uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension in a patient undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy belongs to class III of the ASA-PS classification system.

American Society of Anesthesiologists classification is designed to provide perioperative clinicians with a system to classify a patient's physiological status to help estimate the risk of surgery. It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

Class III describes a patient with severe systemic illness that is not life-threatening. It includes the presence of some functional limitations due to diseases such as uncontrolled hypertension or diabetes, morbid obesity, chronic renal failure, stable angina and implanted pacemakers.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A patient with a history of asthma presents with sudden shortness of breath. On examination, there is a slight decrease in breath sounds on the right upper lung fields. An x-ray showed a small (8mm) pneumothorax in the right lung. Which is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient with a small pneumothorax is 100% oxygen inhalation and observation. 

Secondary pneumothorax can occur in patients with asthma due to the rupture of subpleural blebs. Other risk factors include tall height, collagen vascular disorders, and COPD. These blebs form as a result of alveolar enlargement due to air retention and can spontaneously rupture leading to air leak and a pneumothorax formation. In patients with mild cases, the next best step is to provide oxygen inhalation and allow for the air to be reabsorbed back into the lungs. Oxygen inhalation allows for the nitrogen to be reabsorbed back into the bloodstream thus reducing the symptoms. 

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. It may be the only indication of a pneumothorax in such patients.

Management of pneumothorax:

  • Primary pneumothorax
    • <2 cm size: Discharge and follow-up in 2-4 weeks
    • >2 cm size: Aspirate with 16 G cannula → If fails, place a chest drain of size 8-14 Fr
  • Secondary pneumothorax
    • <1 cm size: High-flow oxygen with observation for 24 hours
    • 1-2 cm size: Aspirate with 16 G cannula → If fails, place a chest drain of size 8-14 Fr
    • >2 cm size: Place chest drain of size 8-14 Fr

Pneumothorax refers to gas (air) in the pleural space. A progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration) can lead to a tension pneumothorax. It is characterised by compression of mediastinal structures and compromised cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain.
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea.
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness).
  • Neck vein distention.
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury.
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side.
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side.
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge.
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line.
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung. 
  • Complete lung collapse, as well as subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum, may be seen.
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph).
  • Deep sulcus sign: On a supine film (common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright

 

Other options:

Option A: Chest tube insertion is done in cases of moderate to severe pneumothorax to immediately relieve the obstruction to breathing

Option B: CT chest is indicated if there is a history of trauma to rule out injury to the lungs. 

Option C: Intubation is an invasive procedure done in patients who are unable to maintain their airways. This patient is hemodynamically stable so observation is sufficient.

questions.text: Based on the pattern of postmortem staining shown in the image below, which of the following positions was the body in at the time of death?
questions.solution:
The postmortem staining/lividity in the image provided is characteristic of hanging as it is more marked in the legs, hands, and external genitalia.

Postmortem staining is usually seen in the dependent parts of the body wherein there is gravitational pooling of blood. 

Medicolegal importance - Postmortem staining and its fixation can be helpful to ascertain the time since death. It can also be used to estimate the body's position at the time of death and if the body has been relocated since. 

Other options:

Option A- In supine position (shown below), postmortem staining is limited to the neck and entire back except for the points of contact between the body and the ground (occipital areas, scapulae, buttocks, calves, and heels). The absence of lividity in these areas, due to external compression of blood vessels, is termed contact pallor.

 

Option B- In the prone position, postmortem staining is marked on the anterior surface of the body associated with the presence of Tardieu spots. 

Option C- In a body lying on the side, postmortem staining will is marked on that particular side due to the pooling of blood in the dependent parts.

questions.text: A 6-year-old female child presents with multiple episodes of inattentiveness, blank staring, and lip-smacking. Her symptoms are precipitated by hyperventilation, and associated EEG findings are given below. Identify the correct statement concerning this condition.

choices.text: The episodes are preceded by an aura
Episodes are associated with a postictal period
Most patients outgrow the condition before adulthood
A brain MRI with MRA and MRV is indicated to rule out structural abnormalities

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 6-year-old female child presenting with multiple episodes of inattentiveness, blank staring, and lip-smacking, which can be precipitated by hyperventilation and associated EEG findings of 3-Hz spike-and–slow-wave discharges, is characteristic of typical absence seizures of childhood absence epilepsy. The condition has a good prognosis, and most patients outgrow the condition before adulthood.

Typical absence seizures usually start at 5 to 8 years of age and are often overlooked due to their briefness (each episode lasts about 10 seconds). They can, however, occur up to 100 times per day. They are not associated with a preceding aura (Option A) or a postictal period (Option B). Episodes may be associated with simple automatisms such as lip-smacking or picking at clothing. Children are able to immediately resume what they were doing prior to the seizure after the episode ends. 

Hyperventilation for 3-5 min can precipitate the seizures. An EEG done during a seizure will demonstrate 3-Hz spike-and–slow-wave discharges (shown below). This finding is diagnostic of the condition and no other investigation is generally necessary (Option D). Neuroimaging with a head CT or brain MRI is performed if the seizure is focal, if there is a postictal period, or in patients with a history of trauma preceding the seizure.

The condition is most often initially treated with ethosuximide, which is as effective as, but less toxic than, valproate. EEG is helpful in monitoring the response to therapy and often normalizes when complete seizure control is achieved. Childhood absence epilepsy is associated with a good prognosis, and most patients outgrow it before adulthood.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the calcium homeostasis?

choices.text: Parathyroid hormone increases formation of vitamin D
CaSR is a G protein coupled receptor
Calcitonin increases calcium excretion in urine
Calcitonin causes the activation of osteoclasts

questions.solution:
Option D is false. Calcitonin causes inhibition of the osteoclasts.

The parathyroid hormone increases the formation of the 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol and this increases the absorption of calcium from the intestine.

The calcium-sensing receptor, CaSR is a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), which is located in the parathyroid gland. When the serum calcium levels are higher, it is sensed by this receptor and inhibits the secretion of the parathormone.

Calcitonin, in an attempt to lower the serum levels of calcium, increases the urinary excretion of the calcium.

Effects of parathormone (PTH): In response to low levels of Ca+2 in the extracellular fluid(ECF), PTH tends to increase Ca+2 concentration by:

  • Increasing bone resorption leading to Ca+2 release into the ECF
  • Increased reabsorption ofCa+2 by renal tubules, decreasing the urinaryCa+2 excretion
  • Decreased phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, increasing the urinary excretion of phosphate
  • Conversion of 25-­hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­-dihydroxycholecalciferol- increases intestinal Ca absorption 

Effects of Calcitonin: Calcitonin tends to decrease plasma calcium concentration in response to high levels ofCa+2 in the ECF, with effects opposite to that of PTH:

  • Decreased osteoclastic and osteoblastic activ­ity
  • Slowing of intestinal absorption of Ca+2

However, the effects of calcitonin on Ca+2 regulation are minor in adult humans.

questions.text: A woman presents with fever, chills, malaise, and headache after attending a large convention at a hotel. Further tests lead to a diagnosis of Pontiac fever. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Pontiac fever is an acute, self-limited respiratory illness caused by Legionella pneumophila. It is typically acquired by inhaling aerosols contaminated with the bacteria, often from sources like cooling towers, humidifiers, air conditioning systems at hotels, and plumbing fixtures.

Legionella pneumophila can be found in natural, freshwater environments, but generally is not present in sufficient numbers to cause disease. Infection is typically by inhalation of aerosols produced by cooling towers, air conditioners, and showerheads which act as disseminators. No animal reservoirs exist. No evidence of human-to-human transmission has been found and no carrier state is established.

The symptoms of Pontiac fever develop following an incubation period of 24-48 hours, and include a flu-like syndrome such as fever, chills, muscle aches, headaches, and fatigue. Unlike Legionnaires' disease, which is a more severe pneumonia, Pontiac fever does not involve lung infection and usually self resolves.

Other options: 

Option A: Chlamydia pneumoniae is a common cause of respiratory diseases such as sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia.

Option B: Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes atypical pneumonia. Patients present with dry cough, fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms.

Option D: Haemophilus influenzae can cause various infections, including pneumonia and meningitis. It is not a cause of Pontiac fever.

questions.text: Fincham’s test was done for a patient presenting with blurred vision and colored halos that did not disappear on irrigation. The halos were broken up when the stenopaeic slit was moved. What is the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
In Fincham's test, the breaking up of halos when the stenopaeic slit is moved indicates that the halos are due to a lenticular cause such as a cataract. 

Colored halos can be seen as rainbow-colored rings around lights at night. They occur as a result of the prismatic dispersion of light caused by various conditions such as: 

  • Cataract
  • Acute angle-closure glaucoma
  • Mucopurulent conjunctivitis
  • Corneal edema

Fincham's test distinguishes between the colored halos caused by cataracts and glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaeic slit before the eyes across the line of vision and noting the changes observed in the halos. A lenticular halo, such as one due to a cataract, breaks up into fragments, similar to the wings of a fan, and moves together. A glaucomatous halo, however, remains intact but diminishes in intensity.

Other options:
Option B - Angle-closure glaucoma/glaucomatous halos involve the history of colored halos along with periodic blurring of vision. Fincham's test shows intact halos that are diminished in intensity.

Option C - Halos due to conjunctivitis is because of the associated mucopurulent discharge over the cornea. These halos can be eliminated by irrigating the eye and removing the discharge.

Option D - Fuchs' dystrophy is the most common endothelial corneal dystrophy, more common in elderly females. This condition is caused by endothelial changes and the formation of hyaline excrescences on Descemet's membrane (cornea gutta). Patients present with morning halos that later disappear. A slit-lamp examination shows hexagonal endothelial cells and central guttate spots.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text:
Match the embryological origin with their derivatives.
            Embryological origin                 Derivatives 

      a) Septum transversum

      1) Hepatogastric ligament

      b) Dorsal pancreatic bud

       2) Duct of santorini

      c) Ventral pancreatic bud

       3) Kupffer cells
      d) Ventral mesogastrium       4) Gastrophrenic ligament
      e) Dorsal mesogastrium       5) Uncinate process
questions.solution:
All the above structures are the embryological of the digestive system. The liver bud, ventral pancreatic bud and dorsal pancreatic bud arise from the foregut, ventral mesogastrium arises from the septum transversum and dorsal mesogastrium arises from the lateral plate mesoderm. 

Ventral and dorsal mesogastrium develop into the peritoneal connections in the abdomen which are together called ventral and dorsal mesentery. 

Liver is developed by the septum transversum and the hepatic bud.

Ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds give rise to the pancreas and the pancreatic ducts. When the duodenum rotates to the right to form a “C” shape, the ventral pancreatic bud moves dorsally. It moves such that it comes to lie immediately below and behind the dorsal pancreatic bud. Later the parenchyma and the ducts of both the buds fuse. Development of pancreas is as shown in the below image.

Embryological origin of foregut structures 

                   Derivatives

1) Respiratory bud

 Trachea, primary bronchial buds

2) Liver bud

 Hepatocytes, biliary apparatus

3 )Septum transversum

 Kupffer cells, stromal connective tissue

4) Ventral pancreatic bud

 Uncinate process, lower head of pancreas, duct of Wirsung

5) Dorsal pancreatic bud

 Upper head of pancreas,neck, body and tail of pancreas, duct of Santorini

6) Ventral mesogastrium

 Falciform ligament, lesser omentum(hepatogastric ligament, hepatoduodenal ligament)

7) Dorsal mesogastrium

 Greater omentum, gastrophrenic ligament, gastrosplenic ligament, lienorenal ligament

questions.text: The first internal organ to putrify is  usually the __________
questions.solution:
The order of putrefaction of organs from first to last:

Larynx and trachea—> Stomach, intestine, spleen—>Liver and lungs —> Brain—>Heart—->Kidney and the bladder—>Prostate and uterus—>Bones

  • first external sign: Greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.
  • Earliest internal change: Reddish-brown discoloration of the inner surface of vessels, especially of the aorta.
  • Sulphmethemoglobin is the agent imparting greenish color.

Related Pearl: Order of Putrefaction

  • Larynx and trachea – first organ to putrify   
  • Stomach, intestine, and spleen
  • Liver and lungs
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney and bladder
  • Prostate and uterus – virgin uterus resists putrefaction whereas uterus soon after delivery putrefies rapidly.
  • Skin, muscle, tendon
  • Bones


NOTE: This is only a generalised order of putrefaction, as each case must be assessed as per the attending factors, both endogenous and exogenous.

questions.text: All of the following are entirely retroperitoneal organs except which one?
questions.solution:
The duodenum is a retroperitoneal organ except for the proximal 2.5 cm of the first part of the duodenum which is intraperitoneal.

The duodenum is divided into 4 parts: first (superior), second (descending), third (horizontal), and fourth (ascending) parts. The duodenum is mostly a retroperitoneal structure, except for the proximal 2.5 cm of the first part. It is also fixed except for the 2 ends which are suspended by peritoneal folds.

Organs that rest directly on the posterior abdominal wall, and covered by the peritoneum on one side are retroperitoneal. Examples include most of the duodenum, pancreas, kidney, ureter, and suprarenal adrenal glands.

Other options: 

Option A: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that lies transversely across the posterior abdominal wall.

Option C and D: The kidneys and adrenal glands are retroperitoneal organs and are only partly covered by the peritoneum anteriorly.

questions.text: A patient complains of an itchy rash in sun exposed areas 3 days after starting doxycycline. He has taken the drug in the past without any complaints. Eczematous lesions are visible on sun exposed areas of face and neck. Photopatch test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an itchy rash and eczematous lesions in sun exposed areas of face and neck 3 days following tetracycline use. Positive photopatch tests points to a diagnosis of photoallergic reaction.

It is a delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction with a predilection for photo exposed sites with well‐demarcated margins where the skin is covered by clothing (at the collar and ‘V’ of the neck, on the backs of the hands, and on the ankles). It spares the skin behind the earlobe (Wilkinson’s triangle) since it is a photo-protected site.

Treatment includes photoprotection, withdrawal of the drug, and antihistamines. Topical steroids are used in mild cases, and systemic steroids or methotrexate are used in severe cases.

Chemical and drug-induced photodermatoses could be phototoxic or photoallergic. 

  Phototoxic reaction Photoallergic reaction
Amount of drug required Large Small
Latent period Immediately after light exposure

Delayed
Symptoms Pain or burning Pruritus
Signs Erythema, edema, bullae Eczematous
Photopatch test Negative Positive

Photopatch test: The standard patch test units are applied in two sets (on either side of the spine) and kept covered. One set of patches is removed and exposed to UVA. After irradiation, the other set of patches are also removed and both the sites are covered again for 48 hours. A positive reaction on the irradiated side only is an indication of photoallergy. Negative reaction is seen in phototoxic reaction (Option A).

Other options: 

Option C: Photosensitive lichenoid eruption is a variant of polymorphic light eruption, and is characterized by confluent small, shiny papules on the dorsal aspects of forearms and ‘V’ of chest and neck. Seen mainly in fair complexioned women. Face is spared.

Option D: Actinic prurigo is a rare idiopathic photodermatosis affecting sun exposed skin. It is a variant of polymorphic light eruption with a strong genetic component.

questions.text: The return of normal motility following postoperative paralytic ileus occurs last in which of the following parts of the GIT?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the return of normal motility occurs last in the colon.

The return of normal motility occurs in the following temporal sequence:

Small intestine (within the first 24 hours) → Stomach (within 48 hours) → Colonic motility (3 to 5 days)

Paralytic ileus is a form of adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves secondary to neuromuscular failure (i.e., in the myenteric [Auerbach’s] and submucous [Meissner’s] plexuses). Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain.

Clinical features :

The resultant stasis leads to the following:

  • Accumulation of fluid and gas in the bowel
  • Distension that can be marked with tympanitic resonance
  • Vomiting (effortless)
  • Absence of bowel sounds
  • Absolute constipation.
  • Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy:
    • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
    • No passage of flatus
  • Colicky pain is not a feature.
  • Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary).

Treatment:

  • Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until the return of bowel sounds and passage of flatus.
  • Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids plays a key role in the generation and transmission of visual impulses in the retina?
questions.solution:
Phosphatidylinositol (PI) is responsible for signal transmission as well as the generation of impulses in the retina. 

Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process.

Visual pigments are a type of G-protein-coupled receptors. The receptor protein, known as opsin, is locked in its inactive state by 11-cis retinal. Isomerization and photo-excitation result in the activation of G-protein and the production of cyclic GMP. Transducin serves as the G-protein specifically within the retina.   The nerve impulse that is produced in the retina is then conveyed to the visual centres in the brain. The signal is ended through the process of phosphorylation, specifically targeting a serine residue on the activated rhodopsin. This phosphorylation is carried out by an enzyme called rhodopsin kinase. The purpose of this phosphorylation is to allow the inhibitory protein beta-arrestin to connect to the rhodopsin and deactivate it.

The phos­phorylation of membrane-bound phosphatidylinositol(PI) produces polyphosphoinositides such as phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2).

The degradation of PIP2 by phospholipase C occurs in response to the binding of a variety of neurotransmitters, hormones, and growth factors to receptors on the cell membrane. The degrada­tion products are :

  • Inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) which mediates the mobilization of intracellular calcium
  • Diacylglycerol (DAG) which activates protein kinase C

Both of these act synergistically to evoke specific cellular responses thus accomplishing signal transmission.

questions.text: A senior resident working in an intensive care unit has assembled the following equipment to perform a procedure. Which of the following procedures he would be performing?
questions.solution:
From the materials which have been gathered by the senior resident, it can be inferred that he would be performing a central venous catheterization.

The image below shows the equipment for performing a central venous catheterization.

The instruments are numbered as follows:

  1. A syringe with a local anesthetic
  2. Scalpel in case venous cutdown is needed
  3. Introducer needle on the syringe with saline to detect backflow of blood upon vein penetration
  4. Guidewire
  5. Tissue dilator
  6. An indwelling catheter
  7. Additional fasteners, and corresponding surgical thread

The catheter can be inserted into any of the following veins - Right and internal jugular veins, subclavian vein, external jugular veins, and femoral vein.

Indications of central venous catheterization include

  • Central venous pressure monitoring
  • Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring
  • Transvenous cardiac pacing
  • Temporary hemodialysis
  • Drug administration (concentrating vasoactive drugs, hyperalimentation, chemotherapy, agents irritating peripheral veins, prolonged antibiotic therapy)
  • Rapid infusion of fluids
  • Aspiration of air emboli
  • Inadequate peripheral venous access
  • Sampling site for repeated blood testing

Complications of central vein catheterization are

  • Arterial puncture - This is the most common mechanical complication. 
  • Cardiac tamponade - This is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • Pneumothorax - This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization as a result of injury to the underlying pleura.
  • Chylothorax - This can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • Injury to the associated nerves - like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • Thromboembolism - This can lead to venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. It is more common with femoral veins.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: If used early reduces cardiac output
It is to be removed 48 hours after birth
Delayed clamping should be avoided in Rh- pregnancy
Increases iron stores in the baby

questions.solution:
The given image shows an umbilical cord clamp. It should be kept in place until it falls off with the detached stump of the umbilical cord.

It is made of plastic and supplied in a sterile pack. It occludes the umbilical vessels effectively. In preterm infants, delayed clamping may improve transitional circulation, establish better red blood cell volume, reduce the need for blood transfusion and reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage. It should be delayed by 30-60 seconds after birth.

Other options:

Option A: If performed early reduces cardiac output owing to reduced preload to the left ventricle whereas if performed late permits sufficient aeration of the lung and improved / smoother transitioning to a better cardiac output.

Option C: Early cord clamping is advised in Rh-negative pregnancy, babies with asphyxia, or infants of diabetic mothers. Early clamping can also reduce the need for phototherapy due to hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants will increase haemoglobin levels at birth and improve iron stores for the first few months. This may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.

questions.text: All of the following nutrients are present in egg except

questions.text: A patient with impacted wax develops a severe cough while performing the following procedure on him. This is due to stimulation of which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
The image shows syringing which is a procedure done for impacted wax. Reflex cough due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus can occur during this procedure.

Wax is made up of sebaceous and ceruminous gland secretions, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin, and dirt. Factors contributing to the accumulation and impaction of excess wax may be a narrow, tortuous external canal, stiff ear, or obstructive lesions in the canal.

Patients with impacted wax may present with impaired hearing, tinnitus or giddiness. Long-standing impacted wax may ulcerate meatal skin and result in the formation of a wax granuloma.

Wax removal is achieved through syringing or other instrumental manipulation. Hard impacted mass may require prior softening with wax solvents in some cases.

The patient is seated, with the ear to be syringed facing the examiner. The patient wears a kidney tray over his or her shoulder and to collect the return fluid, the patient's head is tilted over the tray. A stream of water from the syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus as the pinna is pulled upwards and backward. The ear canal and tympanic membrane must be inspected and dried with a pledget of cotton at the end of the procedure.

Complications of syringing:

  • Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
  • Rupture of the tympanic membrane
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation

Contraindications for syringing:

  • Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
  • Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents with redness, pain, and photophobia in his left eye. Findings on fluorescein staining are given below. Which of the following agents can be used to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with unilateral eye redness, pain, photophobia, and fluorescein staining findings revealing the characteristic dendritic ulcer is suggestive of viral epithelial keratitis. Of the given agents, acyclovir 3% eye ointment can be used to manage this condition.

Herpes viral keratitis, also known as herpetic keratoconjunctivitis, is a form of keratitis caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea. The virus, which lies dormant in the trigeminal ganglion after an initial infection, periodically reactivates and replicates. These reactivations result in unilateral symptoms of epithelial or stromal keratitis. 

Epithelial keratitis presents with redness, pain, photophobia, tearing, and decreased vision. A dendritic ulcer is the most common lesion associated with epithelial viral keratitis. It is an irregular, zig-zag, and linear branching ulcer whose floor can be stained with fluorescein. Other manifestations of epithelial keratitis may include superficial punctate lesions and vesicles, which may erupt to form a large 'geographic ulcer.'

Topical antiviral drugs are the first choice in treatment. Acyclovir 3% eye ointment is the least toxic and most commonly used agent. Other topical agents include trifluorothymidine 1% eye drops and vidarabine 3% eye ointment. Ganciclovir can also be used as a 0.15% ophthalmic gel. However, it is more toxic than acyclovir.

Other options:
Ciprofloxacin 0.3% eye drops (Option A) is used in the treatment of uncomplicated bacterial corneal ulcer. The ulcer, in this case, is oval with an associated hypopyon (shown below).

Gentamycin eyedrops (Option B)are typically used in bacterial conjunctivitis.

Natamycin 5% eye drops (Option C) is used in the management of fungal corneal ulcer. The ulcer in this case has feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation (shown below). There may be associated satellite lesions (red arrows below) and a large hypopyon.

    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

    • Geographical ulcer

  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis

  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a swelling over the tibia which is gradually progressing in size and associated with pain for 8 months. An x-ray shows a dense lytic lesion with a sclerotic margin. What’s the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis arrived from the above-given clinical scenario is Brodie’s abscess.

Brodie abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

The above X-ray shows the dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction in the upper end of the tibia.

All the given conditions may present a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess Children, adolescents A lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents, and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years

A lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction, 

soap bubble appearance
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance

Other options:

Option A: Osteoclastoma cannot be the diagnosis as it is unlikely to occur in a 12-year-old and X-ray findings would show a typical soap bubble appearance.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a rapidly growing malignant tumor. It is unlikely to have a gradually progressing course which is more suggestive of a subacute condition like Brodie's abscess.

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma is unlikely to occur in the upper tibia as it is a diaphyseal tumor.

questions.text:
Match the following food adulterants with the respective conditions they result in
  1. BOAA
  2. Sanguinarine 
  3. Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
  4. Clavine alkaloids

 

  1. Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
  2. Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
  3. Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
  4. Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice
questions.solution:
The correct match is: 

  • BOAA - Lathyrism
  • Sanguinarine - Epidemic dropsy
  • Pyrrolizidine alkaloids - Endemic ascites
  • Clavine alkaloids - Ergotism 
Disease   Food Substance  Toxic Principle  Clinical features
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus /Khesari dal  BOAA (beta oxalyl amino alanine) Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine  Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Acute- Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness
Chronic- Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids  Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice

 

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram dal or Bengal gram dal. It is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities. It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism. The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water.  Parboiling can be used for detoxifying the crop on large-scale operations. Overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling is also effective in destroying the toxin. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/split/flour).

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test 

The weed seeds of Crotalaria contain Pyrrozolidine alkaloids that are hepatotoxic. The millet Panicum milaire gets adultered or contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria, produces symptoms of endemic Ascites, which is rapidly developing ascites and Jaundice.

Preventive measures:

  • Sieving of millets at home
  • Deweeding of Jhunjhunia plants
  • Health education

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20 percent saltwater. Floatation and handpicking can also be used in the removal of them. 0.05 mg per 100 grams of food material is the upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids.

questions.text:
The histological images of four brain tumours are given below. Pick out the correct match.
  1. Schwannoma
  2. Oligodendroglioma
  3. Glioblastoma multiforme
  4. Medulloblastoma
questions.solution:
The correct option is C: A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4

Image A -

The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells is seen in oligodendroglioma.

  • These are infiltrating gliomas comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes.
  • Common in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter.
  • The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).

Image B - 

The image shows verocay bodies which are seen in schwannoma. These are nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading.

It consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

Image C - 

The image shows pleomorphic cells characteristic of glioblastoma multiforme.

Grossly, glioblastomas are found infiltrating the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages.

  • They are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity.
  • Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic.
  • They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis, which is characteristically seen in this image above

Image D -

The image shows a densely cellular medulloblastoma

  • These tumors will have sheets of anaplastic cells. The individual cells are small, with scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Mitosis is abundant and markers of cellular proliferation are abundant
  • The tumour may express neuronal (neurosecretory) granules, form Homer-Wright rosettes and express glial markers (GFAP)
  • There are two variants - nodular desmoplastic and the large cell variant. The nodular desmoplastic variant has areas of stromal response, marked by collagen and reticulin deposition and nodules forming pale islands. The large cell variant has irregular vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli and apoptotic cells 

 

Note:

Fried eggs in pathology:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

questions.text: A patient presents with dizziness and fatigue. His EKG shows dropped beats after every 3 PR intervals. Which of the following is true about his condition?

choices.text: The ventricular rate is lower than the atrial rate
The ventricular ECG complexes are distorted
There is a high incidence of ventricular tachycardia
Stroke volume is normal or increased

questions.solution:
In second-degree heart block, not all atrial impulses are conducted to the ventricles. So, the ventricular rate is lower than the atrial rate.

The description of dropped beats after every 3 PR intervals suggests a type of second-degree heart block, Mobitz type I (Wenckebach). In this condition, the PR interval is progressively prolonged until a beat is dropped (i.e., a QRS complex is missing). The ventricular rate is lower than the atrial rate because some atrial impulses (P waves) are not conducted to the ventricles, resulting in fewer ventricular contractions compared to atrial contractions.

Other options:

Option B: This option is incorrect as Mobitz type I heart block typically shows normal QRS complexes.

Option C: This option is incorrect, as Mobitz type I is not associated with a high incidence of ventricular tachycardia. 

Option D: In second degree heart block, due to the lost beat, there is an overall decrease in the stroke volume. Thus this option is not entirely correct and Option A is more appropriate

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: The type of speech seen in peritonsillar abscess is _______
questions.solution:
Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy. 

 

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. 

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat/ Dysphagia 
  • Drooling of saliva 
  • Trismus 
  • Ipsilateral otalgia 
  • Fever 

Management: Antibiotics and Incision & Drainage to drain the abscess followed by Interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is undergoing surgery for the correction of a clubfoot deformity that has not improved with a POP cast. The surgeon removes a part of the calcaneum bone in a wedge shape to correct the varus deformity. What is the procedure performed?
questions.solution:
Dwyer’s osteotomy procedure is the operative procedure of choice for correction of clubfoot in the age group of 5-8 years that has not been corrected by conservative methods. It involves an open-wedge osteotomy of the calcaneum to correct the varus deformity.

The age-wise treatment protocol for correction of clubfoot is as follows:

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age. If the deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night.

If the deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR), also called Turco’s procedure (Option A)
  • 3-5 years: Dilwyn Evans procedure - PMSTR + calcaneo-cuboid fusion (Option B)
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy - wedge osteotomy of the calcaneum
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy - wedge osteotomy of the mid tarsal bones
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis (fusion of subtalar, calcaneo-cuboid and talo-navicular joints) external fixators (Ilizarov’s, Joshi’s) (Option D)

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a history of headache, pulsatile tinnitus, and transient visual obscurations. Her only medication is an OCP. She has papilledema and bilateral sixth nerve palsies. MRI reveals a normal brain parenchyma but empty sella. CSF examination shows elevated opening pressure with normal cell count and protein levels. What is the most appropriate drug for treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that is the first-line treatment for idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). It works by decreasing the production of cerebrospinal fluid, which helps to reduce intracranial pressure. 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension refers to a rise in intracranial pressure in the absence of a structural lesion or hydrocephalus. There is an association with obesity, female gender, pregnancy, and drugs such as tetracycline, vitamin A/retinoid derivatives. Patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension typically present with a generalized headache that is present on waking up in the morning and improves as the day goes by. Transient visual obscurations are frequent during severe headache episodes. Elevated intracranial pressure can also cause VI cranial nerve palsy, causing diplopia. On examination, papilledema is seen. If accompanied by appropriate history, papilledema is considered the diagnostic sign of idiopathic intracranial hypertension. 

The initial evaluation of patients suspected of elevated CSF pressure is done with an MRI, including an MR angiogram. Measurement of CSF pressure using lumbar puncture can also be done. High opening pressure and improvement in the headache following CSF removal are considered diagnostic if papilledema is absent. CT of the head is often normal, but may show empty sella in some patients. Initial treatment is with diet and lifestyle modifications targeted at achieving the ideal BMI. The first-line pharmacotherapy is with Acetazolamide. If ineffective, Topiramate is the next drug of choice. Patients in whom chronic papilledema is threatening vision, optic nerve sheath fenestration, or lumbo-peritoneal shunt may be considered. Acetazolamide can cause side effects such as paresthesias, dysgeusia, and kidney stones.

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is not effective for treating IIH.

Option B: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that can be used to temporarily reduce intracranial pressure. However, it is not as effective as acetazolamide for long-term treatment of IIH.

Option D: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used for migraine prophylaxis, and is ineffective for IIH.

questions.text: You should perform a shake test prior to using all of the following vaccines, except ________.
questions.solution:
Only the injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is freeze sensitive, not the oral polio vaccine (OPV). Hence, a shake test is not relevant for OPV.

The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial, and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing, and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze sensitive:

  • Hep B
  • Pentavalent
  • IPV
  • DPT 
  • TT
  • PCV

Vaccines like OPV and rotavirus vaccines do not lose their potency and efficacy on freezing. Hence, these vaccines can be used again once they liquefy.

questions.text: A patient with a mechanical prosthetic valve is on a long-term oral coumarin anticoagulant. Which of the following coagulation factors will functionally reduce due to this drug?
questions.solution:
The coagulation factor II will be functionally reduced due to the use of oral coumarin anticoagulant. 

Coumarin anticoagulants, such as warfarin (most commonly used), are vitamin K antagonists that act by indirectly interfering with the production of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. 

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase which is inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

Warfarin is chiefly used as a chronic anticoagulant (e.g., in venous thromboembolism prophylaxis or for preventing stroke in atrial fibrillation). It is also used as an anticoagulant to prevent systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

However, warfarin toxicity can lead to bleeding that may even be fatal. Its dose is regulated by measuring prothrombin time and international normalized ratio (INR) levels. Treatment of toxicity involves withholding the anticoagulant, administration of vitamin K, and giving prothrombin complex concentrate or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

questions.text: A young man presents with diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, passage of mucoid stools and tenesmus for 5 months. His physician advises a Barium X-ray to be done. Which of the following techniques is used to obtain the desired X-ray?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, passage of mucoid stools and tenesmus are highly suggestive of Ulcerative colitis (UC). Since the large intestine is involved in this condition, the technique used to obtain the desired X-ray is a double-contrast barium enema.

Ulcerative colitis(UC) is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the rectum and extends proximally to involve some parts of the colon.

A double-contrast barium enema is done which involves the administration of a contrast material, usually barium sulfate, into the rectum through a tube. The barium coats the lining of the colon and rectum, allowing for better visualization of any abnormalities or structural changes. 

In UC complete loss of haustral markings in the diseased section of the colon is seen, and the organ appears smooth-walled and cylindrical; giving it the appearance of a lead pipe.

Patients of UC typically present with diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, crampy abdominal pain, and mucus discharge. They may also present with anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Diagnosis can be made by colonoscopy followed by a biopsy. Salazopyrine/Sulfasalazine and Mesalamine (5 ASA) are used in first-line therapy of UC. Steroids are used in refractory cases.

Other options:

Option A: Barium swallow is used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used). They are used in hiatus hernias, tumours, reflux from the stomach, disorders of swallowing.

Option C: Barium meal is used to assess the stomach and duodenum (95% BaSO4 is used). Used in ulcers, small fleshy lumps (polyps), tumours

Option D: Barium meal follow through is used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used). It is performed following a barium meal examination where X-rays are taken 10-15 minutes after the intake of barium. This allows time for the barium to reach the small intestine.

questions.text: A child is brought by his parents to the OPD with ears as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes his anomaly?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a boy with protruding ears which is caused due to a large concha with a poorly developed antihelix.

questions.text: An HIV-positive male patient is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. The consultant adds emtricitabine, a drug with dual antiviral activity, to his treatment card. This drug belongs to which of the following classes of antiviral agents?
questions.solution:
Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It has activity against HIV-1, HIV-2, and hepatitis B viruses (HBV).

Emtricitabine is an FDA-approved drug for treating HIV infection in adults, children, and infants, in combination with other antiretroviral agents. It is also approved for HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (in combination with tenofovir) in adults with a high risk of acquiring the infection.

It has good oral absorption and can be taken without regard to meals. It is excreted unchanged in the urine and the dose should be reduced in patients with poor renal function.

Emtricitabine is one of the least toxic antiviral drugs. Prolonged exposure can cause hyperpigmentation of the skin, especially in sun-exposed areas. It should not be abruptly discontinued in HBV patients as it can lead to a rebound of HBV replication and exacerbation of hepatitis.

questions.text: An elderly patient was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and was started on beta-blockers. However, the patient continued to have symptoms despite it's use. He was then started on ivabradine. This drug improves the symptoms of angina by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine decreases the automaticity in the sinoatrial node and thus reduces the heart rate. This reduction in the heart rate decreases the myocardial oxygen demand.

The oxygen requirement of the heart mainly depends on the work done by the heart. This work mainly depends on cardiac output and peripheral resistance. An increase in these parameters will increase the oxygen requirement of the heart.

Important determinants of cardiac output are:

Stroke volume- It is the amount of blood pumped out of the heart during each heartbeat. This stroke volume increases whenever, there is increased venous return to the heart, increased end-diastolic volume (preload), and increased contractility. Contractility further depends on the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber and the autonomic innervation.

Heart rate- Increased heart rate increases the cardiac output which in turn increases the oxygen requirement. Heart rate is controlled primarily by the autonomic nerves, with sympathetic stimulation increasing the rate and parasympathetic stimulation decreasing the rate.

Afterload- The tension at which the load is lifted is called afterload. As the afterload increases, the heart has to work more in order to pump blood to the organs. This in turn results in increased oxygen requirement. It is dependent on the peripheral resistance. 

Drugs used in the management of angina either decrease the work done by the heart or increases the blood flow to the heart.

  • Nitrates- They increase the cGMP and cause venodilation. It mainly results in an increase in venous capacitance and a decrease in the ventricular preload. They might also increase coronary flow in some areas and in variant anginas.
  • Calcium channel blockers- Blocking the calcium channels leads to the relaxation of vascular smooth muscles and decreased impulses in the conduction system. This leads to decreased peripheral resistance, decreased blood pressure, decreased contractility, decreased heart rate, and decreased oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Beta-blockers- They decrease the oxygen requirement by decreasing the heart rate, blood pressure, and contractility. Some drugs like carvedilol and nebivolol also cause vasodilation.

Newer antianginal drugs

  • Ranolazine- It inhibits the late sodium current and reduces the intracellular calcium concentration. It reduces diastolic tension, cardiac contractility, and work.
  • Trimetazidine- inhibits the fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. It decreases the oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Ivabradine- decreases the heart rate and decreases oxygen requirement.
  • Fasudil- It is a Rho kinase inhibitor. It is useful in coronary vasospasm.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs:

    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the effects of acetylcholine on the heart and the muscarinic receptor M2 through which its actions are mediated. Which of the following change is mediated by muscarinic receptor subtype M2?
questions.solution:
The reduction of cAMP is mediated by the activation of the muscarinic receptor M2. 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein coupled receptors and consist of five subtypes: M1, M2, M3, M4 and M5. 

M2 is a muscarinic cholinergic receptor that is located in the heart. When an agonist binds to the receptor, it opens K+ channels and causes inhibition of adenyl cyclase. This in turn inhibits the activation of cAMP. M4 subtype acts by the same mechanism but is located in the central nervous system. 

M1 is present in autonomic ganglia while glands and smooth muscles contain the M3 subtype. M5 is also located in the central nervous system. These subtypes act by increasing the inositol triphosphate (IP3) and Diacylglycerol (DAG)

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents to the ENT outpatient department with decreased hearing in both ears, often associated with a ringing sensation for the past few years. The Rinne test was negative and the Schwartze sign is seen on otoscopy. Which of the following types of curves will be seen on her impedance audiometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis. As type of curve will be seen on her impedance audiometry. Decreased hearing with ringing sensation, a negative Rinne, and the presence of Schwartze sign indicate a diagnosis of otosclerosis.

Impedance audiometry is an objective test that consists of tympanometry and assessment of acoustic reflexes.  

It is based on the principle that when sound strikes against the tympanic membrane, some of it is absorbed while the rest is reflected. The reflected sound is measured to assess the compliance of the tympanic membrane. The compliance of the membrane is inverse to the intensity of the sound reflected, i.e. lesser the compliance, the more the sound reflected.

There are 5 types of tympanograms based on the change in pressures applied:

  • A- Normal tympanogram. It is seen in normal individuals. 
  • As- Low compliance in normal pressure. Seen in conditions where ossicles are fixed like in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.
  • AD- High compliance under normal pressure. Seen in conditions of ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane.
  • B-  A flat/ dome-shaped tympanogram indicates that there is no change in compliance with changes in pressure. Seen in thick tympanic membrane or fluid in the middle ear.
  • C- Compliance is increased with negative pressure in excess of 100 mmH2O. Seen in eustachian tube obstruction and retracted tympanic membrane.

Uses of impedance audiometry include testing hearing in children and infants.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 20-year-old bodybuilder started a diet of raw eggs as a source of protein, following which he developed dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscular pains. On investigation, he was diagnosed with a vitamin deficiency. Which of the following enzymes does not require this vitamin as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of features like dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscle pain developing in an individual on a raw egg diet is suggestive of biotin deficiency, and carbamoyl phosphate synthetase is the enzyme that is not dependent on biotin.

A protein called avidin is present in the egg white, which binds to biotin in the diet, making biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption. Avidin is heat labile, and boiling of the egg neutralizes its inhibitory activity. One molecule of avidin can bind with four molecules of biotin.

Biotin deficiency is rare, except in individuals on prolonged total parenteral nutrition and those consuming raw eggs. Individuals with a biotin deficiency may develop features such as dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, and hallucinations. Treatment is the administration of an injection of 100–300 mg biotin.

Biotin serves as a co-enzyme for several carboxylase enzymes:

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
    • This enzyme adds CO2 to acetyl CoA, forming malonyl CoA.
    • It is the rate-limiting reaction in the biosynthesis of fatty acids
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
    • Pyruvate + CO2 +ATP → Oxaloacetate +ADP + Pi
    • It provides oxaloacetate, which is the catalyst for the TCA cycle and is an important enzyme in gluconeogenesis.
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
    • Propionyl CoA +CO2 + ATP → Methyl malonyl CoA + ADP + Pi
  • Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase

Biotin also plays a role in the regulation of the cell cycle.

Biotin-independent reactions:

  • Urea and pyrimidine synthesis, with carbamoyl phosphate synthetase as the stepping stone
  • Addition of CO2 to form C6 in the purine ring
  • Conversion of pyruvate to malate by malic enzyme

questions.text: All of the following is observed in cauda equina syndrome except?
questions.solution:
All of the above signs are observed in cauda equina syndrome except knee jerk. In Cauda equina syndrome, the knee jerk is lost.

The cauda equina is a group of nerves and nerve roots arising from the distal end of the spinal cord, typically levels L1-L5 and contains axons of nerves that give both motor and sensory innervation to the legs, bladder, anus, and perineum.

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) results from compression and disruption of these nerves occurs. 

Causes for cauda equina syndrome include:

  • Tumours of the spine
  • Pott's disease
  • Protrusion of disc
  • Fracture-dislocation of the thoracolumbar spine.

Initially, there is saddle-shaped hyperesthesia and later anesthesia involving buttocks, anus, and perineum. Along with this, there is flaccid paralysis below the knee and ankle reflex is lost. Bulbocavernosus reflex is also absent.

The gold standard method of investigation for CES is an MRI.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady with a known history of mitral stenosis presented with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. Which of the following is not true about labor and delivery in this case?

choices.text: Oxytocin is used to control hemorrhage

questions.solution:
From the given options, the false statement about the management of mitral valve stenosis is option D. 

Epidural analgesia is safe in most heart diseases and is not contraindicated.

Management during labor in heart diseases like mitral stenosis: 

Vaginal delivery is preferred over cesarean, and induction of labor is safe. Induction can be done with vaginal PGE2.

First stage of labor:

  • Lateral semirecumbent position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural, combined epidural/spinal, or continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Fluids should not be infused at more than 75 mL/h
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labor and 48 h after delivery
  • Central venous pressure monitoring

Second stage of labor:

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anesthesia
  • Withhold IV ergometrine with the delivery of anterior shoulder

Third stage of labor:

  • Oxytocin by infusion

Cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetric indications such as:

  • Dilated aortic root >4cm
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Acute severe congestive heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
  • Warfarin within 2 weeks of delivery
  • Emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD).

choices.text: There is a defect in neutrophil migration
Delayed separation of umbilical cord is seen
Patients have recurrent infections with excess pus formation

questions.solution:
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is associated with recurrent infections with lack of pus formation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in the function of neutrophils that include migration, adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria. As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count. A characteristic presentation is the delayed separation of the umbilical cord.

There are three types of LAD:

  • LAD 1- Defective beta 2 integrin (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 
  • LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X, leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling.
  • LAD 3- Defective signaling for integrin activation, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. (milder than type 1)

questions.text: A 75-year-old man came with complaints of bilateral pedal edema and decreased urine output for the past one month. He has a past history of diabetes mellitus and has not been under regular treatment. The following histopathological image was obtained after a biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows PAS-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis which is seen in diabetic nephropathy.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis, also known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion is a glomerular lesion characterized by spherical-ovoid deposits of a laminated matrix in the periphery of the glomerulus surrounded by patent or dilated capillary loops. These nodules are PAS-positive and usually contain trapped mesangial cells. The nodules often show features of mesangiolysis, defined as disruption of anchoring interactions between the capillaries and the mesangial stalks, which leads to the formation of capillary aneurysms.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis is encountered in approximately 15% to 30% of individuals with long-term diabetes and is a major contributor to renal dysfunction.

The lesions encountered in diabetic nephropathy are:

  • Glomerular lesions: Capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.

Other options:

Option B: Crescentic glomerulonephritis is also known as rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Histopathology will show compressed glomerular tufts by a crescent-shaped mass of epithelial cells and leukocytes.

Option C:  glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a pattern of immune-mediated injury. MPGN is characterized histologically by changes in the glomerular basement membrane, multiplication of glomerular cells, and the presence of deposits in the mesangial area and glomerular capillaries. The basement membrane shows a 'double-contour' or 'tram-track' appearance on silver or PAS stains. 

Option D: Segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by presence of focal and segmental sclerotic lesions of glomeruli which show obliteration of capillary lumens and deposition of plasma proteins along the capillary wall (hyalinosis). On electron microscopy, there is diffuse effacement of foot processes.

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: The spirochete structure responsible for corkscrew motility is found where?

choices.text: Between outer membrane and peptidoglycan layer
Between peptidoglycan layer and inner membrane

questions.solution:
The endoflagella, responsible for producing corkscrew motility in spirochetes is located in the periplasmic space between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan layer.

Spirochetes are Gram-negative bacteria, but their cell wall differs from other Gram-negative bacteria by the presence of endoflagella. Endoflagella (axial filament) do not protrude outside the organism (Option A) but are present in the periplasmic space between the outer membrane and peptidoglycan layer. The endoflagella that begin at each end, wind around, and overlap at the midpoint of the spirochete.

The endoflagella covers the inner membrane (Option C and D) which provides osmotic stability and covers the protoplasm.

Endoflagella are responsible for various types of motility such as flexion-extension, corkscrew-like rotation, and translatory movement. Corkscrew motility, i.e movement by rotation around the long axis is shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to increase in a patient who is brought to the casualty with acute diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
A patient with diarrhoea has an increase in hematocrit as a relative change.

Dehydrating conditions such as diarrhoea, burns and vomiting, cause loss of fluid from the extracellular compartment. There is no loss from the intracellular compartment and no change in the osmolarity. ECF volume contraction therefore is reflected by a relative increase in hematocrit.

The reverse is what occurs as a physiological change in pregnancy, where ECF volume expansion is reflected as physiological anemia of pregnancy.

Diarrhoea is usually managed by volume replacement with IV fluids. Administration of normal saline, ie, isotonic fluid would similarly lead only to ECF volume expansion with no change in the ICF volume or the osmolarity.

Whenever hypertonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid (ECF), the extracellular osmolarity increases. It causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment. Almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment and fluid diffuses into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is that the volume of ECF increases, the volume of intracellular fluid (ICF) decreases, and the osmolarity of both compartments increase. 

Whenever hypotonic saline is added to ECF, the osmolarity of ECF decreases. This leads to the movement of water from the ECF to the ICF until both attain the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, but the intracellular volume increases to a greater extent. Osmolarity decreases in both the compartments.
