questions.text: Which of the following is false about miRNA?

choices.text: DICER is involved in the processing of miRNA

questions.solution:
The inhibition is done at the level of translation.

RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/ siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs.The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme DROSHA intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequence in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

miRNA expression has been found to be dysregulated in many cancers. Such misregulation is thought to have a causal role in the pathogenesis of such cancers. Some types of miRNAs are oncogenic (referred to as oncomiRs) and are overexpressed in cancerous tissue. On the other hand, tumour-suppressive miRNAs that counteract oncogenic characteristics are found to be underexpressed in cancers.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with sickle cell trait undergoes his annual checkup. He currently feels well, and physical examination is normal. What finding can be expected in his urinalysis?
questions.solution:
Hyposthenuria is typicallt present in the urinalysis of a patient with sickle cell trait. This is because the chronic hemolysis and intravascular sickling in the acidic renall medulla  can damage the kidneys and impair their ability to concentrate urine.

People with sickle cell trait (SCT), or the heterozygous genotype AS, have no symptoms and are considered hematologically normal. They don't have anemia and their red blood cells appear normal in a blood smear. However, hemoglobin electrophoresis will show approximately 40% of their hemoglobin is the abnormal hemoglobin S.

SCT individuals are at increased risk for:

Rhabdomyolysis during vigorous exercise
Venous thromboembolism
Microscopic and gross hematuria (blood in urine)
Hyposthenuria (poor urine concentration)
Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Ohter options:

Option A: Muddy brown casts are typically seen in patients with acute tubular necrosis, which is not a common complication of sickle cell anemia.

Option B:  Myoglobinuria can occur in patients with rhabdomyolysis, which is a rare complication of sickle cell anemia. However, the absence of a history of exertion and muscle pain or weakness on examination makes myoglobinuria unlikely.

Option D: A high urine pH is more commonly seen in patients with metabolic alkalosis, which is not a typical manifestation of sickle cell anemia - chronic sickling leading to CKD can make the pH acidotic.

questions.text: The given incidental finding in the ileum was noted while performing an appendectomy for a child. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Gastric mucosa is the most common heterotropic mucosa seen
Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in children

questions.solution:
The above finding depicts Meckel's diverticulum. Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in adults with Meckel’s diverticula. Bleeding is the most common manifestation in children.

Meckel's diverticulum has a 2:1 male-to-female preponderance and is the most common congenital anomaly of the small intestine. It is situated on the antimesenteric border of the ileum, usually 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve, and occurs due to incomplete closure of the vitelline duct. It is a true diverticulum consisting of all layers. 

It can present as:

  • Incidental findings during surgery
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the form of hemorrhage in children
  • Intestinal obstruction in the form of volvulus, intussusception (urge to defecate, vomiting, red current stools) 
  • Diverticulitis (right lower quadrant pain)

In children, 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in Meckel's diverticulum and is the most accurate diagnostic modality. However, in adults, less ectopic gastric tissue is seen, so the test is not very accurate. The sensitivity and specificity can be improved by the use of cimetidine.

In case of false-negative results, barium studies, mesenteric arteriography, or double-balloon endoscopy can be used for diagnosis.

Treatment is diverticulectomy or segmental resection of ileum containing diverticulum. In children, an incidentally found asymptomatic diverticulum has to be resected.

  • Approx 2 inches in length

The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is a branch of the abdominal aorta and originates at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra in the transpyloric plane. It descends anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas and the third part of the duodenum and posterior to the body of the pancreas and the splenic vein. The left renal vein separates it from the aorta posteriorly.

The branches of SMA include:

questions.text: You observe a resident perform the following test where he abducts the patient's arm on a patient presenting with arm pain. What is the underlying etiology he is suspecting?
questions.solution:
The test shown above is Wright's hyperabduction test. It is done as a provocative test for Thoracic outlet syndrome.

The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. The absence of a pulse indicates a positive test.

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicles, the first rib, and scalene muscles. 

The causes of TOS vary and can include abrupt movements, hypertrophy of the neck musculature, and anatomical variations in which the brachial plexus roots pass through this musculature, cervical rib, edema, pregnancy, repeated overhead motions, or abnormal posture.

Individuals with TOS typically experience upper limb pain, numbness, tingling, or weakness that is exacerbated by shoulder or neck movement. They may complain of pain during activities that include reaching overhead (eg, brushing the hair, holding a telephone to the ear, getting objects from a cabinet), overhead lifting, prolonged typing or working at a computer, or driving. Sensory abnormalities involving T1 are commonly seen in neurogenic TOS.

It can be diagnosed with electrodiagnostic testing and imaging for identifying bony abnormalities, vascular anomalies, and vascular compression. The provocative tests for thoracic outlet syndrome include Adson's test, Wright's test, and Elevated Arm Stress Test/Roos's test.

Several treatment options are available like physical therapy, interscalene injection of anaesthetic agents, and steroids. Surgery is done in cases of vascular compression and failure of non-operative therapy.

The other options mentioned have their own clinical presentations and diagnostic tests:

Subclavian steal syndrome involves reversed blood flow in the vertebral artery due to a blockage in the subclavian artery. It is not diagnosed with Wright's hyperabduction test.

Shoulder impingement syndrome involves compression of the rotator cuff tendons under the coracoacromial arch during arm elevation, diagnosed by other specific tests like the Neer or Hawkins tests.

Frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis) involves stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint itself, diagnosed through clinical examination focusing on the range of passive and active shoulder motions.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: The structure shown in the given image is found in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in all of the mentioned conditions except in schwannoma. 

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include:

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Meningioma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma

 

Verocay bodies are found in schwannomas. Antoni A area is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed Verocay bodies.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

questions.text: The brain of a 32-year-old HIV-positive man, who died following a CNS infection, is sent for examination. Histopathological section reveals a gelatinous mass growing in perivascular Virchow-Robin spaces within the gray matter, producing soap-bubble lesions. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
In immunosuppressed people, Cryptococcus infection evokes virtually no inflammatory reaction. As a result, gelatinous masses of fungi grow in the meninges or in the perivascular Virchow-Robin spaces within the gray matter, and expand it, producing the so-called soap-bubble lesions. Cryptococcus mostly causes lesions in the CNS, involving the meninges, cortical gray matter, and basal nuclei. 

Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

Pathogenesis:

  • Infection is initiated by inhalation of the yeast cells.
  • The primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic or may mimic an influenza-like respiratory infection, often resolving spontaneously.
  • In immunocompromised, the yeasts may multiply and disseminate to other parts of the body, but preferentially to the CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis.
  • Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Clinical findings:

  • Chronic meningitis (Headache, nuchal rigidity, disorientation)
  • CSF pressure, protein concentration and cell count are elevated
  • Cutaneous ulcers, granulomata

Diagnosis:

  1. Specimens - CSF, tissue, exudates, sputum, blood, urine, skin scrapings
  2. Microscopy - 
    • Gram staining shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells
    • India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells; capsules are prominent in this staining.
  3. Culture - 
    • Colonies on SDA at 37°C appears as smooth, mucoid and creamy white.
  4. Serology
    • Demonstration of cryptococcal antigen by latex agglutination test is a sensitive, specific and rapid method for identificcation of cryptococcal meningoencephalitis.

Treatment:

  1. Cryptococcosis without CNS involvement: Fluconazole is the drug of choice
  2. HIV patient with CNS involvement: 
    • Induction: Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine for at least 2 weeks 
    • Maintenance: Oral Fluconazole 

The below image shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink. Note the prominent capsule.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of two pregnancy losses, both of which occurred in the second trimester. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step of management in this scenario is an ultrasound scan.

In this scenario of recurrent second-trimester abortions, cervical insufficiency has to be suspected as one of the main causes. Miscarriages due to cervical insufficiency are characterized by painless cervical dilatation and expulsion of the fetus.

According to the RCOG guidelines, women with a current singleton pregnancy and a previous history of 3 or more preterm births or second-trimester miscarriages are offered history-indicated cervical cerclage at 11 to 14 weeks of gestation.

However, before placing a history-indicated cerclage, patients are offered first-trimester ultrasound screening to ensure viability, and singleton pregnancy and to rule out major fetal anomalies.

Women with a singleton pregnancy and a previous history of one preterm birth or second-trimester miscarriage are offered serial ultrasound scans for the measurement of the cervical length and if the cervical length is less than 25mm at less than 24 gestational weeks, an ultrasound-indicated cervical cerclage may be done at 14 to 24 weeks of gestation.

In women with no prior history of preterm birth and incidentally found short cervix, progesterone therapy is preferred over cerclage. 

Causes of mid-trimester Spontaneous Pregnancy Losses:

Fetal Anomalies  Uterine Defects  Placental causes  Maternal Disorder 
Chromosomal aberrations Congenital anomalies Abruptio, Previa Autoimmune syndromes 
Structural abnormalities Leiomyomas  Defective spiral artery formation  Infections
  Incompetent cervix  Chorioamnionitis  Metabolic causes

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and requested early discharge from the hospital.  However, WBC counts and platelet counts were found to be 15,000 cells/mm3 and 5 lakh cells/mm3 respectively, one-day following delivery. Her body temperature was measured to be 37 degrees celsius. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Start her on high dose antibiotics

questions.solution:
During the first 24 hours following delivery leukocytosis and thrombocytosis are considered normal, hence does not deem any further intervention.

Leukocytosis and thrombocytosis can be observed during and after childbirth. The white blood cell count rarely reaches 25,000/μL, and the increase is mostly caused by granulocytes. Relative lymphopenia and absolute eosinopenia are characteristic. Typically, in the initial few days after childbirth, there is a moderate reduction in the concentration of haemoglobin and hematocrit. If they fall far below prelabor values, a substantial amount of blood has been lost.

Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of 38 °C or higher (100.4 °F) recorded on 2 separate occasions 24 hours apart within the first 10 days following delivery. This excludes the first 24 hours.

Other options:

Options A, C and D: Due to the absence of any other corroborative findings, it would be unnecessary to further investigate this patient with elevated leucocytes and platelets.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought by his mother with growth failure and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations revealed a hemoglobin of  8 g/dL and normal levels of vitamin B12 and B9. His peripheral smear is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing hypersegmented neutrophils with normal vitamin B12 and B9 levels is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare autosomal recessive condition. It occurs due to an error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine resulting in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. It is of two types:

  • Type I - deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase)
  • Type II - deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Children clinically present with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intellectual disability.

Confirmation of the diagnosis requires an assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patient's red blood cells. Anemia responds well to the administration of uridine.

Other options:

Option A: Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. It is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It usually presents as painful monoarthritis that mainly involves the metatarsophalangeal joints of the first toe.

Option B: Severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) occurs due to a deficiency in adenosine deaminase, an enzyme of purine metabolism. This results in the accumulation of adenosine metabolites. This causes premature cell death of B, T and NK cells. Children with SCID present with recurrent oral candidiasis, failure to thrive, diarrhea and interstitial pneumonitis.

Option D: Copper deficiency is usually seen in a condition called Menkes kinky hair syndrome. Children usually present with intellectual disability, hypocupremia, and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: Concentration of which of the following ions predominantly affect the resting membrane potential (RMP) in a neuron?
questions.solution:
Concentration of potassium (K+) ions predominantly affect the RMP in a neuron, as there are more K+ channels open at rest, facilitating the flow of potassium ions across the membrane.

Resting membrane potential (RMP) is the difference in the electrical potentials between the cytoplasm of the cell and the extracellular space. 

At rest, there are more open K+ channels compared to Na+ channels, thus the membrane permeability of K+ is greater. As a result of this, the intracellular and extracellular K+ concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP. Furthermore, the RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of K+ in general. 

Clinical Significance:

In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential leading to a more excitable nerve. The excitable nerve, stimulates the muscle repeatedly causing fasciculations, exhaustion of muscle, and weakness.

In hypokalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is reduced. Thus the RMP is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

questions.text:
An outbreak of MRSA has been reported in a hospital. Which of the following media would be most suitable for screening potential carriers among hospital staff?

MRSA - Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
Prevention of spread of MRSA infections in hospitals during outbreaks involves screening of carriers among hospital staff. Mannitol oxacillin agar is the preferred medium for this purpose.

MRSA outbreaks occur both in the hospital and community settings. Risk factors include poor hygiene, close contact, contaminated material, and individuals with damaged skin. Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene, which alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell wall to PBP-2a, which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

MRSA can be detected by antimicrobial susceptibility test using cefoxitin disk or oxacillin. These antibiotics are surrogate markers for the identification of MRSA. 

Selective media such as mannitol salt agar (nutrient agar with 7.5% NaCl) are useful when staphylococci are expected to be scanty or outnumbered by other bacteria in the sample (e.g. swabs from nasal carriers). Salt is inhibitory to other normal microbiota but not to S. aureus. S. aureus ferments mannitol helping differentiate it from other staphylococci which don't.

Other options: 

Option B: Deoxycholate citrate agar is a selective medium to isolate enteric bacteria such as Salmonella. 

Option C: S. aureus produces small pink colonies on MacConkey agar due to lactose fermentation but it would not be helpful in screening for MRSA.

Option D: Potassium tellurite agar is a selective medium used to isolate Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A patient with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) presents for follow-up. He has a history of progressive dyspnea and dry cough for the past year. His FVC has declined by 10% from the previous year. You propose treatment with Pirfenidone. Which of the following statements regarding Pirfenidone is true?

choices.text: It is a bronchodilator that helps open up the airways.
It is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation in the airways.
It is an antifibrotic agent that slows down the progression of scarring.
It is an antibiotic that treats bacterial infections in the airway.

questions.solution:
Pirfenidone is approved by the FDA for the treatment of IPF. Pirfenidone works by inhibiting the production of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β), a key mediator of fibrosis. It has been shown to slow the decline in lung function and improve survival in patients with IPF.

IPF is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and a recent history of diarrhea. He has associated tenderness over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the management of the CT finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, abdominal pain, a recent history of diarrhea, and an abdominal CT showing a moderate-sized abscess in the right liver lobe is suggestive of an amebic liver abscess. It is an extra-intestinal infection caused by Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating this condition. 

Amebic liver abscess follows intestinal amebiasis. However, a history of diarrhea may not always be present as most patients remain asymptomatic carriers. In patients presenting with the above symptoms, stool examination, serological tests, and radiological imaging help to confirm the diagnosis. 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating invasive amebiasis like an amebic liver abscess. It is a nitroimidazole compound and is a highly active tissue amebicide. Tinidazole, which is another longer-acting imidazole, is also highly effective for the management of this condition. Other tissue amebicides include secnidazole, satranidazole and ornidazole.

Metronidazole is also effective against other anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. It is used in the management of giardiasis, trichomoniasis, anaerobic bacterial infections (e.g., pelvic or abdominal abscesses following surgery), pseudomembranous enterocolitis, and Helicobacter pylori gastritis.

Adverse effects include gastrointestinal manifestations like anorexia, nausea, and a metallic taste. It is known for its ability to produce a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol. Metronidazole can decrease the renal elimination of lithium and potentiate its toxicity. It may also cause significant bleeding in patients on warfarin therapy.

Other options:

Iodoquinol (Option B), paromomycin (Option C), and diloxanide furoate (Option D) are luminal amebicides. They are poorly absorbed and thus reach high concentrations in the bowel and are used in the management of intestinal amebiasis. They are also indicated for invasive amebiasis. However, their role is to eradicate cysts and prevent further transmission. They would not have any direct effect on the extraintestinal liver abscess as seen in this case.

questions.text:
A child presents with anemia, jaundice, and painful swelling of the hands and feet. Peripheral smear shows the presence of crescent-shaped RBCs. Which of the following are potential chronic complications of his condition?
  1. Functional asplenia
  2. Cholelithiasis
  3. Pulmonary hypertension
  4. Neurocognitive decline
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a child presenting with anemia, jaundice, painful swelling of the hands and feet (dactylitis), and crescent-shaped RBCs (sickle cells) on the peripheral smear suggest sickle cell anemia. Potential chronic complications of this condition include functional asplenia, cholelithiasis, pulmonary hypertension, and neurocognitive decline.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which replaces glutamate residue with valine. This results in the production of hemoglobin S (HbS). In the deoxygenated state, HbS molecules interact with each other, forming rigid polymers that give the RBC its characteristic “sickled” shape. Intravascular sickling results in obstruction of blood flow. The sickle cells have a shortened lifespan with resultant hemolysis, which can clinically present with anemia and jaundice. 

Chronic complications of the condition are primarily a manifestation of the above. These include:

  1. Functional asplenia - Chronic splenic infarcts result in most children with sickle cell anemia having complete functional asplenia by 5 years of age. This places them at risk of infection and death, particularly from encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and Neisseria meningitidis.
  2. Cholelithiasis - Chronic hemolytic disease predisposes to the development of gallstones. These are black pigment gallstones composed of calcium bilirubinate and glycoprotein matrix.
  3. Pulmonary hypertension - The exact pathophysiology of pulmonary hypertension in children with sickle cell anemia is unknown. However, plausible explanation includes a combination of chronic thromboembolism and hypoxia. This has been implicated as a significant cause of death in adults with sickle cell anemia.
  4. Neurocognitive decline - Cognitive abnormalities manifest in various aspects such as memory, verbal learning, executive functions, and attention. Children with sickle cell disease are at greater risk for academic failure. Possible underlying causes of neurocognitive dysfunction include cerebral hypoxia or a cerebral infarct (either silent or an overt stroke).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a likely sequelae of deep vein thrombosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient with deep vein thrombosis, he is least likely to develop Mesenteric ischemia. Mesenteric ischemia is caused by obstruction of the mesenteric arteries, the source of the thrombus is most likely to be a left heart phenomenon like left atrial fibrillation.

PE and DVT are part of the same spectrum of venous thromboembolism(Option C). PE occurs due to obstruction of the pulmonary arterial circulation by deep venous thrombi that detach from their site of formation and embolize to the vena cava, right atrium, and right ventricle. Virchow’s triad of venous stasis, hypercoagulability, and endothelial injury, leading to recruitment of activated platelets, provides the ideal environment for thrombus formation.

DVT presents with pain and swelling of the calf (the most common symptom), tenderness and edema. Clinical examination is unreliable and the elicitation of signs such as Homan's or Mose's signs is not recommended owing to the risk of clot dislodgement. Patients with symptoms of PE present with fever, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis. On examination, they can have cyanosis, jugular venous distension, fixed split-second heart sound and pleural rub, but may be subtle or absent. Some patients are asymptomatic.

Depending on the clinical presentation, patients with PE can be stratified as:

  • High-risk (massive) PE is characterized by systemic hypotension. Patients can have dyspnea and syncope and may present in cardiogenic shock. 
  • Intermediate-risk PE is characterized by right ventricle (RV) dysfunction but normal blood pressure. RV dysfunction can be diagnosed with echocardiography and ECG.
  • Low-risk PE is characterized by normal blood pressure and the absence of any RV dysfunction. 

Investigations: 

  • Venous duplex ultrasound to look for thrombi in the leg.
  • Chest x-ray in PE shows hyper lucency in an area of oligemia (Westermark sign). D-dimer levels are elevated and ECG will show sinus tachycardia (the most common ECG abnormality) and an S1Q3T3 sign (an S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III).
  • Definitive diagnosis of PE is by a CT-Pulmonary Angiography.

The management of PE will vary according to the risk stratification:

  • A patient with high-risk PE will primarily be treated with anticoagulation and thrombolysis or catheter/surgical embolectomy.
  • A patient with low-risk PE will be treated with anticoagulation alone, or an IVC filter as secondary prophylaxis.
  • Patients with intermediate-risk PE require individualized treatment. 

Anticoagulation can be done with the classical strategy of low-molecular-weight heparin followed by warfarin, or by low-molecular-weight heparin for 5 days, switched to novel oral anticoagulant like Dabigatran after that. Fibrinolysis, if indicated, is done with recombinant TPA administered over 2 hours. It can be done up to 14 days after the PE has occurred.

Management of DVT:

  • Anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and unfractionated heparin (UFH) if renal impairment is present.
  • After treatment with heparin, patients should be commenced on oral anticoagulants for at least 3 months with either factor Xa inhibitors (rivaroxaban and apixaban) or direct thrombin inhibitors (dabigatran).
  • Other measures such as rest, limb elevation and compression stockings are also used.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic venous insufficiency occurs after long term DVTs which can lead to prolonged back pressure on the valves, thus leading to incompetence. 

Option B: Gangrene of the affected foot can occur in DVT due to a massive clot that leads to obstruction of blood flow upstream to the clot and thus leading to a huge buildup of fluid and eventually gangrene.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text: A patient demonstrates the following abnormal finding with the given test. Identify the underlying etiology.

choices.text: Damage to nerve cells in the ciliary ganglion
Defect in the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex
Defect in the efferent limb of the pupillary light reflex
Lesion in the pretectal nucleus of the midbrain

questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates a Marcus Gunn pupil on the swinging flashlight test. The given clinical finding is a result of a defect in the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex. 

The swinging flashlight test involves shining a light onto one pupil and transferring it to the other pupil after 2 to 3 seconds. This "swinging" movement of the light is repeated several times while observing the response of both pupils. When the input through both optic nerves to the midbrain is equal, both the direct and consensual light reflex will have the same magnitude of pupillary constriction (as given below).

When there is a lesion in one optic nerve, both pupils will dilate instead of constrict due to impaired conduction of light signal through the injured optic nerve. The Marcus Gunn pupil is also called the relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), as the presentation is because of a unilateral defect in the afferent limb of the light reflex. The most common cause of an RAPD is optic neuritis or retrobulbar neuritis. Other uncommon causes include severe retinal diseases (e.g., extensive retinal detachment) or macular degeneration.

 

Other options:
Damage to nerve cells in the ciliary ganglion (Option A) is the underlying cause of Adie's tonic pupil. This affected pupil is slightly dilated, and there is a very minor constriction when light is shone. There is an associated sluggish reaction to convergence.

Defect in the efferent limb of the pupillary light reflex (Option C) would result in the absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and the presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side.

Lesion in the pretectal nucleus of the midbrain (Option D) results in an Argyll Robertson pupil. The cause of the lesion is invariable syphilitic. There is a light near dissociation, which is the absence of light reflex but the presence of accommodation reflex in both pupils.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty after a motor vehicle collision. On examination, he has a cervical collar. He is obtunded, unresponsive to commands, and withdraws to pain. There is a depressed fracture of the skull. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient presenting with head trauma who has a GCS score of 6 and only withdraws to pain, the next step in management is to urgently perform endotracheal intubation. 

Management of any trauma patient follows the ABCDE protocol and securing the airway is the priority. The Glasgow coma scale can be used to assess the need for intubation. This patient's score is likely Eyes - 1, Verbal - 1, and Motor - 4, ie 6. A GCS score of less than 8 is a reliable indicator for intubation. Additionally, this patient has a depressed fracture of his skull which increases his risk for intracranial hemorrhages and brain herniation which may lead to respiratory compromise. 

The steps in Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) include the following:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate). If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control bleeding and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion). Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation). This is most commonly assessed by the Glasgow coma scale and pupil reactivity score (GCS-P).
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress the patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Other options:

A. X-ray of the cervical spine is necessary in this patient to rule out injuries to the C spine but maintaining the airway takes precedence in this case

B. Head end elevation is used in patients with raised intracranial tension as a temporizing measure before definitive management, however, this patient is at risk for airway compromise and requires intubation first. 

D. Urgent surgery might be required in this patient but he will still require some form of imaging studies before surgery. Maintaining his airway is a more important step at this point

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

questions.text: Which of the following features would be characteristic of Frontotemporal dementia?
questions.solution:
Disinhibition and compulsive behavior are key features of Fronto Temporal Dementia. Patients with FTD may exhibit socially inappropriate behavior, poor judgment, and impulsive actions. This is due to the degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes, which are responsible for social cognition and impulse control.

In the behavioral variant (bvFTD), the most common FTD syndrome, social and emotional systems dysfunction manifests as apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, loss of empathy, and overeating, often but not always accompanied by deficits in executive control. A history of personality changes, and compulsivity followed by issues of memory, later on, should raise suspicion for frontotemporal dementia. On histopathology, intraneuronal argentophilic inclusions made of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins may be seen. Neuroimaging in FTD would show atrophy in the frontal and temporal lobes.

Other options:

Option B: Early-onset ataxia is more characteristic of conditions like Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus, spinocerebellar ataxia or Friedreich's ataxia.

Option C: Myoclonus is sudden, involuntary muscle jerks. While it can occur in some neurodegenerative diseases, it is not a feature of FTD. Myoclonus is associated with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Option D: Visual hallucinations are not typically seen in FTD. They are more characteristic of other neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and Lewy body dementia.

questions.text: A patient presents with confusion, nausea, and vomiting and is found to have hyperkalemia. His heart rate is 40 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. His ECG shows tall T waves and flattened P waves. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be used to stabilize the cardiac membrane and improve the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Calcium gluconate is specifically useful to stabilize the cardiac membrane and antagonizes the cardiac conduction abnormalities.

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  • Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective
  • Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin. (Option A)
  • Salbutamol nebulization will also shift potassium inside the cell. (Option D)
  • Remove potassium with calcium-based resins - Sodium polystyrene sulfonate, diuretics, or hemodialysis; binds potassium and is a non-emergent therapy. (Option B)

questions.text: All of the following are obligate intracellular organisms except which one?
questions.solution:
Among the following, mycobacterium tuberculosis is the only organism that is a facultative intracellular pathogen.

Some organisms are able to survive in the intracellular environment. They are classified into obligate or facultative intracellular organisms. Obligate intracellular organisms are entirely dependent on the synthetic machinery of the host cell for replication.

These organisms have developed strategies that inhibit phagocytosis once engulfed into the cell to ensure intracellular survival, such as inhibition of phagolysosome fusion, resistance to lysosomal enzymes and ability to replicate in the cytoplasm.

Examples of obligate intracellular organisms include Toxoplasma gondii, Coxiella burnetii, Mycobacterium leprae, Rickettsia and Chlamydia. 

Examples of facultative intracellular organisms include Salmonella Typhi, Brucella Legionella, Listeria, Nocardia Neisseria meningitidis, Yersinia and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a history of alcohol use disorder and seeks treatment to maintain abstinence. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Acamprosate is a medication specifically designed to help individuals with alcohol dependence maintain abstinence. It works by reducing cravings and preventing relapse. Acamprosate is generally well-tolerated and has few side effects.

Acamprosate is an NMDA antagonist and GABA analogue that is used in the management of alcohol dependence and maintenance of alcohol abstinence. It acts to mitigate the effects of alcohol withdrawal, less effective if not yet abstained from alcohol or in a relapse.

Treatment should be initiated as soon as after achieving abstinence. Augmentation with naltrexone and behavioral and supportive therapies may be more effective than monotherapy. Side effects of the drug include depressed mood, suicidal ideation and gastrointestinal side effects like diarrhea and nausea. Contraindications to acamprosate include severe renal impairment, previous allergy to acamprosate, pregnancy and breastfeeding.

Other options:

Option A: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine primarily used to treat anxiety and insomnia. While it may be helpful for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms, it is not recommended for long-term treatment of alcohol use disorder as it can be addictive and lead to dependence.

Option C: Bupropion is a medication used to treat depression and smoking cessation. It has also shown some preliminary evidence to be helpful in reducing alcohol consumption. However, its effectiveness in maintaining abstinence is not as well-established as acamprosate.

Option D: Varenicline is a medication used to treat smoking cessation. It has no established role in the treatment of alcohol use disorder and should not be used for this purpose.

questions.text: A new disease-modifying drug X is being developed for the management of rheumatoid arthritis. A randomized controlled trial is being conducted among 1000 patients to compare the efficacy of drug X to methotrexate. Identify the phase of the clinical trial.
questions.solution:
The given scenario where a randomized controlled trial is being conducted among 1000 patients with rheumatoid arthritis to compare the efficacy of a new disease-modifying drug X with methotrexate (i.e. the existing standard of care) is indicative of phase 3 of a clinical trial. 

Clinical trials are experimental studies involving humans that compare the therapeutic benefits of 2 or more treatment options, or of a particular treatment to a placebo. They are divided into the following phases:

  • Phase 0 - This is a new strategy being developed to reduce the cost and time of the drug development process. It involves a micro-dosing study undertaken before the phase 1 trial for initial pharmacokinetic assessment. Very low doses, generally about 1/100th of the estimated human dose, are administered to healthy volunteers and pharmacokinetics is worked out. 
  • Phase 1 (Option A) - A phase where subjects (mostly about 10-100 healthy volunteers) are exposed to the lowest possible dose, increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose. The emphasis is to work out the safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous side effects.
  • Phase 2 (Option B) - This phase involves about 100-500 patients with the disease and is used to work out the therapeutic efficacy, optimal dosing strategy, and ceiling effect of the drug in a controlled setting. 
  • Phase 3 - This phase involves a large number of patients (about 500-3000) being assigned randomly to either the treatment under investigation (e.g., drug X in the question) or to the present standard of care (e.g., methotrexate as the first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug). The aim is to establish the value of the drug in relation to existing therapy. If it is better than existing modalities, indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated.
  • Phase 4 (Option D) - This is a phase of postmarketing surveillance of patients after the treatment is approved. It is used to detect efficacy, rare or long-term adverse effects, and evaluate cost-effectiveness.

questions.text:
A food poisoning outbreak occurs at a communal gathering, with attendees experiencing nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea within 48 hours of consuming catered food. Salmonella is identified as the causative agent. Which category of bioweapon does this fall under according to the CDC?

CDC: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
questions.solution:
Food safety threats such as Salmonella, Shigella and Escherichia coli O157 belong to category B of bioweapons according to the CDC.

Bioterrorism is the intentional release of biological agents (i.e. viruses, bacteria, fungi, or their toxins) in order to cause disease or death among the human population or food crops and livestock to terrorize a civilian population or manipulate the government.

The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

Category A bioweapons are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum and Yersinia pestis.

Category B bioweapons are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella. It also includes toxins (Ricin, Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin B and Epsilon toxin of Clostridium perfringens), food threats (Salmonella, Shigella and Escherichia coli O157) and water threats (Vibrio cholerae, Cryptosporidium).

Category C bioweapons are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: A 28 year old female on combined oral contraceptives presents to the clinic on 24th day of her menstrual cycle as she had forgotten to take tablets on the 22nd and 23rd day. What would be your advice for her regarding contraception?

choices.text: Take two pills at the scheduled time

questions.solution:
The last 7 pills in the 28 pill pack are non-hormonal (iron tablets). She can discard the missed pills and continue taking the rest of the pills as usual. 

A woman can start using combined oral contraceptives anytime if it is reasonably certain that she's not pregnant. If she starts taking the pills within 5 days of the start of her menstrual period, she can just continue to take one pill a day and there's no need for backup contraception. If she starts taking pills 5 days after the onset of her menstrual period, then she should use a backup contraceptive (barrier contraception) for the first 7 days.

 

Missed pills Management

Missed 1 or 2 pills

 

 Take the missed pill as soon as possible, resume schedule, no backup method necessary

Missed 2 pills

  • In weeks 1 or 2: take 2 pills daily for 2 days then finish the pack, backup is not needed but advised for 7 days

  • In week 3: Start a new pack. Backup for 7 days.
Missed >3 pills
  • Start a new pack
  • Backup contraception for the next 7 days

 

If any non-hormonal pills were missed, she can discard the remaining pills. Start the new pack of oral contraceptives and continue taking as usual.

If she vomits within 2 hours of taking a pill, another pill from the pack should be taken as soon as possible. After that, continue taking the pills as scheduled. If the vomiting or diarrhoea persists for >2 days, follow the instructions for 1 or 2 missed pills as mentioned above.

The contraceptive method should be discontinued and changed in the following situations:

  • Unexplained or prolonged heavy vaginal bleeding that suggests an underlying condition not related to the method
  • Starting anticonvulsant medication or treatment with rifampicin
  • Migraines
  • Non-ambulatory conditions lasting for >1 week like major surgery, leg in a cast, etc. Combined oral contraceptives can be restarted 2 weeks after ambulation.
  • Suspected heart or liver disease, hypertension, deep vein thrombosis, stroke, breast cancer, diabetes, or gall bladder disease

  • Post-coital pills or interceptive

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is being evaluated for refractory hypotension 1 day after an emergency hernia repair. Per abdomen examination is unremarkable. He has a history of gallstones, rheumatoid arthritis, and bronchial asthma. What is the likely cause of his hypotension?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with refractory hypotension post-op with a past history of rheumatoid arthritis and bronchial asthma is suggestive of an Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.

This patient has a history of both rheumatoid arthritis and bronchial asthma which indicate that he was potentially being treated for the same with glucocorticoids. If the drug isn't continued post-op and replacement corticosteroids are not given intra and post-op, it can lead to an adrenal crisis. Surgery itself is a cause for adrenal insufficiency in a vulnerable patient as it is a period of stress for the body.

The symptoms of adrenal insufficiency are as follows:

  • Glucocorticoid deficiency leads to:
    • Fatigue, lack of energy
    • Weight loss, anorexia
    • Myalgia
    • Hypoglycemia 
    • Low blood pressure, postural hypotension
  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to:
    • Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
    • Dizziness, postural hypotension
    • Low blood pressure, postural hypotension
    • Hyponatremia
    • Hyperkalemia
  • Adrenal androgen deficiency leads to dry and itchy skin, loss of libido 
  • The hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas results from excess ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) secretion which occurs in response to decreased adrenal cortical hormones.

Primary causes of the Addisonian crisis include:

  • Adrenal hemorrhage
  • Acute infection

Secondary causes of the Addisonian crisis include:

  • Surgery
  • Cessation of steroid therapy
  • Postpartum pituitary necrosis.

If a patient displays features of adrenal insufficiency, treatment must immediately be commenced, before awaiting the biochemical diagnosis. Intravenous administration of hydrocortisone 100 mg every 6 hours, >2 liters of saline is given in 6 hours under careful cardiovascular monitoring.

Other options:
Option A - Intraoperative injury to a vessel: While this is a possibility, it would typically present more acutely, often during or immediately after surgery. Also, significant intraoperative vascular injury would likely have been identified during the procedure or would have manifested with more obvious symptoms such as abdominal distension, severe pain, or a drop in hemoglobin.
 
Option C: Sepsis after bowel ischemia is less likely given the lack of peritoneal signs on abdominal examination. Sepsis secondary to bowel ischemia usually presents with significant abdominal pain, tenderness, and often systemic signs of infection.
 
Option D - Complication of anesthesia: While anesthesia can cause hypotension, it is usually transient and resolves within hours after the surgery. Persistent hypotension a day after the procedure is less likely to be due solely to anesthesia, especially in the absence of other symptoms like respiratory depression or altered mental status.
 

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with 50% total body surface area burns sustained in a fire incident is admitted to the burns ICU. Two weeks after admission, he develops a fever of 38.5°C, leukocytosis (WBC 15,000/mm3), and vague abdominal discomfort localized to the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound reveals signs thickened gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid collection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acalculous cholecystitis refers to inflammation of the gallbladder without gallstones. It is a known complication in critically ill patients, including burn victims, due to factors like prolonged fasting, sepsis, and medications. The patient's symptoms and ultrasound findings are consistent with this diagnosis.

It is mainly seen in critically ill patients and those recovering from major surgery, trauma, burns, and patients on total parenteral nutrition. The other precipitating factors include diabetes mellitus, torsion of the gallbladder, and parasitic infestation of the gallbladder. It has a high mortality rate.

Clinical features are similar to that of acute calculous cholecystitis, such as:

Right upper quadrant pain
Fever
Positive Murphy's sign
Leukocytosis
Sepsis

A USG demonstrates a distended gallbladder with thickened wall, biliary sludge, pericholecystic fluid, and the presence or absence of abscess formation. HIDA scan shows a non-visualization of the gallbladder. 

Acalculous cholecystitis requires urgent intervention. Percutaneous ultrasound or CT-guided cholecystostomy is the treatment of choice for these patients, as they are usually unfit for surgery.

Cholecystectomy is performed under a laparoscopic approach after the patient has recovered from the underlying illness.

Option A. Cholelithiasis: This option is incorrect because the patient has acalculous cholecystitis, which means there are no gallstones present.

Option B. Choledocholithiasis: This option is also incorrect. Choledocholithiasis refers to gallstones in the bile duct, which can cause symptoms like jaundice and pancreatitis. However, the patient's presentation is more suggestive of acalculous cholecystitis.

Option C. Cholangiocarcinoma: This option is less likely than acalculous cholecystitis. Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer of the bile ducts, which typically presents with symptoms like jaundice, weight loss, and abdominal pain. The absence of these symptoms and the presence of an edematous gallbladder wall on ultrasound make acalculous cholecystitis a more plausible diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of myasthenia gravis presents with sudden worsening of her muscle weakness, particularly involving her respiratory muscles. Which of the following is the most appropriate inital treatment?
questions.solution:
Myasthenic crisis is a life-threatening exacerbation of muscle weakness, typically caused by diaphragmatic and intercostal weakness leading to ventilatory failure. The most appropriate treatment now is plasmapheresis.

Plasmapheresis is a procedure in which plasma is removed and replaced with fluids or plasma from a donor. Plasmapheresis is effective in removing circulating antibodies that block acetylcholine receptors in myasthenia gravis, leading to rapid improvement in symptoms. It is considered the most appropriate initial treatment for myasthenic crisis.

Myasthenic crisis management requires intensive care.

  1. Exclude "cholinergic crisis" by temporarily stopping anticholinesterase medication if deterioration is suspected.
    Identify and treat any underlying infections immediately.
  2. Ventilatory assistance for breathing support.
  3. Rapid Immunotherapy: Plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin.
  4. Corticosteroids for long-term immunosuppression. Thymectomy may be considered in some cases. Neither of these are administered on an emergency basis.

Option B: Edrophonium: This is a short-acting cholinesterase inhibitor that increases the amount of acetylcholine available at the neuromuscular junction. Edrophonium can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis and to temporarily improve muscle strength. However, it is not effective in severe myasthenic crisis and may even worsen symptoms.

Option C: Corticosteroids can be helpful in the long-term management of myasthenia gravis but are not effective in the acute setting of myasthenic crisis.

Option D: Thymectomy can be beneficial in some patients with myasthenia gravis, but it is not an emergency treatment and is not indicated in myasthenic crisis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is scheduled for cardiac stress testing with Dobutamine. He is currently taking the following medications: Beta blocker, statin, ACE inhibitor and Metformin. Which medication should be withheld prior to the test?
questions.solution:
The beta blocker should be withheld prior to the test.

Beta-blockers should be held 24 hours before the dobutamine stress test due to the opposite antagonistic action.

Beta blockers slow down the heart rate and decrease blood pressure. This can interfere with the results of the cardiac stress test, as the test is designed to measure how well the heart pumps blood under stress.

Other medications that may need to be withheld prior to cardiac stress testing include alpha blockers, calcium channel blockers, and antiarrhythmic medications.

Other options: 
Option B: Statins are cholesterol-lowering medications. They do not interfere with the results of the cardiac stress test and can be continued without interruption.

Option C: ACE inhibitors do not interfere with the results of the cardiac stress test and can be continued without interruption.

Option D: Metformin does not interfere with the results of the cardiac stress test and can be continued without interruption.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement with regard to contact lenses.

choices.text: The field of clear vision is greatly increased from spectacles
Soft lenses are associated with a greater incidence of microbial keratitis
Daily disposable soft lenses can be worn for up to 15 hours
Hard contact lenses are made of hydroxyethyl methacrylate

questions.solution:
Hard contact lenses are made of polymethyl-methacrylate (PMMA). Hence, the incorrect statement with regard to contact lenses is option D.

Contact lenses are thin optical corrective lenses worn on the eye that rest directly on the cornea's surface. They provide multiple advantages over spectacles. The field of clear vision is significantly increased as the prismatic effects of spectacles are eliminated (Option A). Therefore, they are valuable in managing high errors of refraction, especially myopia and aphakia. They are also helpful in managing anisometropia and high errors of astigmatism, such as keratoconus. 

They, however, need special care to avoid infection, allergy, and hypoxia to the cornea. Soft lenses are associated with a greater incidence of microbial keratitis (Option B), especially ones with a high water content used on an extended-wear basis. 

Contact lenses are of 3 types:

  • Hard lenses are made of polymethyl-methacrylate (PMMA). These lenses do not allow enough oxygen to reach the eye, and thus, their use is now restricted.
  • Soft lenses are made from hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA). They are available as daily, weekly, or monthly disposables. Daily disposables are designed to be worn for up to 15 hours for just a day (Option C).
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses are made of a copolymer of PMMA and silicone and cellulose acetate butyrate. They are less likely than soft contact lenses to harbor bacteria and are easier to clean and disinfect. They retain their shape better and provide sharper vision. 

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate)
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with pain and swelling in his right knee undergoes synovial fluid aspiration which shows positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals. All of the following can be used in the management of this condition, except?
questions.solution:
A patient with knee pain and synovial effusion showing positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarized light is likely to be suffering from calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD / pseudogout). Allopurinol (xanthine oxidase inhibitor) which is a urate-lowering agent, is used in the treatment of gout, but has no role in the treatment of CPPD as there is no associated hyper-uricemia in this condition.

The treatment of acute CPPD is similar to an acute flare of gout including ice packs and rest, synovial aspiration and steroid injection, NSAIDs (option A), oral colchicine (option C) and anakinra (IL-1β antagonist) (option D). Daily oral colchicine may be useful as a prophylactic treatment in patients with frequent attacks. 

CPPD is a joint disease of the elderly wherein there is cartilage destruction and accumulation of inorganic pyrophosphates which bind with calcium from the cartilage matrix, and incite an inflammatory response in the joint. As the clinical presentation is similar to gout, it is also called pseudogout; however in contrast to gout, larger joints are affected, the knee joint being the most common and the first metatarsophalangeal joint is rarely affected. Chronic CPPD also mimics osteoarthritis. It is associated with other systemic illnesses such as hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypo-phosphatemia, and may also flare up following surgery and trauma.

X-rays of the joint typically reveal chondrocalcinosis, ie, radiodense deposits within the articular cartilages, but the definitive diagnosis is by synovial aspiration showing positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarized light, (vs gout which shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dull pain and heaviness over the right lower abdomen for two months. Imaging reveals a right-sided multiloculated cystic ovarian mass and cystic dilation of the appendix, with mural calcification. Which among the following conditions is most likely associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.solution:
The condition most likely to be associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei among the given options is a mucinous ovarian tumor.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to abundant mucoid or gelatinous material surrounded by a thin fibrous capsule in the pelvis or abdominal cavity that results from an ovarian mucinous carcinoma with ascites. 

Mucinous ovarian tumors are predominantly true epithelial tumors and are mostly undetected primary intestinal cancers of the appendix or colon. Ovarian mucinous tumors associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei are usually metastatic tumors.

Well-differentiated type of mucinous tumors resembles those that originate from the intestine or endocervix. These are mucin-secreting adenocarcinomas. Advanced mucinous ovarian tumors have the worst prognosis. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department with hemoptysis and severe chest pain. After a few hours, the patient died due to a massive stroke. Autopsy of the lungs revealed pulmonary infarct, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true about the type of infarct?

choices.text: It is seen in tissues with dual circulation.
It occurs in solid organs with end arterial circulation.
As time passes, the infarction becomes progressively paler.

questions.solution:
The autopsy specimen of the lung shows hemorrhagic infarct (red infarct). A red infarct usually occurs in tissues with dual blood supply, such as the lungs. All other options are incorrect.

Pulmonary infarction may occur in patients as a result of pulmonary embolism (PE). The clinical features of PE mimic those of myocardial infarction, and the patient presents with severe chest pain, dyspnea, and shock. Some patients may also present with pleuritic pain, and cough. Emboli that lead to pulmonary infarction additionally cause fever and hemoptysis.

 An infarction is an area of ischemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either arterial supply or venous drainage.

  • The infarctions are usually wedge-shaped, with the occluded blood vessel forming the apex and the periphery of the organ, forming the base.
  • Fresh infarcts are poorly defined. Over a few days, the margins become better defined due to congestion caused by the inflammatory reaction surrounding the lesion.
  • Depending on the appearance, infarction may be either a red infarct or a white infarct. 

Red infarcts occur

  • with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion).
  • in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone.
  • in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone.
  • in tissues previously congested by a sluggish venous outflow.
  • when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

The infarcts in the lung are almost always hemorrhagic. The extravasated red RBCs in the red infarct are phagocytosed by the macrophages, which convert the heme iron into hemosiderin. Over time, the infarction appears brown in color due to the accumulation of the hemosiderin-laden macrophages. 

The image below shows red infarct in the lung.

 

White infarcts:

  • They occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney).
  • It is seen in organs, where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.
  • In contrast to red infarct, the white infarcts tend to become paler as time passes.

The image below shows white infarcts in the spleen.

questions.text: A patient with a phobic disorder is undergoing systematic desensitization therapy. This therapy includes all the following steps, except ____.
questions.solution:
Flooding is not a part of systematic desensitization.

Systematic desensitization is based on the behavioral principle of counterconditioning and was developed by Joseph Wolpe. Counterconditioning involves a gradual approach to a feared situation, in a psychophysiological state that inhibits anxiety, to overcome the maladaptive anxiety elicited by that situation. It works best in cases of a clearly identifiable anxiety-provoking stimulus. It has been successfully used in the treatment of phobias, obsessions, compulsions, and certain sexual disorders.

It consists of three steps:

  • Relaxation training - Patients attain a state of complete relaxation and are then exposed to the stimulus that elicits the anxiety response. Relaxation methods like yoga, progressive relaxation, hypnosis, and mental imagery can be used. The physiological changes during the relaxation process; slow heart rate, increased peripheral blood flow, and neuromuscular stability; are opposite to that of the adrenergic response invoked during anxiety. The relaxed state inhibits the negative reaction of anxiety associated with the phobia and this is known as reciprocal inhibition. 
  • Hierarchy construction - The therapist determines all the conditions that elicit anxiety and the patients prepare a graded list or hierarchy of 10-12 fear-provoking scenes in the order of increasing anxiety.
  • Desensitization of the stimulus - Patients proceed systematically through the list from the least to the most anxiety-provoking scene while in a deeply relaxed state.

Flooding involves repeated and prolonged exposure to fear cues of high intensity without a hierarchy. It is based on the premise that anxiety gets reinforced by conditioning when the patient escapes from the anxiety-provoking situation. Patients are encouraged to face the feared situations directly and are prevented from escaping. There is no gradual build-up or use of relaxation techniques.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. Exposure or anticipation of contact with the situation/object triggers an anxiety reaction. This inadvertently leads to panic attacks in people who are susceptible. The person goes to great lengths to avoid this situation or object. According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5th edition (DSM-5),  phobias are classified under Anxiety disorders.

Behavior therapy is considered the most effective treatment for phobias. Systemic desensitization is the most common behavior therapy used for phobias. Other modes of treatment of phobias include insight-oriented psychotherapy, virtual therapy, hypnosis, and family therapy.
