questions.text: A 12-month-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and difficulty breathing. On examination, the child had inspiratory stridor. The mother says she has been to many doctors in the past, however her child's inspiratory stridor, a weak cry and hoarseness seem to persist. Laryngoscopy performed is as shown below.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of this child, combined with the laryngoscopic image indicating narrowing at the level of the glottis, point to a possible diagnosis of laryngeal web. 

Laryngeal webs are caused due to the incomplete recanalization of the larynx. The web is mostly located between the vocal cords anteriorly. They are of two types thin membranous and thick fibrous type. The primary characteristics are blockage of the airway, a feeble cry, or complete loss of voice since birth. The treatment is contingent upon the thickness of the web. A knife or CO2 laser can be used to cut thin membranous webs.   Thick fibrous webs may need to be surgically removed through a procedure called laryngofissure. A silicon keel (McKnought keel) will be inserted and followed by dilatations after the surgery.

Other options:

Option A: Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency presenting in children with a rapidly progressive course of fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and respiratory obstruction, followed by a toxic appearance and drooling. The neck is hyperextended and stridor is a late finding. Radiography shows a classic thumb sign. Although signs and symptoms show a slight resemblance, however, laryngoscopy leads us to different diagnoses.

Option B: Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, the omega-shaped epiglottis is seen.

Option C: Laryngo-esophageal cleft becomes apparent when there is cricoid lamina fusion failure. The patient experiences recurrent aspiration and pneumonitis. Coughing, choking, and cyanosis are all present during feeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for completed suicide?
questions.solution:
Previous suicide attempt is the strongest risk factor for suicide completion. Studies have consistently shown that previous suicide attempts are the single most important risk factor for future suicide attempts. This is due to a complex interplay of factors, including learned helplessness, hopelessness, and access to lethal means.

Around 40% of patients with depression that committed suicide have had a history of a previous attempt, with the risk of second attempt being the highest in the 3 months following the first attempt.

Indications for hospitalization for suicide prevention include the following: 

  • Suicidal plan of action
  • Inability to discuss safety planning
  • Absence of a strong social support system
  • History of impulsive behavior
  • Psychotic patient 
  • Precautions were taken to evade discovery
  • Severe agitation, poor judgment, and refusal to accept help


A suicide attempt is a psychiatric emergency. While suicide is hard to predict, the patient may unintentionally provide clues to the same. Some high-risk factors for suicide are male sex, age above 45, unemployment, multiple attempts at suicide, and social isolation. Most people who have committed or attempted suicide have an underlying mental disorder, of which depression and schizophrenia are the most common.

During hospitalization, objects that can be used for self-harm should be removed. Anti-depressants or antipsychotics are used depending on the underlying condition. Individual therapy, group therapy, and family therapy are other useful measures.

Suicide attempts and thoughts are more common in women, but the rate of committing suicide is more in men. Suicide rates increase with age and are rare before puberty. 

Several suicide helpline numbers may be dialed toll-free across India and the world as well.

Other options:

Option A: Family history of depression: While a family history of depression can increase the risk of suicide, it is not the most significant risk factor.
Option B: Social isolation: Social isolation can be a contributing factor, but it is not the most important risk factor.
Option D: Substance abuse can exacerbate mental health issues and increase suicide risk, but it is not the strongest factor.

questions.text:
A patient with fatigue and weight loss is found to be HIV positive. Which of the following genera does HIV belong to?

HIV - Human immunodeficiency virus
questions.solution:
HIV belongs to the lentivirus genus, in the retroviridae family. 

The retrovirus family is classified into 7 genera which includes lentiviruses, which is the genus that HIV belongs to.

Lentiviruses possess a linear, positive sense, single stranded RNA genome. They possess a glycoprotein envelope containing a spherical virion with a cylindrical core. They use reverse transcriptase for replication and protease for maturation. Lentiviruses contain the four genes gag, pro, pol, and env required for a replicating retrovirus.  

Genes such as gag, env and pol code for structural proteins. Gag gene codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24. Env gene codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41. Pol gene codes for the enzymes polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease, and endonuclease.

Major antigens of HIV include envelope antigens (gp120, gp41), shell antigen (p18), core antigens (p24, p15, p55) and polymerase antigens (p31, p51, p66).

Other options: 

Option A: Alpharetrovirus is a genus in the retroviridae family, and does not include HIV.

Option B: Deltaretrovirus is a genus in the retroviridae family, which includes human T-lymphotropic viruses (HTLV) but not HIV.

Option D: Flavivirus is a genus that includes arboviruses such as West Nile virus, Zika and Yellow Fever.

questions.text: Within 2 hours of a blood transfusion, a patient develops shortness of breath, tachypnea, and hypoxia. A chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, and catheter measurement confirms non cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Which of the following antibodies is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
TRALI is a complication of blood transfusion that can lead to acute lung injury and respiratory failure. It is characterized by non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema with bilateral infiltrates and signs of hypoxemia. The implicated antibodies are Anti-HLA antibodies that target the recipient's leukocytes.

TRALI - TransfusionRelated Acute Lung Injury - often arises from the transfusion of donor plasma containing high levels of anti-HLA class II antibodies that attach to the recipient's white blood cells. Anti-HLA class I antibodies and anti-human neutrophil antigen (HNA) antibodies can also contribute to TRALI. White blood cells accumulate in the pulmonary vasculature and release substances that increase capillary permeability. Checking the donor's plasma for anti-HLA antibodies can help confirm the diagnosis of TRALI. Multiparous women are frequently the donors responsible for TRALI. The risk of TRALI can be lowered by transfusing plasma and platelets from male and nulliparous women donors. Factors in the recipient that increase the risk of TRALI include smoking, chronic alcohol use, shock, liver surgery (transplantation), mechanical ventilation with a pressure support of >30 cm H20, and a positive fluid balance.

Option B: IgG antibodies against IgA would occur in case of transfusion in a patient with IgA deficiency, and would lead to a severe anaphylactic reaction.

Option C: Anti-platelet antibodies, are involved in the development of transfusion-related thrombocytopenia or post-transfusion purpura, due to a decrease in the number of platelets after a transfusion. 

Option D: Anti-red blood cell antibodies, are involved in the development of hemolytic transfusion reactions (HTRs). HTRs are a spectrum of reactions that can occur when a patient receives blood that is incompatible with their own. HTRs can range from mild to severe and can lead to hemolysis, renal failure, and even death.

questions.text: Which of the following are recommended to optimally manage ARDS?

choices.text: Persistent high FiO2 for initial 72 hours

questions.solution:
Low tidal volume ventilation is a recommended lung protective strategy in ARDS.

Mechanical Ventilation Strategies for ARDS:
Two key mechanisms of ventilator-induced lung injury are:

Volutrauma: Alveolar overdistension from high tidal volume.
Atelectrauma: Recurrent alveolar collapse.

Minimizing Volutrauma: Low tidal volume (VT) ventilation: 6 mL/kg predicted body weight is recommended, leading to improved survival compared to conventional VT (12 mL/kg). and Lower airway pressures: Plateau pressure ≤30 cm H2O.

Minimizing Atelectrauma: Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP): Prevents alveolar collapse and improves oxygenation.
Prone positioning: Improves oxygenation. 

Other options:

Option B: High RR can lead to low CO2 level: Not recommended. While maintaining adequate oxygen levels is crucial, hypocapnia can be detrimental in ARDS- it leads to cerebral vasoconstriction, potentially reducing cerebral blood flow and oxygen delivery. Therefore, permissive hypercapnia is allowed.

Option C: High FiO2: Recommended for initial management. However, persistently high FiO2 can cause oxygen toxicity, and it must be gradually reduced as the patient improves.

Option D: Reverse Trendelenburg positioning: While prone positioning is beneficial for improving oxygenation in ARDS, reverse Trendelenburg is not.
This position can increase venous return and potentially worsen pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A drug X is to be administered orally to a patient weighing 60 kg. The target plasma concentration is 15 mg/L, the apparent volume of distribution is 0.3 L/kg, and the bioavailability of drug X is 50%. Calculate the loading dose of X.
questions.solution:
The loading dose of drug X is 540 mg.

The loading dose is the amount or dose of a drug given to achieve target plasma concentration quickly when the treatment requires an immediate therapeutic response. It is usually given at the onset of therapy.

Loading Dose is given by the formula: 
Loading dose = (Cp x Vd )/ F

where, 

  • Cp is the target plasma concentration
  • Vd is the total volume of distribution, and
  • F is bioavailability.

In this case, the weight of the patient is 60 kg, and the apparent volume of distribution is 0.3 L/kg. Therefore Vd is:
Total volume of distribution (Vd) = apparent volume of distribution x weight = 0.3 x 60 
Therefore, Vd = 18 L

Target plasma concentration (Cp) = 15 mg/L
Bioavailability (F) = 50% = 0.50

On substituting the values in the given formula for the loading dose, we get:
Loading dose= (15 mg/L x 18 L) / 0.50 = 540 mg

questions.text: Following the cesarean delivery of a baby weighing 4.2 kg, the mother developed torrential vaginal bleeding. Examination revealed uterine atony, following which the obstetrician performed a suture as depicted in the image below. Identify the type of suture performed by the obstetrician.
questions.solution:
The procedure is B-lynch compression sutures also known as brace sutures and it is used in atonic PPH. 

B lynch suture is a technique to arrest haemorrhage in severe postpartum atony.

Observe the transverse highlighted region in the image showing a hysterotomy suture which is seen in a B- Lynch suture and absent in Hayman suture and Pereira suture.

The suture bites are taken over the lower uterine segment anteriorly. Then it is looped over the fundus to go posterior. Another bite is taken posteriorly. Then it is looped back over the fundus and taken anteriorly. The final bite is taken over the lower uterine segment and the free ends are tied in a surgical knot, thus compressing the uterus anteroposteriorly. The success rate of this procedure is high with ischaemic uterine necrosis being a plausible complication.

questions.text: You witness a patient undergo an amputation in a road traffic accident. What is the correct way to transport the amputated part to the hospital?

choices.text: Place directly in a clean container and place that container on ice
Wrap in saline-soaked-gauze, and place in a plastic container filled with ice
Wrap in saline-soaked-gauze, place in a waterproof plastic bag and place it on ice
Place directly in a plastic container, place container in saline at room temperature

questions.solution:
The correct way to transport an amputated part to the hospital is by wrapping it in a saline-soaked gauze, placing it in a clean container/ waterproof plastic bag, and then placing that on ice. 

The gauze is soaked to maintain moisture on the raw surface of the amputated part. It should never be placed directly on ice as it increases the risk of frostbite and can devitalize the tissue. Dry ice should be avoided. 

Proximal stump: Bleeding should be controlled in the proximal stump by as minimal a means as necessary.

The stump should be dressed with a nonadherent gauze and bulky dressing.

questions.text: A previously healthy patient is admitted to the ICU following a traumatic injury. Their blood glucose level is 200 mg/dL, and their HbA1c is 5.3%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
Stress hyperglycemia is a common complication of stress and hospital admission. It is caused by the release of stress hormones, such as cortisol and epinephrine, and pro-inflammatory cytokines which increase insulin resistance and glucose production. This can lead to transiently elevated blood glucose levels.

Risk factors are ICU admission, high fever, sepsis, CNS infections, and trauma.

Other options:

Option A: Undiagnosed diabetes is also a possibility, but the patient's HbA1c of 5.3% is not diagnostic of diabetes. Diabetes insipidus is a condition that causes excessive thirst and urination, but it does not typically cause hyperglycemia. Cushing syndrome is a condition that results from excess cortisol production, but it is also unlikely to be the cause of hyperglycemia in this patient, given their recent trauma.

Option C: Diabetes insipidus is a disorder that causes the kidneys to produce too much urine. This can lead to dehydration, which can in turn elevate blood glucose levels. However, diabetes insipidus is a rare condition, and it is unlikely to be the cause of the patient's elevated glucose level.

Option D: Cushing syndrome is a disorder that causes the body to produce too much cortisol. Cortisol is a stress hormone that can increase insulin resistance and elevate blood glucose levels. However, Cushing syndrome is also a rare condition, and it is unlikely to be the cause of the patient's elevated glucose level.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of severe joint pain on his big toe with multiple such episodes in the past. The X-ray shows the 'G' sign. Which of the following signs is also expected to be seen on ultrasound in this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of this patient shows Martel's sign/ G-sign which refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone. It is seen in chronic gout. Among the given options, the radiological sign that is seen in chronic gout is the double contour sign. 

Double contour sign is an ultrasound finding that is characterized by an echogenic line on the outer surface of the joint cartilage due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals on the surface of articular cartilage.

Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males and it usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. 

  • Acute gout presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint.

Chronic gout may present with chronic nonsymmetric synovitis, gouty arthritis, and periarticular tophaceous deposits.

Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features-

  • Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance
  • Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid.

Other options-

Option A: Linguine sign is seen in intracapsular rupture of silicone breast implant.

Option C: The Accordion sign is seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

Option D: Water lily sign is seen in hydatid cyst.

questions.text: In patients with whooping cough, during which stage of the illness is the patient most infectious?
questions.solution:
Patients with whooping cough, which is caused by Bordetella pertussis are most infectious during the catarrhal stage of infection.

Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis. It is also known as '100-day cough'. The incubation period of pertussis in humans is 7-14 days. After the incubation, the disease takes a protracted course comprising three stages, catarrhal phase, paroxysmal phase, and convalescent phase.

The catarrhal phase lasts 1-2 weeks and is characterized by coryza, lacrimation, mild cough, low-grade fever, and malaise. It is the most infectious stage, and smear and culture are likely to be positive.

The paroxysmal phase lasts 2-4 weeks with the cough becoming more frequent and spasmodic with repetitive bursts of 5–10 coughs, often within a single expiration. Post-tussive vomiting is frequent. The episode may be terminated by an audible whoop, which occurs upon rapid inspiration against a closed glottis at the end of a paroxysm. Patients are less infectious, and smear and culture may become negative.

The convalescent phase lasts 1–3 months and is characterized by gradual resolution of coughing episodes.

For 6–12 months following the illness, intercurrent viral infections may be associated with a recrudescence of paroxysmal cough.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a doppler. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical arteries.

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but do not appear below it. This is associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). 

Pregnant women having intrauterine growth restriction with AEDF in the umbilical artery are managed expectantly until delivery at 34 weeks. 

Umbilical artery vessels usually have forward flow throughout the cardiac cycle.  As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the placental resistance indices, so the amount of the forward diastolic flow increases and the S/D ratio (systole to diastole ratio) decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Note: Reverse end-diastolic flow has seen an insignificant increase in resistance to blood flow within the placenta. They are managed expectantly until delivery at 32 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules helps in diapedesis through the endothelium during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium of the capillaries to reach the site of injury. This process is aided by platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1).

The process of acute inflammation has 3 components: An increase in blood flow due to small vessel dilation, and increased permeability of the microvasculature to aid plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave the circulation and migrate to the site of injury to exert their effects.

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

  • Lumen of the vessel to the endothelium:
    • Margination: Leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface because of stasis of blood flow.
    • Rolling: Leukocytes start rolling on the vessel wall because of signaling molecules from the endothelium.
    • Adhesion: Leukocytes are attached to the endothelium because of adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. 
  • Transmigration of the leukocytes across the vascular endothelium.
  • Migration towards a chemotactic stimulus in the extravascular tissues.

Selectins, integrins, and their ligands are the most important proteins involved in adhesion and migration. Selectins are of 3 types: L-selectin present on leukocytes, E-selectin present on endothelium, and P-selectins present in platelets and on the endothelium. 

The weak rolling action slows down the leukocytes and allows them to bind more firmly to the endothelium with the help of integrins. Chemokines that are produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them. This in turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state.

This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.

Diapedesis occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31.

questions.text: What attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure?
questions.solution:
The sequence CCA attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure.

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • TΨC loop
  • Variable loop

 

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Thus, a specific tRNA exists for each of the 20 amino acids that are commonly present in proteins. This tRNA acts as a mediator between the cytosolic amino acids and the mRNA strand undergoing translation.

Other options-

Option (A): The guanyl cap is not a part of tRNA. it is a molecule of 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate at the 5' end of mRNA. 

Option (B): The anticodon is present at the anticodon loop as shown in the above image. The anticodon is complementary to the codon present on the mRNA strand.

Option (D): The codon refers to sequences of base triplets on the mRNA strand. These codons base pair with the corresponding anticodons on the anticodon arm of the tRNA. This allows the correct amino acid at the 3' end of the tRNA structure to get added to the elongating polypeptide chain.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a 5-year history of rheumatoid arthritis. She reports fatigue, easy bruising, and recurrent oral ulcers. Examination reveals splenomegaly and bilateral lower extremity edema. Laboratory investigations show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and a positive ANA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Felty syndrome is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis characterized by splenomegaly, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. The clinical presentation and laboratory findings in this case are most consistent with Felty syndrome. It occurs in the late stages of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia is known as Felty's syndrome. Some patients with Felty's syndrome can have large granular lymphocytic leukemia as an underlying cause.

Other options:

Option A: Caplan’s syndrome- characterized by both rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis. It is associated with development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules in the lungs. While the patient may have pulmonary symptoms, the presence of splenomegaly, cytopenia makes this option less likely.

Option C: Secondary Sjogren’s syndrome- development of keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia in association with connective tissue disorder.

Option D: Behcet syndrome: Characterized by recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, skin lesions, and other systemic manifestations. While the patient has oral ulcers, the absence of other characteristic features and the presence of splenomegaly and cytopenia make this option less likely.

questions.text: Identify the following graphical representation.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a Bar Chart because the rectangles are separated by spaces indicating that the data forms discrete categories.

But, in histogram the rectangles are not separated by spaces representing data that forms continuous categories instead of discrete groups

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: The mental ability of a person to make a valid will is known as _______________.
questions.solution:
The mental ability of a person to make a will is called testamentary capacity (testament = will).

A valid will is a written, duly signed, and witnessed document. At the time of making the will, the testator must be major and of sound disposing mind such that he can dispose of his property with understanding and reason.

A person affected by delusions can make a will if the delusion is not related in any way to the disposal of property or the persons affected. During the period of lucid interval, a mentally ill person can make a valid will.

The testator appoints an executor to carry out the terms of his will after his death.

Other options:

Option A: Mens rea (guilty mind) in criminal law refers to the state of mind of a defendant who is accused of committing a crime. Actus reus refers to the actual physical act causing death.

Option B: Corpus delicti, also known as the body of offence, says that a crime must be proved to have occurred before a person can be convicted of committing that crime.

Option D: Compos mentis- Before documenting a dying declaration, the doctor has to ascertain that the person is conscious and of sound mind with normal mental faculties (compos mentis).

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presents with step-ladder fever and loose stools. On examination, rose spots and splenomegaly are noted. Which of the following antigens are associated with the flagellae of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
A patient with step-ladder fever and loose stools associated with rose spots and splenomegaly is likely to be suffering from typhoid fever, which is caused by the organism Salmonella typhi. The H antigen is associated with the flagellae of the organism.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. It is characterized by gradual onset headache, malaise, step ladder pyrexia and gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal pain with either constipation or diarrhoea. They also present with rose spots on the skin during the 2nd to 3rd week, that fade on applying pressure. 

The following image depicts rose spots in enteric fever.

Salmonellae possess three important antigens on their cell wall :

  1. Somatic antigen (O): part of cell wall lipopolysaccharide. Serogrouping of salmonellae is based on the O antigen (Option B).
  2. Flagellar antigen (H): Made up of protein flagellin. Confers motility. Serogroups are differentiated into serotypes based on H antigen.
  3. Surface envelope antigen (Vi): It is part of surface polysaccharide envelope or capsular antigen covering the O antigen. Found in only few species and can be used for vaccination (Option A). 

Widal Test is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's sera. The antigens used in Widal's test include:

  • O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
  • H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Other options:

Option D: Capsular or K antigen is the polysaccharide capsular surface antigen present on the envelope of Escherichia coli.

questions.text: The postmortem finding seen in smothering is

choices.text: Abrasion on the inner side of the mouth

questions.solution:
Abrasion on the inner side of mouth is found in smothering.

Smothering is a form of asphyxia which occurs due to closure of external respiratory orifices by means of hands or by blocking of nose or mouth using foreign substances like mud, cloth etc.

Accidental smothering is the most common type.

Postmortem findings in case of smothering:

  • Since there is slow asphyxia, asphyxial signs will be severe.
  • Victim’s face might show lacerations, nail marks and scratches.
  • Bruising and laceration of lips, gums and tongue and oozing of blood from mouth and nose will be seen.
  • Protruded tongue
  • Asphyxial signs are absent in case of sudden death due to reflex cardiac arrest and in case of plastic bag suffocation.

questions.text: Syringoma is a benign tumor of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Syringoma is a benign tumor of the sweat ducts. 

It mostly appears during adolescence, usually in females. It consists of small dermal papules, that may be yellow in color or transluscent and cystic. They have a variable size ranging from 1-5mm. They may resemble milia. 

Syringomas usually are distributed bilaterally and symmetrically. They generally affect the front of the chest, face, and neck. 

The lesions are benign and are only treated for cosmetic reasons. Diathermy and carbon dioxide laser may be performed. However, diathermy has better cosmetic results while those treated with carbon dioxide laser recur. 

Syringoma is also known as

  • Hidradenomes eruptifs
  • Syringocystadenoma
  • Syringocystoma

Option A - Sebaceous adenomas are benign tumors of the sebaceous glands. They appear as yellow, smooth, circumscribed papules or nodules. They may be present on the face, scalp, and neck. 

Option C - Melanocytic nevi are benign tumors of melanocytes. They can be congenital or acquired. They have a varied presentation from even pigmentation to an array of colors. They should be differentiated from melanomas. 

Option D - Lipomas are benign tumors of adipocytes. They are slow-growing, rubbery nodules with a firm consistency. They usually occur on the trunk, shoulders, neck, and axillae.

questions.text: On reading the CTG below, you would conclude that it shows:
questions.solution:
Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline and it lasts > 2 min but < 10 min.

In the tracing below, you can see around 30 small boxes from the beginning of the deceleration which equates to 30x 10 = 300s ie 5 min. 

Bradycardia is a decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline lasting > 10 min.

Types of decelerations:

  • Early decelerations (Type I Dips): Onset, nadir, and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively. It suggests fetal head compression resulting in vagal nerve activation.
  • Late decelerations (Type II Dips): These begin after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak, and end of the uterine contraction respectively. The peak occurs 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction and FHR returns to normal after the contraction is over.
    It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

 

  • Variable deceleration: It is associated with umbilical cord compression and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. It has an acceleration at the beginning and also at the end of the deceleration. These accelerations are described as the shoulders of the deceleration. It is the most common type of deceleration. 
  • Sinusoidal pattern: It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting > 20 min, thus resembling a sine wave. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal hypoxia (acidosis). It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A woman presents with fever, cough, and chest pain. Chest X-ray reveals right lower lobe consolidation. Sputum Gram stain shows Gram-positive diplococci. Which of the following findings will point to Streptococcus pneumoniae, when cultured on blood agar?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pneumoniae produce draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies when cultured on blood agar.

Streptococcus pneumoniae, is the leading cause of lobar pneumonia. They are capsulated, lanceolate shaped Gram-positive diplococci. They are identified by being bile soluble and optochin sensitive. 

On blood agar, they produce draughtsman or carrom coin shaped α-hemolytic colonies. Colonies undergo autolysis due to the production of autolysin, an enzyme that cleaves peptidoglycan in the cell wall. Therefore, the colonies which have undergone autolysis have a central depression with an elevated rim, producing the characteristic draughtsman or carrom coin-shaped appearance. 

Other options:

Option A: Corroded or pitting colonies on blood agar are characteristic of Eikenella corrodens, belonging to the HACEK group of organisms.

Option C: Pinpoint colonies on blood agar are produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. The pinpoint colonies are surrounded by a wide zone of β-hemolysis.

Option D: Mercury drop appearance of colonies are produced by Bordetella pertussis when cultured on Regan-Lowe agar.

questions.text:
What is the cause of hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome?

A) Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion
B) Decrease in hepatic production of fibrinogen
C) Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S
questions.solution:
Hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome is due to the following factors:

  • Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Increase (not decrease) in hepatic production of fibrinogen.
  • Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S.
  • Increased platelet number and aggregability.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes to the primary health centre with multiple cuts and abrasions on his feet. He reports having reduced sensation in his feet. After addressing the wound, he is referred to another centre to receive microcellular rubber footwear. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this scenario?

This is a tertiary level of prevention
The district hospital will supply the microcellular footwear

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding this scenario is that the district hospital will supply the microcellular (MCR) footwear. The district nucleus supplies the MCR footwear, not the district hospital. 

In the given scenario, the patient has developed multiple abrasions and cuts secondary to insensitive feet suggestive of neuropathy. To reduce further complications this patient is referred to the district nucleus to receive the MCR footwear. This is a form of tertiary prevention since it reduces the number and impact of complications.

questions.text: A 4-day-old neonate is being evaluated in the nursery for a bluish discoloration of the skin. This child was born to a mother who is 41 years old and has a long-standing history of diabetes mellitus. On examination, the child is cyanotic at rest and there is no change with crying or feeding. Cyanosis does not improve with supplemental oxygen. Pulse rate is 120/min and respiratory rate is 70/min. There is a pansystolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border on auscultation. Chest X-ray findings are significant for an egg-on-side appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: PGE2 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus open
PGE1 infusion to keep the VSD open
PGE2 infusion to keep the VSD open
PGE1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriousus open

questions.solution:
The classic "Egg on side appearance " appearance on this chest X-ray image is seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). Prostaglandin E1 is administered for initial stabilization.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Clinical features:

  • Most infants present with cyanosis that is not affected by exertion or supplemental oxygen
  • Tachypnea with a respiratory rate > 60 breaths/min
  • Murmurs depending on the presence of a VSD or a left-ventricular outflow tract obstruction
  • Some patients with coarctation of the aorta may have diminished pulses in the lower extremities

Imaging:

  • ECG may demonstrate right axis deviation
  • Chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow superior mediastinum (the classic “egg on a string heart”), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart is because of the malposition of the great vessels
  • Echocardiography with Doppler will show a great artery branching into the left and right pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle. The aorta arises anteriorly from the right ventricle

Treatment:

Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulation

Congenital heart disease and time of presentation of cyanosis:

  • At birth - TGA, Tricuspid atresia, pulmonary atresia, truncus arteriosus, Obstructed TAPVR

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A woman with a history of anorexia nervosa is admitted for severe malnutrition and started on enteral nutrition. She develops hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hyperglycemia, accompanied by congestive heart failure. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
The electrolyte abnormalities, CHF in the context of anorexia are suspicious for refeeding syndrome: a metabolic complication that can occur in patients who are severely malnourished and are rapidly reintroduced to nutrition. This occurs due to increased insulin secretion from acute carbohydrate introduction.

This is due to a shift from catabolism to anabolism, which leads to a number of metabolic changes. One of these changes is increased insulin secretion. This increase in insulin promotes glycogenesis, protein synthesis and also activates the sodium-potassium ATPase symporter, leading to movement of potassium into the cells Magnesium and phosphate are also taken up similarly, which can lead to hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia. Additionally, insulin can inhibit the kidneys' ability to reabsorb phosphate, which can lead to hypophosphatemia - the hallmark of refeeding syndrome. Hyperglycemia is seen due to the acutely increased body insulin production not being able to keep up with the rapidly increasing blood sugar levels. 

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to: Starvation, Alcoholism, Delayed nutritional support, Anorexia nervosa, Massive weight loss in obese patients

These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Prevention of refeeding involves correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalance, administering thiamine and increasing calorie intake gradually.

Options A, B and C: The other answer choices are incorrect because they do not explain the metabolic changes that lead to refeeding syndrome. Decreased aldosterone secretion can lead to hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia. While increased cortisol secretion can potentiate the hyperglycemia in refeeding syndrome, it does not affect the transport of phosphate in the cells nor does it impair magnesium metabolism. Decreased thyroid hormone secretion can lead to weight gain, not weight loss.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain, redness, and swelling at the base of the big toe. X-ray shows Martel's G sign. He was recently started on first-line anti-tubercular therapy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug most likely responsible for this presentation?

choices.text: Disruption of cell membrane transport function
Interference with initiation of protein synthesis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with pain, redness, and swelling at the base of the big toe is suggestive of an acute attack of gout. Pyrazinamide, which is a first-line anti-tubercular drug, can cause hyperuricemia, and lead to this presentation. The mechanism of action of the drug involves disruption of cell membrane transport function. 

Pyrazinamide is a bactericidal anti-tubercular drug that has a mechanism of action similar to isoniazid. It is converted into the active metabolite pyrazinoic acid, which makes the intracellular environment more acidic, and prevents mycolic acid synthesis. It also disrupts the transmembrane proton motive force, thereby killing the mycobacteria.

Adverse effects include hyperuricemia due to inhibition of uric acid secretion in renal tubules. This can precipitate an acute attack of gout. Hepatotoxicity is another important adverse effect. Other adverse effects include rashes, fever, and worsening glycemic control in diabetics. 


Other options:
Inhibition of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (Option A) is the mechanism of action of rifamycins. Side effects of these drugs include orange-colored body fluids and flu-like symptoms. 

Inhibition of arabinogalactan synthesis (Option B) is the mechanism of action of ethambutol. The most commonly observed adverse effect is optic neuritis causing red-green color blindness and decreased visual acuity. 

Interference with initiation of protein synthesis (Option D) is the mechanism of action of aminoglycoside antibiotics which are second-line anti-tubercular drugs. The most commonly observed adverse effects in this group include ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman was diagnosed with Burkitt lymphoma. Cytogenetic studies demonstrated a t (8;14) chromosomal translocation. Which of the following best explains the role of this translocation in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The activation of the proto-oncogene MYC due to translocation is mainly responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

In Burkitt lymphoma, the MYC gene is translocated from its normal locus 8q24 to chromosome 14q32. The MYC gene at its normal locus is controlled and expressed in actively dividing cells. When the MYC gene is moved to 14q32, it is usually placed close to the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) gene. This movement is associated with the loss of regulatory sequences of the MYC gene, which are replaced by the control regions of the IGH gene, which is highly expressed in the B cells. The translocation is denoted as t (8;14) (q24; q32).

As a result, the MYC coding sequence is intact with the loss of regulatory control. The activation of the proto-oncogene leads to overexpression of the MYC protein, which is responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of intermittent claudication in his lower limbs while walking. He is prescribed a drug that prevents platelet aggregation by acting as a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor. Identify the drug that he was likely to be prescribed.
questions.solution:
The drug that this patient presenting with intermittent claudication in his lower limbs while walking was likely to be prescribed is cilostazol. It is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor that prevents platelet aggregation.

Phosphodiesterase (PDE) inhibitors inhibit the enzyme PDE which catalyzes the hydrolysis of cyclic nucleotides cAMP and cGMP. These drugs therefore increase cAMP and/or cGMP to produce various clinical effects depending on their specificity for varying PDE isoforms. 

Cilostazol is a PDE-3 inhibitor. It increases intracellular cAMP in platelets and vascular smooth muscle to prevent platelet aggregation and produce vasodilation. It is used in the management of peripheral vascular disease. It is indicated for use in patients presenting with intermittent claudication with no history of rest pain or heart failure. It has produced better results than pentoxiphylline in increasing the walking distance in such patients. 

Adverse effects of cilostazol include headache, palpitations, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and an increase in ventricular ectopics. 

Other options:
Milrinone (Option A) is also a selective PDE-3 inhibitor. It is used as a short-term therapy in severe or refractory congestive heart failure as it increases intracellular cAMP in cardiomyocytes to increase ionotropy and chronotropy.

Pentoxiphylline (Option C) is a rheological agent and a weak phosphodiesterase inhibitor. It is used in the management of peripheral vascular disease and increases blood flow in ischaemic areas. 

Clopidogrel (Option D) is a antiplatelet drug that acts as an irreversible P2Y12 antagonist. It is also indicated for the management of peripheral vascular disease.  It is primarily used in the initial management of acute coronary syndrome and the secondary prevention of myocardial infarction, and stroke.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with complaints of dizziness and palpitation. ECG reveals regular narrow-complex tachycardia. He is administered an intravenous drug and develops flushing, chest pain, and shortness of breath shortly after. What was the likely drug that was administered?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with dizziness, palpitation, and ECG revealing regular narrow-complex tachycardia is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The drug of choice to terminate an attack of PSVT is intravenous adenosine. The most common adverse effect of the drug seen in nearly half the patients is transient cutaneous flushing, chest pain, and shortness of breath.

PSVT is a regular, narrow QRS complex tachycardia, most often caused due to an atrioventricular nodal re-entrant circuit. Patients may present with sudden onset palpitations, dizziness, and diaphoresis. 

Management involves slowing AV node conduction and vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva maneuver, splashing cold water on the face) are the first step. If this does not work, intravenous (IV) adenosine is the drug of choice used to terminate the majority of PSVT episodes.

Adenosine is a very short-acting endogenous purine signal molecule. It is administered as a 6 mg IV bolus over 2-3 seconds followed by a rapid flush with 20 mL NS. It can be followed up with a 12 mg IV bolus dose if required. It causes membrane hyperpolarization of cardiac muscle cells to terminate the re-entrant circuit through the AV node.

Since the action of the drug lasts for less than a minute, adverse effects are short-lived. These include transient shortness of breath, chest pain, hypotension, and cutaneous flushing due to vasodilation. It can however precipitate bronchospasm in asthmatics and verapamil is preferred in such patients. 

Other option:
Sotalol (Option A) is a class III antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of some ventricular tachycardias and for maintaining sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation. It is administered orally. Adverse effects include precipitation of torsades de pointes in patients with long Q-T interval. 

Lidocaine (Option C) is a class IB antiarrhythmic used in the management of arrhythmias following acute myocardial infarction. It is administered slow IV and adverse effects are mainly neurological and include drowsiness, paresthesias, disorientation, nystagmus, and seizures. 

Amiodarone (Option D) is a class III antiarrhythmic used in the management of ventricular and supraventricular arrhythmias. It causes rapid termination of such arrhythmias when administered IV. Adverse effects include pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, thyroid disorders, photodermatitis, and corneal deposits.

questions.text: A preterm neonate in neonatal intensive care is found to have transient eye deviations, nystagmus, and abnormal extremity movements. What is the most likely type of seizure in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a preterm neonate having transient eye deviations, nystagmus, and abnormal extremity movements is suggestive of subtle seizure. They are the most frequently occurring neonatal seizures and are more common in premature than in full-term infants.

Seizures are the most important indicator of significant neurologic dysfunction in the neonatal period. The immature brain is more excitable and thus more likely to develop seizures if specific underlying causes are present.

Subtle seizures are characterized by transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (like rowing, swimming, bicycling, and stepping), fluctuations in heart rate, episodes of hypertension, and apnea. They are frequently not associated with electrographic discharges and are thus thought to be secondary to brain injury rather than true epileptic seizures. 

The most common underlying cause of neonatal seizures is hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). Vascular events such as intracranial bleeds are another important cause. Germinal matrix–intraventricular hemorrhage can occur in preterm infants. Other causes of seizures include hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, electrolyte abnormalities, intracranial infections, developmental anomalies, and inborn errors of metabolism.

Other options:
Clonic seizure (Option B) is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk. These are epileptic seizures and may be unifocal or multifocal. Generalized clonic seizures are uncommon in the neonatal period.

Tonic seizure (Option C) is characterized by persistent posturing of a limb or posturing of the trunk or neck in an asymmetric way, often with persistent horizontal eye deviation. They can be focal or generalized and are also epileptic seizures.

Myoclonic seizure (Option D) is characterized by rapid jerking movements and lack of rhythmicity. Focal myoclonic seizures usually affect the flexor muscles of the upper extremities. Multifocal myoclonic seizures involve asymmetrical jerking of several parts of the body. These seizures can be either epileptic or non-epileptic.

questions.text: Which of the following increases the diagnostic capability of the investigation shown below?
questions.solution:
The investigation shown above is a magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP). Secretin helps in increasing the diagnostic capability of MRCP.

MRCP is a non-invasive test used to visualise the intra and extrahepatic biliary tree and pancreatic ductal system. By acquiring images using heavily T2-weighted sequences, this technique uses the fluid present in the biliary and pancreatic ducts as an intrinsic contrast medium.

Secretin-enhanced MRCP (S-MRCP) improves diagnostic yield and clinical utility over standard MRCP by improving visualization of ductal anatomy and providing insight into pancreatic function.

Secretin is a hormone that promotes the exocrine pancreatic secretion of bicarbonate-rich fluid from pancreatic acinar cells into the pancreatic ductal lumen.

Exogenous secretin administration results in the temporary dilation of the pancreatic ducts allowing better visualisation. The peak effect of intravenous secretin administration is usually seen 3-5 minutes after injection. At this point, the main pancreatic duct's calibre may rise by 1 mm or more in comparison to the baseline measurement, and the side branches may become visible and useful for diagnosis.

S-MRCP is used in the diagnosis of pancreas divisum, anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction, chronic pancreatitis and main pancreatic duct stenosis.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the effect of arginine deprivation in a patient with prostate cancer as he believes in the importance of leucine zipper proteins in the development of the same. Tumour cells are cultured on media containing both low and high concentrations of arginine. An oligonucleotide probe is used to identify the transcription factor. Which laboratory technique did the biochemist employ?
questions.solution:
The Southwestern blot using tagged double-stranded DNA probes, identifies DNA-binding proteins (for example, c-Jun and c-Fos [leucine zipper motif]).

The Southwestern blot and overlay blot are variations of the Southern, Northern, and Western blotting techniques. The Southwestern blot is used to study protein-nucleic acid interactions, while the overlay blot is used to study protein-protein interactions. In these two methods, proteins are isolated through electrophoresis, transferred to a membrane, restored to their original structure, and examined for their interaction with a specific DNA, RNA, or protein sequence. This is done by exposing them to a labelled nucleic acid probe or a protein probe.

Other options :

Option A: Northern blotting is used for the detection of RNA.

Option C: Western blotting is used for the detection of proteins.

Option D: Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA.

questions.text: A confused and agitated patient is brought to casualty with a perineal mass as shown in the image below. Thirty minutes back she delivered at home with the aid of her sister who applied fundal pressure and umbilical cord traction. Her clinical findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion, as observed by the tip of the uterine fundus marked in the image below.

Fundal pressure while the uterus is atonic (soft, relaxed, and boggy) causes uterine inversion. It results in hemorrhage followed by complete uterine inversion protruding out of the vulva. A neurogenic type of shock develops due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament and the ovaries.

Uterine inversion is an extremely rare but life-threatening complication in the 3rd stage of labor, in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely.

Causes:

  • The most common cause is mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor
  • Spontaneous
  • Placenta accreta (rarely)

Features:

  • Shock immediately after delivery
  • The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding
  • Shock is either neurogenic or hemorrhagic
  • Per abdomen examination - the fundus of the uterus is not palpable. 

Management of uterine inversion:

Vaginal operations Abdominal operations Hydrostatic method
Kustner Huntington's O Sullivan
Spinelli Haultain Oguchi

Other options:

Option A: Uterine myoma is unlikely in this patient as there are no observed masses distinct from the uterus. A picture showing a uterine fibroid is as follows.

Option B: Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Rectal prolapse is of two types namely partial rectal prolapse and complete rectal prolapse. 

Option D: Cystocele is the prolapse of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It appears as a reducible swelling with ill-defined margins, rugosities, and a cough impulse. It is often associated with urinary symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath and hematuria. Her blood pressure is 190/120 mmHg, and her urine dipstick is positive for protein. Which medication is the first line for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors are the cornerstone of treatment for scleroderma renal crisis.

Scleroderma renal crisis is a life-threatening complication of scleroderma characterized by rapidly deteriorating renal function, hypertension, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. They work by blocking the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of the disease. ACE inhibitors reduce blood pressure, improve renal function, and significantly reduce mortality in patients with scleroderma renal crisis.

Captopril is commonly used due to its short-acting nature and ability to rapidly lower blood pressure. Close blood pressure monitoring is crucial during treatment with ACE inhibitors to avoid excessive hypotension.

The pathogenesis of scleroderma renal crisis involves a complex interplay of factors leading to accelerated hypertension and kidney damage.

  1. Obliterative vasculopathy and luminal narrowing 
  2. Intravascular hemolysis: Due to the narrowed blood vessels
  3. Complement activation: The complement system, a part of the immune system, becomes activated in scleroderma renal crisis. This can further damage blood vessels and contribute to inflammation.
  4. Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) activation: In response to reduced blood flow to the kidneys, the juxtaglomerular cells release renin, an enzyme that triggers the RAAS. The RAAS leads to increased production of Angiotensin II, a powerful hormone that causes blood vessels to constrict.
  5. Accelerated hypertension: the cumulative effects of these factors lead to a rapid and severe increase in blood pressure, known as accelerated hypertension. This is the hallmark feature of scleroderma renal crisis and requires immediate medical attention.


Explanation of other options:

Option A. Beta-blocker: While beta-blockers can be used to treat hypertension, they are not the first-line therapy for scleroderma renal crisis. They may even be harmful in this setting by reducing renal perfusion.

Option B. Similar to beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers can be used for hypertension management. However, they are not as effective as ACE inhibitors in scleroderma renal crisis and do not adequately address the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms.

Option D: Diuretics can be used to manage fluid overload in scleroderma renal crisis. However, they are not the primary treatment and should be used in conjunction with ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A child is brought with malodorous scalp lesions as shown below. Wood's lamp examination of hair follicles reveals blue-grey fluorescence. What is the causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cup‐shaped scutula (crusts) around hair follicles, which is suggestive of favus. It is a manifestation of tinea capitis, an inflammatory infection of the hair follicle caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Favus is a chronic fungal infection in which dense yellow crusts (scutula) develop in the hair follicles with a distinct malodorous smell, leading to scarring alopecia. T. schoenleinii is the most common cause. T. violaceum and Microsporum gypseum are rare causes but have been reported. 

T. schoenleinii demonstrates blue-gray fluorescence on Wood lamp examination. Microscopy with KOH preparation reveals hyphae arranged lengthwise around and within the hair shaft. The hyphae do not produce spores.

Option C: T. violaceum is a rare cause of favus, although it does not display fluorescence under Wood's lamp.

Option D: T. verrucosum is a common cause of kerion, which is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation.

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Which of the following systems ensures that the pipelines shown below are inserted into their respective inlets?
questions.solution:
The Diameter Index safety system (DISS) ensures that the pipes shown below are inserted into their respective inlets.

DISS is a safety feature in the modern anaesthesia workstation. DISS connectors have unique diameters for each type of gas to prevent wrong pipeline attachment to the wrong inlet. After entering the machine, the gas passes through a filter followed by a pipeline check valve. With the help of this one-way valve, gas cannot flow backwards from the machine into the medical gas pipeline system or out of an open inlet into the atmosphere.

Other options:

Option A: Pin Index Safety System (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment. It is a unique configuration of holes and pins which match precisely to eliminate the connection of a wrong cylinder to equipment, thus preventing the delivery of the wrong gas to a patient.

Option B: Fail-safe system/ fail-safe valves are oxygen supply failure protection devices. Here oxygen failure influences the flow of other gases within the gas supply system. The oxygen supply failure protection device in the anaesthesia machine reacts to low oxygen pressure by either reducing (proportional valve) or shutting off (binary valve) the flow of other gases such as air or nitrous oxide.

Option C: Contamination of the anaesthetic environment by waste gases is prevented by the Scavenging system.

questions.text: What is the primary response of a bleeding vessel?
questions.solution:
The primary response of hemostasis is arteriolar vasoconstriction → platelet plug → tissue factor release → fibrin deposit.

Normal hemostasis:

  1. Arteriolar vasocontriction: After vascular injury, local neurohumoral factors induce a transient vasoconstriction.
  2. Primary hemostasis: Platelets bind via glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptors to von Willebrand factor (vWF) on exposed extracellular matrix (ECM) and are activated, undergoing a shape change and granule release. Released adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thromboxane A2 (TxA2) induce additional platelet aggregation through platelet GpIIb-IIIa receptor binding to fibrinogen, and form the primary hemostatic plug.
  3. Secondary hemostasis: Local activation of the coagulation cascade (involving tissue factor and platelet phospholipids) results in fibrin polymerization, “cementing” the platelets into a definitive secondary hemostatic plug.
  4. Clot stabilization and resorption: Counter-regulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic process to the site of injury.

questions.text: A patient with Ca Pancreas underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy. 4 days after his surgery, he still has a persistent fluid leak at the drain site. Analysis of the fluid shows elevated amylase levels. What is the likely etiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with carcinoma pancreas has undergone a pancreaticoduodenectomy, also known as the Whipple's procedure. He now has a persistent leak in his drain with elevated amylase levels and the likely diagnosis is a pancreatic fistula formation. 
 
The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas.

The following structures are removed during the Whipple procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

Complications of the procedure: 

  • Delayed gastric emptying
  • Pancreatic fistula formation
  • Wound infection
  • Bile leak
  • Intrabdominal abscess formation

A pancreatic fistula is diagnosed when there is any amount of fluid draining from a drain after 3 days post surgery with amylase values 3 times the normal.

Most fistulas need no additional management but some rarely need a repeat surgery if the drainage is persistent. 

Hepatico-jejunal anastomotic leak would more likely present with bile in the drainage fluid, not elevated amylase.

Localised abscess formation and Intraabdominal abscess formation may occur postoperatively but would not typically cause elevated amylase levels in the absence of an associated pancreatic leak.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins constitutes a part of the acyl carrier protein?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that constitutes a part of the acyl carrier protein is pantothenic acid.

Fatty acids are synthesized by the fatty acid synthase enzyme complex. The individual enzymes required for fatty acid synthesis are linked in this multienzyme polypeptide complex that consists of an acyl carrier protein (ACP). ACP contains vitamin B5/pantothenic acid.

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol. It involves the formation of palmitate from acetyl-CoA. This process occurs in the liver, kidney, brain, lung, breast, and adipose tissue. Acetyl-CoA and CO2 act as the substrate and palmitate is the end product.

The image given below shows the steps involved in fatty acid synthesis.

Pantothenic acid/vitamin B5 constitutes a part of the coenzyme A, which functions in the transfer of acyl groups.

Pantothenic acid as coenzyme A is involved in:

  • Fatty acid oxidation
  • TCA cycle (succinyl CoA and acetyl CoA)
  • Cholesterol synthesis (HMG CoA)
  • Acetylation reactions

The intestinal gut flora synthesizes vitamin B5 and hence deficiency is rare. Gopalan's burning foot syndrome is a rare disorder that occurs due to deficiency in pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) and the clinical features include paresthesia (burning type of pain as the name suggests) in lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbance.

questions.text: Mcafee and Johnson's  management in case of placenta previa advocates termination of pregnancy at :

choices.text: Immediate termination irrespective of gestational age

questions.solution:
Mcafee and Johnson's expectant management in case of placenta previa advocates termination of pregnancy at 37 weeks.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites 

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health(Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk

         Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or

         Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses

  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic cough, fatigue, and weight loss. Imaging reveal bilateral upper-lobe cavitary lesions. Sputum culture confirms presence of Mycobacterium kansasii. What post exposure prophylaxis is indicated for the patient's close contacts?
questions.solution:
In this patient presenting with nontuberculous mycobacterial lung disease secondary to M. kansasii, no post exposure prophylaxis is indicated in close contacts as the organism does not transmit from person to person.

M. kansasii and Mycobacterium avium Complex are common causes of nontuberculous mycobacterial lung disease. M. kansasii produces lung disease clinically similar to tuberculosis. Extrapulmonary infections such as cervical lymphadenitis in children, skin and soft tissue infections, pericarditis and disseminated disease (in immunocompromised patients) have been reported. Infections are treated with the combination of rifampin, ethambutol, and isoniazid.

While tap water is believed to be the main source of M. kansasii for humans, there is no evidence that it can spread directly from person to person. Hence post exposure prophylaxis is not indicated.

M. kansasii is classified under group I (photochromogen) in the Runyon classification.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to ER with a history of trauma to the flanks whilst playing cricket. His pulse is 80 bpm and BP is 120/85 mmHg. A FAST scan is done, which reveals the presence of free fluid in the spleen window. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
CT scan is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically stable patient with minimal free fluid in the abdomen. It should be done to locate the source of bleeding and grading.

FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma.

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

Technique:

  • The patient is placed in a supine position
  • With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned :
    • Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of a cohort study?

choices.text: Natural history of disease can be studied

questions.solution:
Hawthorne effect is a disadvantage of cohort studies where people change or alter their behaviour during the course of the study, which affects the outcome and distorts the results.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the ER after a skateboarding accident during which he had fallen with head hitting the ground first. He has a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a tissue paper. The investigation of choice for localizing the site is:
questions.solution:
HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea. History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign on tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

Melorheostosis: It is also known as Leri's Disease. It is a rare mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosis of cortices with a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. The presentation is usually monostotic and unilateral. Symptoms include pain, deformity, skin and circulation problems and contractures.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign autosomal dominant sclerosing bone dysplasia with multiple bone islands in a peri-articular distribution in tubular bones, pelvis and scapulae. They are typically bilateral and symmetrical.

Osteopathia striata, is a rare, benign dysplasia of bone with radiographically prominent vertical striations involving the epiphysis and metaphysis of tubular bones. It is typically asymptomatic, although there can be associated joint discomfort.

questions.text: Given below is the histological structure of an endocrine gland. The blood supply to this gland arises from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the histology of the parathyroid gland. It is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery which is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk. 

It can be identified by the presence of acidophilic and principal cells. The principal cells have pale staining cytoplasm while the acidophilic cells are larger than principal cells and have acidophilic cytoplasm. The principal cells produce parathormone. The function of the oxyphil cells is unknown. 

Other options:

Option B- External carotid artery gives a branch called the superior thyroid artery which supplies thyroid gland. The thyroid gland can be identified by the presence of epithelium-lined thyroid follicles. The center of each follicle has a lightly staining colloid. 

Below image shows thyroid gland

 

Option C- The internal carotid artery supplies the pituitary gland via hypophyseal arteries. Section of the pituitary gland can be identified by the presence of pars distalis, pars tuberalis, and pars intermedia. Pars distalis contains chromophils having hormones stored in cytoplasmic granules. Pars tuberalis contains gonadotrophs and pars intermedia is a region between pars distalis and pars nervosa.

Below image shows pituitary gland

 

Option D- Superior mesenteric artery supplies pancreas. Pancreas can be identified by the presence of islets. The islet cells are polygonal or rounded, and more lightly stained than the surrounding acinar cells.
