questions.text: Gunstock deformity is an example of ?
questions.solution:
Gunstock deformity is an example of a cubitus varus deformity.

It occurs as a result of malunion of a supra-condylar fracture of the humerus. 

The terms valgus and varus are used to describe skeletal deformities with respect to the displacement of the structures distal to the affected joint.

In varus deformities, the part distal to the affected joint is displaced towards the midline. Therefore:

  • In cubitus varus, the elbow is involved and the forearm is displaced towards the midline, ie, the elbow appears distant from the trunk. (as shown in above image)
  • In genu varus, the knee is involved and the leg is displaced towards the midline, ie, the knees appear apart, and the heels are closer to each other.

In valgus deformities, the part distal to the affected joint is displaced away from the midline. Therefore:

  • In cubitus valgus, the elbow is involved and the forearm is displaced away from the midline, ie, the elbow appears closer to the trunk.
  • In genu valgus, the knee is involved and the leg is displaced away from the midline, ie, the knees are closer to each other and the heels are apart.

Remember: vaLgus is Lateral displacement of the part distal to the joint.

questions.text: False about a standard normal distribution curve is
questions.solution:
In a normal distribution curve, variance is 1.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a young African patient shows a 'starry-sky' appearance. Which of the following represents the 'sky'?
questions.solution:
In Burkitt's lymphoma, microscopy of a lymph node sample reveals a characteristic starry sky appearance. The homogenous tumor cells represent the sky whereas the reactive macrophages represent the stars.

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation of the c-Myc gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14).

It can occur in 3 forms which have distinct clinical characteristics:

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. It can also spread to bone marrow and meninges.
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it has an abdominal presentation with massive disease, ascites, and renal, testis, and/or ovarian involvement. It can also spread to CNS and meninges.
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukemia is seen in immunocompromised individuals

Histopathology: Tumor cells show round or oval nuclei, coarse chromatin, small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky). The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. These phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic 'starry sky' pattern. 

Burkitt lymphoma is very aggressive but responds well to intensive chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Burkitt's Lymphoma

Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children < 15 years.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty with severe epigastric pain. He is diagnosed with acute pancreatitis and a nasogastric tube is placed. Which of the following is the correct way to start enteral nutrition for him again?

choices.text: Start feeding within 24 hours and slowly increase
Wait for abdominal pain symptoms to subside and then start enteral feeding
Start total parenteral nutrition first and then enteral after 1 week
Start oral feeding after the nasogastric tube is removed

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of acute pancreatitis. Current evidence confirms that the administration of enteral nutrition is beneficial for the treatment of severe acute pancreatitis. Enteral feeding reduces mortality, infectious complications, and multiorgan failure. In terms of the timing of enteral nutritional support, relatively early administration within 24 hours of hospital admission is suggested. It should slowly be increased over 2-3 days. 

According to the revised Atlanta classification, acute pancreatitis is clinically defined by at least the first two of three features:

  1. Abdominal pain suggestive of pancreatitis (epigastric pain often radiating to the back),
  2. Serum amylase and lipase levels ≥ 3 times normal (imaging is to be used if the elevated values are less than 3 times normal); and
  3. Characteristic imaging findings on CT, magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, or transabdominal ultrasonographic (US) studies.   

 If acute pancreatitis is diagnosed based on the first two criteria with no systemic sign of severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome or persistent organ failure, contrast material–enhanced CT may not be necessary for determining patient care.

The optimal time for the performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute pancreatitis is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis are

  • Diagnostic uncertainty
  • In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis
  • In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration
  • When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or a pseudoaneurysm

While both enteral and parenteral nutrition have similar mortality rates, parenteral nutrition is associated with mucosal atrophy and predisposes the patient to small intestinal bacterial overgrowth and increased incidences of pancreatic surgery. Hence, whenever possible, patients should be started on enteral nutrition as much as they can tolerate it and slowly the quantity should be increased. Parenteral nutrition is used in cases of severe intractable pain or when the patients have been intubated.

questions.text: An elderly patient is found to have the following lesion on an eye examination. What is the underlying cause of this condition?

choices.text: Accumulation of epithelial cells in Henle glands
Elastotic degeneration of the submucous tissue

questions.solution:
The given clinical image shows a pinguecula. The underlying cause of this condition is elastotic degeneration of the submucous tissue in the conjunctiva.

Pinguecula is a degenerative condition of the conjunctiva, characterized by the formation of a yellowish-white patch on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually presents as a triangular patch on the nasal side, with the triangle's apex commonly pointed away from the cornea. The underlying etiology, as described, is hyaline infiltration and elastotic degeneration of the submucous tissue.

Pinguecula is usually found in the elderly during routine eye examinations and generally produces no symptoms. Exposure to sunlight, dust, and wind are possible risk factors. 

The condition is non-progressive, and treatment is usually not required. In rare cases, it may present with inflammation or congestion. Such cases are managed symptomatically with topical steroids. 

 

Other options:
Accumulation of epithelial cells in Henle glands (Option A), along with inspissated mucus, is the underlying etiology of conjunctival concretions. They present with foreign body sensation and minute, hard, yellow spots in the palpebral conjunctiva. They are commonly seen in the elderly and associated with trachoma.

Proliferation of avascularized granulation tissue (Option C) is the underlying cause of pterygium. It is another degenerative condition of the subconjunctival tissue, which destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane. The lesion appears as a thick vascularized conjunctiva growing onto the cornea from the canthus. It can follow a pinguecula, is progressive, and results in astigmatism as it progresses into the pupillary area of the cornea.

Inflammatory overgrowth produced by trauma (Option D) is the underlying cause of pseudopterygium. This is a cicatrizing lesion produced as a result of trauma, thermochemical burn, or chronic conjunctivitis. Distinguishing features include location at any quadrant of the corneal limbus. Unlike a pterygium, this condition is non-progressive.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child with a cough and cold for the last 7 days is taken to an ANM worker by his mother. On examination, the child had a respiratory rate of 58 breaths/min and chest indrawing. In accordance with SAANS guidelines, what should be done by the ANM?

choices.text: ANM gives the first dose of oral Amoxicillin, IM Gentamicin and refer
ANM  refers the child to the nearby PHC
ANM herself advices for home-based care
ANM gives oral Amoxicillin for five days and advices rest

questions.solution:
The ANM worker is to provide oral Amoxicillin, IM Gentamicin and refer the patient to a higher centre.

The 6-month-old child with a cough and cold for 7 days, having a respiratory rate of 58 breaths/min and chest indrawings is classified as "Severe pneumonia" in accordance with the SAANS guidelines. According to the latest SAANS guidelines (Social Awareness and Actions to Neutralize Pneumonia Successfully), a child with Severe Pneumonia needs to provide oral Amoxicillin, and IM Gentamicin and refer the patient to a higher centre.

 

For classifying Pneumonia, SAANS guidelines of India are similar to the IMNCI protocols of WHO, except it allows ASHA to take the decision for advising Home based treatment as she has been trained for classifying Pneumonia. Also in the SAANS guidelines, chest indrawing is a feature of severe pneumonia, while it comes under pneumonia in the IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A traveler presents to your OPD with profuse watery diarrhea. You suspect it to be a case of cholera due to the recent outbreak in his hometown. You would recommend isolation of the patient until:

choices.text: A negative stool antigen test is obtained

questions.solution:
The duration of isolation recommended for a patient with cholera is until 3 days of antibiotic therapy.

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice-water stools) associated with effortless vomiting.

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea. 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludens toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells. The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Antibiotics that can be used include fluoroquinolones, tetracycline, Azithromycin, ampicillin, or Trimethoprim -Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).

questions.text: A study on mood stabilizers shows that a new drug X works faster to stabilize mood than the standard drug Y. The results are statistically significant. The study is carried out 100 different times and shows such significant differences 95 times. Which of the following accurately characterizes the probability of not detecting a correlation between X and Y in this study?
questions.solution:
The likelihood of not detecting a correlation between X and Y is nothing but a type II error or a beta error which is 5%.

A type II error is the probability of rejecting the alternate hypothesis when it is true. It is also known as a beta error.

In this case, it is the chance of saying the experimental drug does not work better than the standard drug, while it does. This happened in 5/100 studies, hence the likelihood of a type II error (beta) is 5%.

Note: Power = 1- beta. Here, the power of the study is 95%.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. Patient was advised to perform Kegel's exercises. Which muscle in this patient is most likely to stay unaffected by exercises?
questions.solution:
Kegel's exercises would be most useful in preventing future pelvic organ prolapse by strengthening voluntary muscles or muscles of levator ani ie pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, puborectalis, ischiocavernosus, etc. Since the internal anal sphincter is under autonomic control it cannot be strengthened by performing Kegel's exercises.

Kegel pelvic floor exercises involve intermittent tightening of the perineal muscles which leads to strengthening of the pelvic floor muscles especially the pelvic diaphragm (Level III), and decreases the urethral mobility. It is strongly advised for 4-6 months in the puerperal period following vaginal delivery to strengthen the tone of the pelvic diaphragm muscles.

Kegel's exercises or pelvic floor muscle training (PMFT) is useful in the following situations:

  • Before and after delivery to reduce the risk of pelvic organ prolapse and postpartum urinary incontinence.
  • To limit the progression and alleviate symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse.
  • As first-line therapy in patients with stress urinary incontinence and urge urinary incontinence.

questions.text: An open splenectomy is planned for a patient. The procedure involves ligating and dividing the short gastric vessels. Which of the following structures contains these vessels?
questions.solution:
The gastrosplenic ligament contains the short gastric vessels which are ligated in an open splenectomy.

The gastrosplenic ligament runs from the hilum of the spleen to the greater curvature of the stomach. In an open splenectomy, the gastrosplenic ligament is opened and short gastric vessels are ligated and divided.

questions.text: As a first-year psychiatry resident, you get a call from the casualty to see a 25-year-old man with suspected psychotic symptoms. On probing, the patient reveals that he is scared that people are plotting to destroy his life, and he feels that bugs are crawling on his skin. Which of the following drugs would you suspect this patient to be abusing?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is the most likely agent responsible for drug abuse in this case.

Bugs crawling over the skin i.e., tactile hallucination (formication/ cocaine bugs/ Magnan's sign), a delusion of persecution, paranoia, and suspiciousness, which resemble acute schizophrenia, are common in cocaine intoxication. Increased energy, alertness, sociability, elation, euphoria, decreased need for sleep and appetite are also features of cocaine intoxication.

Chronic methamphetamine use can lead to meth mouth, which typically involves severe tooth decay, dry mouth, cracked teeth, and gum disease. 

Note: Magnan's sign can also be seen with amphetamine use.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the presence of minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of volatile anaesthetic agents in the following age groups?
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) for volatile anaesthetic agents is greater in infants than in neonates and adults. The order of sequence is infants > neonates > adults.

The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anaesthetic is the lowest concentration required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. It is a measure of the potency of inhalational anaesthetics. So, the lower the MAC value, the lower the concentration of anaesthetic drug required, implying the drug is more potent.

MAC is the highest in infants at 6 months of age, after which it declines. After the age of 40, MAC reduces by ~6% per decade.

MAC progressively decreases during pregnancy by as much as 40% and returns to normal by the third day after delivery.

questions.text: Gall bladder develops from _____.
questions.solution:
Gall bladder develops from pars cystica.

Development of extrahepatic biliary apparatus: 

The hepatic bud divides into pars hepatica and pars cystica:

  • Pars hepatica further divides into the right and left branches, which give rise to the right and left hepatic ducts
  • Pars cystica gives rise to the gallbladder and cystic duct

Common bile duct develops from the narrow part of the hepatic bud between pars cystica and the duodenal part of the foregut. 

Other options:

Option A: Septum transversum- The structures derived from this septum include the fibrous capsule of Glisson, sinusoids, and Kupffer cells of the liver. It also gives rise to the central tendon of the diaphragm and ventral mesentery, which further gives rise to the lesser omentum and falciform ligament.

Option C: The common hepatic duct develops from the undivided part of pars hepatica, distal to the origin of pars cystica.

Option D: Dorsal mesogastrium gives rise to the greater omentum.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman who presented with vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and several episodes of vomiting was diagnosed with complete molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the following finding is seen in her left ovary. How would you proceed with the management of this patient?

choices.text: U/L oophorectomy with dilation and curettage

questions.solution:
This patient with a diagnosis of complete molar pregnancy and transvaginal ultrasonography showing the presence of multiple theca lutein cysts in the left ovary can be managed with just suction and curettage. Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2 to 4 months following evacuation of a molar pregnancy, hence can be managed expectantly. Sometimes,  it can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of such cysts has to be done.  

Irrespective of the size of the uterus, suction curettage is typically the preferred method for molar evacuation. If the cervix is minimally dilated, it is advisable to perform preoperative cervical dilation using an osmotic dilator. The amount of bleeding during surgery can be higher in cases of molar pregnancy compared to a uterus of similar size that contains nonmolar products. Having large moles necessitates the use of appropriate anesthetic, sufficient intravenous access, and availability of blood-banking services. To perform a molar evacuation, the cervix is mechanically dilated to facilitate the insertion of a large Karman suction cannula. A normal diameter of 10 to 14 mm is common, depending on the size of the uterus. Oxytocin is used during the evacuation process to minimize hemorrhage. Intraoperative sonography is frequently advised to guarantee thorough evacuation of the uterine cavity and reduce the risk of perforation. When the myometrium has contracted, a meticulous yet delicate curettage can be performed with a sharp large-loop Sims curette. The bleeding persists despite the removal of the uterus and the administration of oxytocin. In such cases, further uterotonic drugs are administered. In rare cases, pelvic arterial embolization, uterine packing, or hysterectomy may be required. 

Indications for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN

Note: Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given to Rh-negative women. The dose is 50 micrograms in the first trimester and 300 micrograms when gestational age is more than 12 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Oophorectomy is not indicated as the patient has no evidence of ovarian torsion on imaging as well as clinical assessment. Theca lutein cysts tend to spontaneously resolve following evacuation.

Option B: Labor-induced evacuation is very rarely performed owing to increased blood loss and the development of persistent trophoblastic disease.

Option D: Hysterectomy with B/L oophorectomy may be performed in patients who have completed their family along with signs of ovarian torsion due to large size cysts.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A patient who had an unprovoked tonic-clonic seizure 6 months ago presents for follow up. There is no family history of epilepsy, no evidence of organic brain disorder on neuroimaging, and EEG is normal. He has been seizure-free for the past 6 months on phenytoin therapy. When should phenytoin be considered for discontinuation?
questions.solution:
A patient on antiepileptics for 6 months with no further seizures, no family history, normal EEG, neurological examination, and intelligence, antiepileptics should be continued on for a duration of 2 years to prevent seizure recurrence.

Anti-epileptic drugs withdrawal is considered only when an adult patient has been seizure-free for ≥2 years along with the following criteria:

Normal CNS examination including intelligence
Normal EEG and normal MRI
Single seizure type
No family history of epilepsy.
It is preferable to taper the dose of the drug gradually over 2–3 months.

questions.text: Nerve entrapment at the structure marked in the image would result in compression of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is Guyon’s canal. Nerve entrapment here would affect the ulnar nerve.

It can be identified as Guyon’s canal as it is located on the anteromedial side of the flexor aspect of the wrist. Guyon's canal is a 4 cm long canal formed by splitting of the flexor retinaculum along the anteromedial side of the wrist.

Boundaries:

  • Ulnar/Medial - Pisiform bone, flexor carpi ulnaris, and abductor digiti minimi.
  • Lateral - hook of hamate, extrinsic flexor tendons, and the transverse carpal ligaments.
  • Floor - Flexor retinaculum and pisohamate ligaments
  • Roof - Palmar carpal ligament and palmaris brevis

Contents: Ulnar nerve and ulnar artery.

 

Guyon' canal syndrome/handlebar palsy caused by entrapment of the ulnar nerve as it courses through the Guyon’ canal in the wrist is commonly seen in regular cyclists. This occurs due to prolonged pressure over the nerve against the bicycle handlebar. The tunnel of Guyon is clinically significant because it contains the ulnar nerve and artery & is the site of compression injury; the ulnar artery is immediately adjacent and radial to the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with intermittent, severe pain on the left cheek & lips which increases on chewing or washing the face. Which of the following is not a potential side effect of the drug used to manage this condition?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with intermittent, severe pain on the left cheek & lips which increases on chewing or washing the face is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. The drug used for the management of this condition is carbamazepine. Of the listed options, gingival hyperplasia is not a potential side effect of carbamazepine. 

Carbamazepine is an anti-epileptic drug that acts by prolonging the inactivated state of the voltage-sensitive neuronal Na+ channel. It can be used for the management of partial seizures as well as generalized tonic-clonic seizures. It is the drug of choice for the management of trigeminal neuralgia. It is also used for the management of acute mania as an alternative to lithium. 

Potential adverse effects of carbamazepine include:

  • Dose-related neurotoxicity which manifests as sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia
  • Gastrointestinal side effects like vomiting and diarrhea
  • Bone marrow toxicity (Option A) which can cause agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (Option B) especially in the elderly, which can cause water retention and hyponatremia
  • Hypersensitivity reactions which can cause photosensitivity, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (Option D), hepatitis
  • Teratogenic and can cause fetal malformations like cleft lip/ palate and spina bifida if used during pregnancy
  • Acute intoxication can cause convulsions, coma, and cardiovascular collapse


Gingival hyperplasia (Option C) is the most common adverse effect of phenytoin seen in younger patients with poor oral hygiene. It is because of the overgrowth of collagen fibres. This adverse effect is unlikely to be seen with carbamazepine.

questions.text: The following instrument is used in:
questions.solution:
The instrument is a haemorrhoid stapler. It is used in hemorrhoidopexy.

The aim of this new operative approach is to reduce the size of internal hemorrhoids by interrupting their blood supply, therefore reducing the size of the vascular cushions and reducing the rectal mucosa for the potential of prolapse.

This procedure is associated with less postoperative pain as there is no perianal wound and the rectal wall above the dentate line has an insensitive mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be used for the management of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Dipivefrin, a pro-drug of epinephrine (adrenaline), should not be used in the management of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Being a non-selective adrenergic agonist, it can trigger α1 receptor-mediated mydriasis and is thus contraindicated for angle-closure glaucoma (ACG).

ACG is an ocular emergency that occurs with the closure of a pre-existing narrow anterior chamber angle. The patient presents with a unilateral headache, acute onset severe eye pain, and blurring of vision with associated nausea and vomiting. On examination, there is ciliary and conjunctival congestion, corneal edema, and a mid-dilated pupil that is non-reactive to light. Gonioscopy is the definitive diagnostic tool that reveals a closed angle.

The condition can be triggered by pupillary dilation i.e. mydriasis (eg, low ambient light) or certain medications (eg, decongestants, anticholinergic drugs). Dipivefrin, which is a pro-drug of epinephrine, is used in the management of open-angle glaucoma. It is a non-selective adrenergic agonist that decreases aqueous production and increases uveoscleral and trabecular outflow. However, due to the non-selective action on α1 receptors, both dipivefrin and epinephrine can trigger mydriasis and are thus contraindicated in ACG. 

Management of acute ACG is directed at rapidly lowering intraocular pressure (IOP): 

  • Intravenous acetazolamide (Option A) is recommended to rapidly reduce IOP. It is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases the further production of aqueous humor.
  • Timolol (Option C) is a topical β-blocker, that can be used with other topical agents such as latanoprost (topical prostaglandin analog) to further reduce the IOP. β-blockers decrease aqueous production, whereas prostaglandin analogs increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Pilocarpine (Option D) is a miotic that causes ciliary muscle contraction to open the trabecular meshwork at the corneal angle.

questions.text: A professor asks a student to identify the structure marked by the red arrows in the dissected part of the neck. He gives him a hint that this nerve arises from the medulla oblongata. He further adds that its damage causes the structure supplied by it to get deviated to the same side of the lesion. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked with the red arrows in the image is the hypoglossal nerve. 

The hypoglossal nerve courses lateral to the internal and external carotid artery and the facial artery. The nerve then ascends along the lateral surface of the hyoglossus muscle.

The hypoglossal nerve supplies all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vago accessory nerve. Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and malaise. On physical examination, he is found to have mild splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal the following:
  • WBC count: 68,000/μL
  • Differential count:
  • Metamyelocytes: 15%
  • Myelocytes: 10%
  • Bands: 20%
  • Segmented neutrophils: 45%
  • Lymphocytes: 10%
  • LAP score: High

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation is most consistent with a leukemoid reaction. The high WBC count, presence of a left shift with more metamyelocytes than myelocytes, and high LAP score all support this diagnosis.

Leukemoid reaction is a non-malignant condition characterized by a marked increase in the white blood cell count, often mimicking leukemia. It is a reactive response to various inflammatory conditions, infections, and other stressors. The presence of a high LAP score (left shift) with more metamyelocytes than myelocytes further supports this diagnosis.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is increased in polycythemia vera and leukemoid reactions. 

Other options:

Options B: CML is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome and an overproduction of mature granulocytes. While the WBC count may be elevated beyond 100000. Additionally, the presence of a high LAP score and a significant number of immature myeloid cells (metamyelocytes and myelocytes) are not typical findings in CML.

Option C: AML is a rapidly progressing cancer of the bone marrow characterized by the overproduction of immature myeloid cells. While the WBC count can be elevated in AML, the presence of a high LAP score and a significant number of metamyelocytes are more suggestive of a leukemoid reaction than AML. Additionally, the patient's age and clinical presentation are more consistent with a leukemoid reaction.

Option D: CLL is a slow-growing cancer of the bone marrow characterized by the overproduction of mature lymphocytes. The WBC count in CLL is typically elevated due to the increase in lymphocytes. However, the presence of a significant number of metamyelocytes and a high LAP score is not typical of CLL. Additionally, the patient's clinical presentation is not consistent with CLL.

questions.text: A patient suspected of having leishmaniasis is tested by culturing a sample in an artificial medium. What stage of the organism's life cycle will be detected in the cultured sample?
questions.solution:
In leishmaniasis, the promastigote form is detected upon culturing in artificial media such as NNN (Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle) medium and Schneider's liquid medium.

Leishmania donovani exists in 2 forms, the amastigote form (in humans and other mammals) and the promastigote form (in the sandfly and artificial culture). The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector is a female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man. 

Culture on NNN medium and Schneider’s liquid medium detects promastigotes and is useful for species identification and drug sensitivity testing. Promastigotes develop from amastigotes when cultured and are detected via Giemsa staining. In the promastigote form, the kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end, and a single flagellum is seen.

The lifecycle of Leishmania is shown below.

Other options: 

Option A: The amastigote form (Leishman-Donovan body) is intracellular, and found inside macrophages, monocytes, or reticuloendothelial cells. A kinetoplast is present which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent. Demonstration of amastigotes inside macrophages is the gold standard method for the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.

Option C and D: Epimastigote and Trypomastigote forms are not seen in Leishmania.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a parenterally administered anti-diabetic drug?
questions.solution:
Of the listed options, repaglinide is not a parenterally administered anti-diabetic drug.

Repaglinide is an oral anti-diabetic drug which is a meglitinide analog. Its mechanism of action is similar to that of sulfonylureas. It causes the closure of ATP-sensitive K+ channels, resulting in cell depolarization and insulin release. It has a quick onset of action and is administered orally before meals to achieve better post-prandial glycemic control. Because of the short half-life, it is unlikely to cause serious hypoglycemia.

Injectable anti-diabetics other than insulin preparations include the following drugs:

  • Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists: GLP-1 is an incretin released from the gut in response to dietary glucose. Thus, GLP-1 agonists induce glucose-dependent insulin release and inhibit glucagon release. These drugs are peptides and cannot be given orally. They are thus administered parenterally as subcutaneous injections. 
    Examples include liraglutide (Option A)  and exenatide (Option D). Both of these agents are used to improve glycemic control in poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • Amylin analogs such as pramlintide (Option C) reduce glucagon release and delay gastric emptying. Pramlintide is also administered as a subcutaneous injection. It is used to achieve better post-prandial glycemic control and can be used in both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with asymptomatic hypercalcemia. Investigations reveal serum calcium 11.5 mg/dL and PTH 65 pg/mL. Which test would be most helpful in differentiating familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) from primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT)?
questions.solution:
24-hour urinary calcium is the most helpful test for differentiating Familial Hypocalciuric Hpercalcemia from Primary Hyperparathyroidism. In FHH, the urinary calcium-to-creatinine clearance ratio (UCCR) is typically low (<0.01) due to increased renal calcium reabsorption. In contrast, PHPT patients have a high UCCR (>0.02) due to increased parathyroid hormone levels leading to increased urinary calcium excretion.

Parathyroid adenoma is an example of primary hyperparathyroidism and parathyroidectomy may be beneficial. In familial hypercalcemic hypocalciuria (FHH), mutations in the calcium sensing receptor lowers the capacity of the sensor to bind calcium. The mutant receptors function as though the serum calcium was low and hence there is excessive PTH secretion.

Other options:

Options A: Serum magnesium: While hypomagnesemia can activate the parathyroid gland, it is not specific for either FHH or PHPT and wouldn't be the best test for differentiation.

Option C: Serum phosphorus: While hypophosphatemia is more common in PHPT, it can also occur in FHH due to reduced renal phosphate reabsorption. Therefore, serum phosphorus alone is not sufficient for differentiation.
Option D: Alkaline phosphatase: Elevated alkaline phosphatase can occur in both FHH and PHPT, making it nonspecific for distinguishing the two conditions.

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient presents with increasing forgetfulness and language difficulties. He has an associated history of sick sinus syndrome. Which of the following drugs can be safely used for the management of his cognitive dysfunction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an 80-year-old patient presenting with increasing forgetfulness and language difficulties is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease. Given the associated history of sick sinus syndrome, the drug that can be safely used to treat his cognitive dysfunction is memantine.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. Symptoms usually begin in the 7th decade of life and consist chiefly of memory loss of recent events, word-finding difficulties, and progressive cognitive decline.

The following agents can be used to slow the progression of the disease:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors - The chief pathophysiology of AD involves the degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert. Thus, these agents work to increase acetylcholine levels to produce symptomatic cognitive improvement. The drugs in this class include donepezil (Option A), rivastigmine (Option C), and galantamine (Option D). They are usually well tolerated and side effects include nausea, diarrhea, and vivid dreams.
    These agents can however worsen bradycardia, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiac conduction abnormalities. They are thus used with caution, especially as elderly patients have increasing sinus node dysfunction. 
  • NMDA receptor antagonists - They reduce glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity and slow the disease progression. Memantine, which belongs to this class, is thus used for moderate to severe AD. Adverse effects include headache, dizziness, confusion, and hallucinations. However, it does not cause any cardiac conduction abnormalities and can be safely used in such patients. It is generally better tolerated than cholinesterase inhibitors and can be used as a monotherapy. 
  • Aducanumab is an amyloid beta-directed antibody recently approved by the FDA for the management of AD. 

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who has regular menstrual cycles presents with amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is done and found to be positive. She recalls that the first day of her last menstrual period was October 9. What would her expected date of delivery be based on Naegele's rule?
questions.solution:
Based on Naegele’s rule, the expected date of delivery (EDD) of this woman is July 16.

Naegele’s rule is based on a 28-day regular cycle and states that the EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the 1st day of the last menstrual period (LMP). In this case, the first day of LMP was October 9, the due date is 10-3(months) i.e. 7th month of the following year- July, and add 7 days to the date i.e. 9+7=16. Hence, the EDD will be on July 16.

questions.text: A patient developed malaria after receiving a blood transfusion. Which infective form of malaria is not transmitted through transfusion?
questions.solution:
The infective form of malaria transmitted through blood transfusion includes intraerythrocytic forms such as merozoites, trophozoites, or schizonts but not gametocytes.

Malaria can be spread through blood transfusion, needle stick injuries, or organ transplants. Clinical features and management of transfusion malaria are similar to naturally acquired infection.

The infective form can be intraerythrocytic forms such as merozoites, trophozoites, or schizonts excluding gametocytes. The incubation period is short as there is no pre-erythrocytic stage of development. Hence, relapses of infection by Plasmodium vivax or ovale do not occur. Primaquine is thus not necessary as there are no liver stages.

The below image shows the life cycle of Plasmodium spp.

questions.text: A long standing diabetic presents with abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence and diarrhea. She has also had weight loss and megaloblastic anemia. Her Hydrogen Breath test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Rifaximin is an antibiotic that is specifically effective against the types of bacteria commonly associated with SIBO.

Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth - SIBO can be caused by strictures, surgery, DM, scleroderma, AIDS. It is characterized by symptoms of malabsorption: diarrhea, flatulence, weightloss, anemia in chronic cases - particularly megaloblastic anemia due to reduced B12 and high folate levels. Diagnosis is by endoscopy with jejunal aspirate (shows > 105 microorgansims) and glucose hydrogen breath test.

Treatment is a 7-day course of Rifaximin/Amoxiclav and a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet. Surgery is often the best option for conditions like blind loops, strictures, diverticula, or afferent loops. However, surgery cannot be used to treat functional stasis caused by scleroderma or other conditions. For these cases, broad-spectrum antibiotics are appropriate. Other treatment options for SIBO include dietary modifications and probiotics. Probiotics can help restore the balance of bacteria in the gut, which may improve symptoms of SIBO. A low-FODMAP diet is a type of diet that eliminates certain types of carbohydrates that can be difficult to digest for people with SIBO.

Options B, C and D: Clarithromycin is usually used for H. pylori, and is not as effective as rifaximin. 5-ASA and budesonide are anti-inflammatory drugs effective for IBD.

questions.text:
According to WHO, which of the following indicators is used to calculate both HDI and PQLI?

HDI - Human Development Index
PQLI - Physical Quality of Life Index
questions.solution:
Literacy is used in the measurement of both HDI and PQLI.

The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:

  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical quality of life index (PQLI).

questions.text: The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by
questions.solution:
The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia.

Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. This is the reason for frequent defecation after meals in children. This reflex can also be amplified by the action of gastrin.

Other reflexes that involve the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include the following:

  • Enterogastric reflex: Signals from colon and small intestinal signals stop gastric motility and secretion.
  • Colonoileal reflex: Signals from the colon prevent ileal emptying

The brain stem and spinal cord are involved in:

  • Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract
  • Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity
  • Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall.

Local reflexes mediated by the enteric nervous system regulate local secretion, peristalsis, mixing contractions, and ileus.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your OPD with lesions as shown below. The parent says he also had similar lesions in childhood. The lesions are present on the forearm, face, and flexures and are very itchy on the background of dry skin showing signs of lichenification. Grattage test or scratching reveals oozing of serous fluid. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image showing eczematous lesions on the forearm, and flexures. This along with the history of them being very itchy and being located on the dry skin showing signs of lichenification and a grattage test revealing oozing of serous fluid points towards atopic dermatitis as the likely diagnosis.

Atopic dermatitis can be divided into 3 phases: Infantile, childhood, and adult phases.

Infantile phase: The lesions of Atopic Eczema most frequently start on the face but may occur anywhere on the skin surface. Often, the napkin area is relatively spared.

  • When the child begins to crawl, the exposed surfaces, especially the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are most involved.
  • The lesions consist of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • Secondary infection and lymphadenopathy are common.

Childhood Phase: From 18 to 24 months onwards, the sites most characteristically involved are the elbow and knee flexures, a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper‐ and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification may be seen depending on the skin type on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles.

  • The sides of the neck may show a striking reticulate pigmentation, sometimes referred to as atopic dirty neck.
  • The erythematous and oedematous papules tend to be replaced by lichenification.

Adult Phase: The picture is essentially similar to that in later childhood, with lichenification, especially of the flexures and hands.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen simplex chronicus usually presents as an itchy plaque. Chronic itching produces secondary lichenification. It may be associated with the history of atopy. It is less likely to appear as oozing on scratching. A predilection for flexural aspect in childhood as in this case is not classically seen.

Option B: Psoriasis classically involves extensor aspect unlike flexures as in this child. Moreover, it is associated with silvery scaling and grattage reveals fresh bleeding points (Auspitz sign) and not oozing of serous fluid.

Option D: Scabies is caused by itch mites laying eggs in burrows made in the skin. The burrows are visible as serpiginous erythematous lesions. It classically causes itching more during the evening and involves lesions in the circle of hebra unlike flexures as in this case.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with acute onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a low-grade fever, with a pulse rate of 90 bpm and blood pressure of 126/84 mm Hg. She has regular menstrual cycles of 28 days. Pelvic examination shows a tender right adnexal mass. Ultrasound scan reveals a swollen oedematous ovary, globular in shape with disruption in adnexal flow seen on doppler. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Urine pregnancy testing- negative
Serum β-HCG level- 1 mIU/L
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion.

Torsion of the ovaries is a gynecological emergency and is most commonly seen in women of the reproductive age group. Ovarian cysts including mucous cystadenomas and dermoid cysts have the highest risks of undergoing torsion. Adnexal masses measuring >6 cm in diameter have the highest rates of torsion.

A patient with torsion presents with sharp lower abdominal pain, usually localized to the involved side with radiation to the flank, groin, or thigh. Nausea and vomiting are commonly associated. Adnexal necrosis may cause a low-grade fever. 

During torsion, the low-pressure veins are initially compressed by the twisting pedicle. This leads to continuous inflow with decreased outflow causing stromal edema and congestion. The increasing stromal swelling later compresses the arteries causing ischemia and necrosis.

On USG, the ovary appears enlarged, globular, and has a heterogenous appearance compared to the contralateral ovary due to edema, engorgement, and hemorrhage. Twisting of the vascular pedicle may give rise to a 'whirlpool sign', a round hyperechoic structure with concentric hypoechoic stripes. Colour Doppler sonography should be performed in suspected torsion as it may show disruption to blood flow, which is highly suggestive of torsion. However, some cases of incomplete torsion or chronic torsion, may not show decreased flow on Doppler. MRI or CT imaging can be used in patients with normal Doppler but with characteristic signs and symptoms of torsion, to confirm or rule out the diagnosis.

Management involves urgent laparotomy or laparoscopic evaluation. Salvage of the involved adnexa with the removal of any associated cyst/tumor and possible oophoropexy are the goals. However, necrosis of the adnexa necessitates the removal of the adnexal structures.

Other options:

Option A: In a woman of reproductive age group, ovulatory pain following the rupture of Graafian follicle (ovulation) may present similarly with lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. This patient has a regular 28-day cycle and should have ovulated around the 14th day. 

Option B: Tubo-ovarian abscess presents with a more indolent course, and may be associated with fever. The characteristic appearance on USG is of a complex, multilocular mass. 

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy presents with nausea, vomiting, and adnexal pain, with or without a mass. However, this patient has a negative UPT, and serum β-HCG level is in the non-pregnant range (< 2 mIU/L) excluding ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient is prescribed clonidine for the management of hypertension. Identify the mechanism of action of the drug.
questions.solution:
Clonidine is a centrally-acting sympatholytic drug used in the management of hypertension. It acts by selective α2 receptor agonism to reduce blood pressure. 

Clonidine is an imidazoline derivative with high affinity and intrinsic activity at the α2 receptors, especially the α2A subtype in the brainstem. Stimulation of α2A receptors at the vasomotor center of the medulla results in the hemodynamic effects of decreased sympathetic outflow and resultant fall in blood pressure. It is associated with an enhanced vagal tone that results in a reduced heart rate. These factors make the drug a moderately potent antihypertensive. 

Clonidine can also be used to manage the sympathetic overactivity of opioid withdrawal syndrome. It has also been used to facilitate & manage smoking cessation and alcohol withdrawal. It has been used in some cases to manage the vasomotor symptoms of menopause and diarrhea due to diabetic neuropathy.

Some adverse effects of the drug include sedation, bradycardia, disturbed sleep, dryness of mouth, and postural hypotension. A potentially serious complication is rebound hypertension if the drug is missed for 1–2 days. This is associated with an alarming rise in blood pressure which may be more than the pretreatment level.


Other options:
Selective α1 receptor antagonism (Option A) is the mechanism of action of drugs used in the management of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and hypertension. They include prazosin, terazosin, doxazosin, alfuzosin and tamsulosin. Tamsulosin & alfuzosin are uroselective α1 blockers that are used to relieve the dynamic obstruction at the bladder neck. Other agents can also be used for the management of hypertension. 

Selective α1 receptor agonism (Option B) is the mechanism of action of drugs such as phenylephrine which is used as a nasal decongestant and also as a mydriatic agent. Midodrine is another example that has been used to treat patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension. 

Nonselective α receptor antagonism (Option D) is the mechanism of action of drugs such as phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. They are administered before the surgical removal of pheochromocytoma to control the episodes of severe hypertension. They have also been used to manage the cheese reaction occurring in patients who take MAO inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: The sign seen in the following sonography is suggestive of which fetal anomaly-
questions.solution:
The lemon sign is suggestive of spina bifida.

This is called lemon sign as at the level of lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by arrow). It is alsocharectaristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

Another sign called banana sign can also be seen in spina bifida in which at the level of posterior fossa, anterior curvature of cerebellum with effacement of cisterna magna can be seen.

questions.text: A hormone, with the structure as shown below, is being administered to a patient. It is known that it is released during the well-fed state and that it induces the rate-limiting enzyme of a reaction. Choose the correct pair of the rate-limiting enzyme induced and the reaction it is involved in.
questions.solution:
The hormone whose structure is shown in the image is insulin which is released in the well-fed state. Insulin induces the enzyme phosphofructokinase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis.

Glycolysis is a pathway in which glucose is converted to pyruvate in aerobic conditions or lactate in anaerobic conditions, along with the production of a small amount of energy. The rate-limiting reaction in glycolysis is the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate. This is catalyzed by the enzyme phosphofructokinase.

There are two phosphofructokinases, PFK-1 and PFK-2 which participate in this reaction. PFK-1 plays a key role in regulating glycolysis and is subject to feedback control. It converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bis-phosphate.

Inhibitors of PFK-1:

  • ATP
  • Citrate

Allosteric activators of PFK-1:

  • AMP
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (most potent activator)

Hormonal regulation:

  • Inducer—Insulin
  • Repressor—Glucagon

Due to the inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 by ATP, there is an accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate, which in turn inhibits the uptake of glucose in extrahepatic tissues.

PFK-2 phosphorylates fructose-6-phosphate to form fructose-2-6-bis-phosphate in the fed state. PFK-2 also acts as fructose bisphosphatase-2 (FBPase-2) and breaks down fructose 2,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate in the fasting state. Hence, PFK-2 is a bifunctional enzyme whose function is reversed by the presence of insulin or glucagon in the fed and fasting states respectively. 

The primary structure of insulin consists of 2 polypeptide chains: A-chain (21 amino acids) and B-chain (30 amino acids).
 
It has two interchain disulfide bonds, 
  • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain 
  • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain

One intrachain disulfide bond is present between the 6th amino acid of the A-chain and the 11th amino acid in the A-chain.

questions.text:
Which of the following are likely the cardiovascular effects of thyrotoxicosis?
Option Contractility Pulse Pressure Cardiac Output Systemic Vascular Resistance
A ↑ ↑ ↑ ↓
B ↑ ↑ ↓ ↓
C ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
D ↓ ↓ ↓ ↑
questions.solution:
A patient with thyrotoxicosis would have increased contractility, pulse pressure, cardiac output, and decreased systemic vascular resistance.

The cardiovascular effects of thyrotoxicosis are caused by the direct and indirect actions of thyroid hormones:

Direct Actions:

Increased β-adrenergic receptor sensitivity: Upregulation of the β-adrenergic receptors in the heart, making them more responsive to catecholamines like epinephrine and norepinephrine. This heightened sensitivity leads to increased heart rate (tachycardia), myocardial contractility, and stroke volume.

Enhanced L-type calcium channel activity: Thyroid hormones increase the activity of L-type calcium channels in the heart, which regulate the influx of calcium ions into cardiac cells. This increased calcium influx enhances myocardial contractility and relaxation.

Peripheral vasodilation: Thyroid hormones relax smooth muscle in the peripheral vasculature, leading to vasodilation and decreased systemic vascular resistance. This vasodilation contributes to the bounding pulse and widened pulse pressure observed in thyrotoxicosis.

Indirect Actions:

Increased metabolic rate: This metabolic increase demands a higher cardiac output to meet the body's oxygen requirements.

Increased blood volume: Thyroid hormones promote fluid retention, resulting in an increase in blood volume. This expanded blood volume further contributes to the high cardiac output and widened pulse pressure.

Sinus tachycardia is the most common cardiovascular symptom of hyperthyroidism. It often causes palpitations, and can occasionally be triggered by supraventricular tachycardia. The increased heart rate, coupled with increased contractility leads to a widened pulse pressure, and a systolic murmur, and can worsen angina or heart failure in older adults or those with pre-existing heart conditions. Atrial fibrillation is more common in patients over 50 years of age with hyperthyroidism. 

A systolic pleuropericardial friction rub (Means-Lerman scratch) may be heard at the left second intercostal space during expiration resulting from rubbing of pericardium against the pleura and is thought to result from the hyperdynamic cardiac motion.


Elderly patients with hyperthyroidism may present with only cardiovascular manifestations of thyrotoxicosis such as sinus tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and hypertension, all of which may be resistant to therapy until the hyperthyroidism is controlled.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient with a history of chronic hepatitis C is brought to the clinic for evaluation of the lesions shown below on his lower limbs. The lesions are non-blanching. Further workup reveals the diagnosis to be leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Which of the following is likely to be seen on biopsy of these lesions?

choices.text: Granulomas with areas of central necrosis and surrounding vasculitis in small vessels
Segmental transmural necrotising inflammation of the medium sized vessels
Granulomatous inflammation of the media with giant cells in large vessels
Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media without granulomatous inflammation in small vessels

questions.solution:
Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media without granulomatous inflammation in small vessels is likely to be seen on biopsy in this patient with microscopic polyangiitis/ leukocytoclastic vasculitis. 

Microscopic polyangiitis/hypersensitivity vasculitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects the capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is associated with the presence of MPO-ANCA. The skin, mucous membrane, lung, brain, heart, kidneys, and muscle can all be affected. It is a feature of many immune disorders such as essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and vasculitis in connective tissue disorders. The pathogenesis involves immune complex deposition, recruitment, and activation of neutrophils within the affected vascular beds

Biopsy findings:

  • Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media and focal transmural necrotizing lesions.
  • Granulomatous inflammation is absent.
  • Postcapillary venules typically show the presence of infiltrating neutrophils that are undergoing apoptosis.
  • Early skin lesions demonstrate immunoglobulins and complement components, most late lesions show no evidence of these findings.

Other options:

Option A: Granulomas with areas of central necrosis and surrounding vasculitis in small vessels is a feature of Churg-Strauss syndrome

Option B: Segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation of the medium-sized vessels is seen in polyarteritis nodosa

Option C: Granulomatous inflammation of the media with giant cells in large vessels is a feature of Takayasu's arteritis

questions.text: A 46-year-old female patient has been recently diagnosed with breast cancer and is undergoing evaluation. As a new mother who is currently breastfeeding, she is curious about the skin changes over her breast. A representative image has been shown below. What is the mechanism for these skin changes?
questions.solution:
The given image shows peau d'orange appearance seen in breast carcinoma and the mechanism for this appearance is cutaneous lymphatic edema. 

In breast cancer, lymphatic fluid accumulates in the extracellular space. In the skin over the breast, there are multiple sweat ducts. The ducts pull the skin, which restricts the swelling that occurs as a result of lymphatic edema. This results in an 'orange skin' appearance which is termed 'peau d'orange' in French. 

Breast cancer spreads locally, lymphatically, and via the bloodstream. Local infiltration involves the skin, pectoral muscles, and chest wall. Lymphatic metastasis occurs via the axillary and internal mammary lymph nodes and is considered to be a poor prognosis. Breast cancer can metastasize to the vertebrae via the bloodstream and is considered to be an advanced disease. 

Other options

Option A - Infiltration of the skin with carcinoma is seen in cancer-en-cuirasse. It usually occurs as a result of local reoccurrence after mastectomy. Other than palliative treatment, there is no specific treatment for this condition. 

Option B - Infection from a cracked nipple is seen in lactational mastitis. This occurs in breastfeeding mothers. The infecting organism ascends from the nipple and causes mastitis. It is treated with antibiotics. 

Option D - Superficial thrombophlebitis is seen in Mondor's disease. This vein appears as a thrombosed, superficial cord that distorts the breast architecture when the arm is moved. There is no specific treatment as it subsides on its own. 

The below image shows lactational mastitis in a breastfeeding mother.

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following would you expect in a patient with obstructive sleep apnea?
questions.solution:
A patient with obstructive sleep apnea will exhibit daytime sleepiness.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) occurs due to increased work of breathing, respiratory muscle impairment related to the increased load, and depressed central ventilatory response to hypoxemia and hypercapnia. The diagnosis of OHS requires: BMI ≥30 kg/m2 and PaCO2 ≥45 mmHg which signifies daytime alveolar hypoventilation.

This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index, and is calculated as: number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep. Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or a brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG). This includes measurement of breathing, oxygenation, body position, cardiac rhythm, sleep stages, and snoring intensity. Note that waking hypoxemia or hypercarbia in a patient with OSA suggests cardiopulmonary disease or obesity hypoventilation syndrome.

Narcolepsy (options B, C and D) also presents with difficulty sustaining wakefulness and disturbed nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy usually feel well-rested on awakening and then feel tired throughout the day. One of the most characteristic clinical features which is seen is cataplexy – sudden muscle weakness without a loss of consciousness, which is usually triggered by strong emotions, and hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations (hallucinations on going to sleep and on waking, respectively)

questions.text: As part of a pretransplant workup, a 59-year-old man with a previous history of MI undergoes cardiac catheterization to determine his cardiac fitness. During estimation of his systolic function, in what phase of the cardiac cycle do expect to see his peak left ventricular pressure?
questions.solution:
Peak ventricular pressure occurs during ventricular ejection

As is clear from Wigger's diagram below, peak pressure in the ventricles in systole corresponds to the ejection phase. 

Isovolumetric contraction occurs when the pressure of the left ventricle goes from the pressure level of the left atrium to that of the aorta, following which the aortic valves open. Isovolumentric relaxation occurs during the reverse process, while the left ventricle's pressure falls.

The Cardiac Cycle:

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to the momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with the 'a' wave in JVP.

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic tonsillitis presented to the OPD with complaints of a gritty sensation in her throat. On palpation and probing, you confirm the sensation. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the clinical scenario, the patient having chronic tonsillitis with a gritty sensation in the throat suggests a possible diagnosis of tonsilloliths. 

Tonsilloliths are complications of chronic tonsillitis and are mostly seen in adults. They are calcium and magnesium-rich calculi of the tonsils that occur due to the blocking of crypts and retention of debris. They give rise to a gritty sensation in the throat and can be confirmed with palpation or probing. They may enlarge and ulcerate through the tonsil. Tonsilloliths are treated by removal of stone or tonsillectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Intratonsillar abscess is a complication of acute tonsillitis where pus is accumulated in the tonsils. It presents with inflamed, tender tonsils with significant pain and dysphagia. They can be treated with antibiotics, drainage, or tonsillectomy at a later date. 

Option C: Tonsillar cyst is an asymptomatic yellowish swelling over the tonsil due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt. It is treated by incision and drainage.

Option D: Lingual tonsil abscess is a severe complication of acute tonsillitis as it can cause laryngeal edema. Jugulodigastric nodes are commonly involved. Dysphagia, excessive salivation and painful tongue protrusion are some of the clinical findings seen in this condition.
