questions.text: Which of the following conditions is unlikely to cause the finding given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image of the eye demonstrates a hypopyon. Of the listed conditions, preseptal cellulitis is unlikely to present with this clinical finding.

A hypopyon is the accumulation of polymorphonuclear leucocytes enmeshed in a mesh of fibrin at the lower angle of the eye's anterior chamber. It is usually associated with corneal ulcers (e.g., fungal keratitis), conditions causing anterior uveitis (e.g., Behçet disease), or severe inflammation of the globe such as endophthalmitis. Inflammation results in an outpouring of leucocytes from the vessels, and these cells gravitate to the bottom of the anterior chamber, depending on the position of the patient’s head. 

  • Hypopyon associated with fungal keratitis (Option A) is usually large, and less fluid due to a dense fibrinous network, resulting from direct invasion by fungal hyphae.
  • Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the iris (iritis), ciliary body (cyclitis), or both (iridocyclitis). This condition is usually idiopathic but can be associated with Behçet disease (Option B), psoriatic arthritis, and HLA-B27-associated diseases. Resulting inflammation of the iris can result in the development of a hypopyon. 
  • Endophthalmitis (Option D) is a severe inflammation of the vitreous humor that can be exogenous (e.g., post-operative, post-traumatic) or endogenous (e.g., septicemia in immunosuppressed patients). It is a sight-threatening condition, and there can be the development of an associated hypopyon.

 

Preseptal cellulitis (Option C) is a purulent inflammation of the cellular tissue of the orbit anterior to the orbital septum. It usually presents with a swelling of the lids with erythema and chemosis. However, it is an inflammation outside the globe, and there is no restriction of ocular function. It is unlikely to present with a hypopyon.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with back pain. He has been smoking for the past 30 years. On physical exam, he has an enlarged pulsatile mass over his abdomen. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following are indications for elective surgical repair in this patient?
  1. Presence of a pulsatile mass on physical exam
  2. Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm
  3. Expansion <0.5 cm in 1 year
  4. Blood pressure >160/100
  5. Associated with iliac arterial aneurysm
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a smoker with abdominal/back pain, history of hypertension and smoking, physical examination revealing a pulsatile mass, and CT findings showing dilation of the abdominal aorta is indicative of abdominal aortic aneurysm(AAA). The following are indications for elective repair of AAA.

  1. Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm
  2. Rapid expansion >1 cm in 1 year.
  3. AAA associated with peripheral arterial aneurysm (eg, iliac, popliteal) or symptomatic peripheral artery disease (eg, iliac occlusive disease) undergoing revascularization

An abdominal aortic aneurysm is commonly asymptomatic and is picked up on screening. Pain may be present in larger aneurysms and is expected over the abdomen or back. Lower limb ischemia may be present in advanced cases. Physical examination may reveal a pulsatile mass in large aneurysms. A ruptured AAA will present with circulatory collapse and acute pain.

It is diagnosed by ultrasonography, which is the screening modality of choice. CT scan is the gold standard for determining the anatomic eligibility for endovascular repair.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple hyperpigmented macules all over the body, which have increased in size and number since birth along with inguinal freckling. His eye findings are given below. Which of the following may be associated with the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with multiple hyperpigmented macules (café-au-lait macules) all over the body, which have increased in size and number since birth, and associated eye findings of iris hamartomas (Lisch nodules) is characteristic of neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1). This condition may be associated with peripheral nerve sheath tumors.

NF1 is caused by the autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. It is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes neurofibromin, a negative RAS regulator. The disease is clinically diagnosed when any two of the following seven features are present:

  1. Six or more café-au-lait macules (CALMs) - They are the hallmark of neurofibromatosis and are present in almost 100% of patients. They are present at birth but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first few years of life, and are scattered over the entire body. 
  2. Axillary or inguinal freckling
  3. Two or more iris Lisch nodules - They are iris hamartomas that are best identified by a slit-lamp examination. They are present in the majority of patients with NF1.
  4. Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma
  5. A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones such as the tibia
  6. Optic gliomas (most frequently observed CNS tumor in NF1)
  7. A first-degree relative with NF-1

NF1 can be associated with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors. These are aggressive sarcomas that can arise de novo or as the result of malignant degeneration of an existing plexiform neurofibroma. Additionally, the incidence of pheochromocytoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, leukaemia, and Wilms tumor is higher in this patient population. 

Other options:
Cardiac rhabdomyoma (Option B) and renal angiomyolipoma (Option C) are associated with tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a multisystem disease that also shows an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. This disease is associated with cortical dysplasia in the brain, subependymal nodules, giant cell astrocytoma, hypomelanotic macules (ash-leaf spots), facial angiofibromas, cardiac rhabdomyoma, and renal angiomyolipoma.

Option D: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma is associated with von Hippel–Lindau syndrome. This disease also follows the autosomal dominant mode of inheritance and is associated with hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum, retinal angiomas, renal cysts, renal cell carcinomas, and pheochromocytomas.

questions.text: The prevalence of the disease 'X' in a population is 30%. Which of the following tests would have the highest positive predictive value of detecting the disease 'X'?
questions.solution:
The prevalence of the disease 'X' in the population is 30%. So the total number of people with the disease is 30(TP+FN) and disease-free(FP+TN) is 70.

Knowing the following three formulas is crucial to come to the answer to this question

  • Since sensitivity is TP/(TP + FN)
  • Specificity is TN/ (TN + FP)
  • Positive predictive value (PPV) = TP/(FP + TP) x 100 

Hence, a test with less false positives would have a high specificity and low false positive rate.

Also, a test with less false negatives would have high sensitivity and a low false negative rate.

An alternate formula(Bayes theorem) that can be used is PPV = (P) x Sn /[P x Sn] +[(1-P) x(1- Sp)]

Sn- Sensitivity, P- Prevalence, Sp- Specificity

Plugging in the values in this formula would yield the following for each value of sensitivity and specificity in the options provided.

Option A: 0.85 x 0.3 / 0.85 x 0.3 + ( 1 - 0.88 ) x ( 1 - 0.3 ) -> 0.255 / 0.255 + 0.084 = 0.255 / 0.339 = 0.7522

Option B: 0.85 x 0.3 / 0.85 x 0.3 + ( 1 - 0.92 ) x ( 1 - 0.3 ) -> 0.255/ 0.255 + 0.056 = 0.255 / 0.311 = 0.819

Option C: 0.7 x 0.3 / 0.7 x 0.3 + ( 1 - 0.9 ) x ( 1 - 0.3 ) -> 0.21 / 0.21 + 0.07 = 0.21 / 0.28 = 0.75

Option D: 0. 66 x 0.3 / 0.66 x 0.3 + (1 - 0.95) x ( 1 - 0.3 ) -> 0.198 / 0.198 + 0.035 = 0.198 / 0.233 = 0.849

Hence, furthering the point that a test with the highest specificity will have the highest positive predictive value.

Although you could calculate using Baye's theorem and still come to the answer, which of course is excruciating. You can always verify the answer with the theorem, but a more logical approach would be to look at the specificity in the actual exam. The higher the specificity, the less likelihood of receiving false positive test results and thus a high positive predictive value.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 62-year-old lady was planned for coronary angiography through the radial route. The cardiologist had multiple unsuccessful attempts with the radial puncture. As a part of evaluating it, a biopsy of the radial artery was done and is shown below. What is the most probable condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. The image shows calcification of the walls of the artery seen as the dark purple stained area on H&E staining.

Monckeberg's medial sclerosis or medial calcific sclerosis is a type of arteriosclerosis, characterized by calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically involving the internal elastic membrane. The calcifications do not encroach on the lumen and are usually not clinically significant. It is usually an incidental finding. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is not associated with hypertension or diabetes.

Arteriosclerosis refers to the thickening and loss of elasticity of arterial wall. Other patterns of arteriosclerosis:

  • Arteriolosclerosis: It affects small arteries and arterioles, and may cause downstream ischemic injury. It is associated with hypertension and has two anatomic variants:
    • Hyaline
    • Hyperplastic
  • Atherosclerosis: Most frequent and clinically important pattern which poses a risk of causing coronary, cerebral, and peripheral vascular diseases. It is characterized by the presence of atheromas (also called atheromatous or atherosclerotic plaques) that protrude into vessel lumens.

questions.text:
A baby was born at 33 weeks of gestation by cesarean delivery. After 3 hours he was found to have cyanosis, tachypnea, and grunting. Auscultation revealed decreased air entry into the lungs. Chest radiograph was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding the substance that is deficient in this baby?
  1. It is produced mainly by type I alveolar cells
  2. It contains phosphatidylcholine
  3. It also prevents pulmonary oedema
  4. Ceramide is the main component
  5. Steroids increase its production
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are true regarding surfactant.

A preterm baby is showing features of respiratory distress along with the radiograph showing increased homogenous opacification of the lungs. This is suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome which occurs due to the deficiency of surfactant. 

Surfactant lines the alveoli of the lungs. It is secreted by the type II alveolar epithelial cells. It contains phospholipids, triglycerides, cholesterol, and fatty acids. Phosphatidylcholine is the major phospholipid. Other phospholipids are phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), sphingomyelin (SM), phosphatidylinositol (PI), and phosphatidylserine. Ceramide is not a major component of surfactants. Important proteins are surfactant protein (SP)- A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

The important function is to reduce the surface tension of the alveoli. The pressure required for the expansion of alveoli is directly proportional to the surface tension present over the alveolar sacs. Surfactant reduces this surface tension and thereby reduces the pressure required to expand lungs. It also prevents pulmonary oedema.

Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of life and peaks at 35 weeks gestation. Therefore, any neonate less than 35 weeks is prone to develop RDS.

 Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS):

RDS is common in preterm babies less than 34 weeks of gestation. It occurs due to the deficiency of the surfactant in the alveoli. Decreased surfactant increases the surface tension over the alveoli which makes the alveoli to collapse easily. Therefore, the baby has to put more effort to expand the lungs. This results in respiratory distress and hypoxemia. Ischemic damage to the alveoli causes the transudation of proteins into the alveoli that form the hyaline membrane.

It usually occurs in the first few hours of life. The babies will have tachypnea, grunting, retractions, cyanosis and decreased air entry. Chest radiograph will show reticulogranular pattern, ground-glass opacity, low lung volume, air bronchogram and white-out lungs in severe disease.

Mild to moderate RDS can be managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). CPAP is a noninvasive modality of support where a continuous distending pressure (5-7 cm H20) is applied at the nostril level to keep the alveoli open in a spontaneously breathing baby. Severe cases will require mechanical ventilation.

Steroids increase the production of the surfactant and therefore steroids are administered antenatally to mothers with preterm labour.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male who is a known diabetic for 10 years has been hospitalised due to community-acquired pneumonia. 5 days later, he developed significant dyspnea, tachypnea, cyanosis. Chest X-ray revealed diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities.  The arterial PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 120 mmHg. There are no signs suggestive of cardiac failure, on  examination. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the inflammatory response in this condition?

choices.text: Lymphocytes play the most significant role in tissue injury.
It is known as shock lung.
Damage to the endothelial cells is the key initiating event.
Prognosis is poor with high mortality rates.

questions.solution:
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has set in this patient with pneumonia. Shock lung also known as ARDS/ HMD/ ALI  is characterised histologically by diffuse alveolar damage. Neutrophils play a significant role in tissue injury in this condition.

The characteristic histological picture is that of a hyaline membrane lining the alveolar walls. Edema, scattered neutrophils and macrophages, and necrotic epithelial cells are also present.

ARDS is a clinical syndrome manifested as a result of severe lung injury and characterized by inflammation, which causes increased pulmonary vascular permeability and edema. Damage to the endothelial and alveolar epithelial cells, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a manifestation of severe ALI.

In ARDS, neutrophils adhere to the activated endothelium and migrate into the interstitium and the alveoli, where they degranulate and release inflammatory mediators, including proteases, reactive oxygen species, and cytokines.

Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition: The Berlin definition requires each of the following criteria to be present to diagnose ARDS:

  1. Onset- Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun within one week of a known clinical insult
  2. Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: must be present on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
  3. Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
  4. Impairment of oxygenation must be present: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS

Severity

PaO2/FiO2 (On ventilator settings that include PEEP ≥5 cm H2O)

Mild

> 200 mmHg but ≤ 300 mmHg

Moderate

> 100 mmHg but ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe

≤ 100 mmHg

ARDS is clinically characterized by the abrupt onset of significant hypoxemia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates in the absence of cardiac failure. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates- white-out appearance.  The prognosis is poor with high mortality (40%). (Option D)

questions.text: Capsular polysaccharide constitutes an important virulence factor responsible for protective antibody response. In which among the following bacteria is the protective response not due to capsular polysaccharide?
questions.solution:
Among the given bacteria, the protective response in Bordetella pertussis is not due to capsular polysaccharides.

Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative coccobacillus. It produces various virulence factors and toxins that are responsible for the clinical disease.

  • Pertussis toxin causes lymphocytosis, sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion. It can be toxoided and the toxoid form is a major component of acellular pertusis vaccines. 
  • Filamentous hemagglutinin(FHA) promotes adherence of the B.pertussis to the cilia of respiratory tract and erythrocytes. It also has a hemagglutinin activity. 
  • Pertactin is an outer membrane protein (OMP) antigen present in all virulent strains. It is part of acellular pertusis vaccines and antibody to pertactin is seen in blood after immunization or infection in children
  • Tracheal cytotoxin causes destruction of the ciliated cells in the trachea. 
  • Other virulence factors- Includes Adenylate cyclase, heat-labile toxin, lipopolysaccharide.

Capsulated bacteria include:-

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Several groups of streptococci
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Klebsiella
  • Haemophilus influenza
  • Yersinia
  • Bacillus

questions.text: Your friend tells you about his upcoming deep-sea diving trip. Which of the following is most likely to cause your friend to suffer from 'the bends'?

choices.text: The speed at which he ascends
The amount of time he spends underwater
The depth to which he dives

questions.solution:
A rapid speed of the ascent is most likely to cause a diver to suffer from decompression sickness, also called Caisson's disease, or 'the bends'.

As a diver goes deep underwater, the pressure of inert gases such as nitrogen, which is inspired, is increased and gets dissolved in the blood and tissues. Divers are advised to ascend slowly so that as they go from higher-pressure surroundings (deep) to lower-pressure surroundings (surface), the inert gases can equilibrate without expanding within the body. Decompression sickness occurs when due to a sudden change in pressure, excess nitrogen, remains within the diver's blood and tissues, so that when they reach the surface, the low pressure allows the gas bubbles to expand within their body cavities, causing the symptoms of decompression sickness.

(One can imagine the size of a bubble increasing as it rises from the bottom of a bottle/pool from the depth to the surface)

Decompression sickness is therefore prevented by having divers ascend gradually and take decompression stops where they spend some time at a certain depth and gradually ascend (a staircase pattern) to allow equilibration of the pressure and prevent the bubbles from expanding.

Spending longer time underwater (Option B), deeper dives (Option C) and colder temperatures (Option D) favour more nitrogen dissolving but it is the sudden change in pressure that is responsible for retention. Divers and pilots are also advised breaks between trips to prevent nitrogen accumulation.

Decompression sickness is treated in a decompression chamber where the patient is administered hyperbaric oxygen within a closed-pressurized chamber to allow the pressures to be equilibrated so they can be expired.

questions.text: A patient with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes presents with recurrent nausea, vomiting, and abdominal bloating, particularly after meals. He reports feeling full quickly and experiencing significant weight loss. Physical examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness. Endoscopy is unrevealing and gastric scintigraphy reveals 65% retention after 2 hours. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient has diabetic gastroparesis, which is best treated by dietary modification and prokinetics. Gastroparesis is a common complication of diabetes, characterized by delayed gastric emptying due to autonomic neuropathy.

Long-term treatment of gastroparesis focuses on maintaining nutrition and managing symptoms.

  • Diet: Small, frequent meals (5-6 per day) low-fiber, low-fat, and low-gas-forming foods. Avoidance of milk, fatty foods, and foods difficult to digest

  • Medications:
    • Opioids and anticholinergics should be avoided as they worsen symptoms by inhibiting gastric motility. (Option D)
    • Prokinetic agents: Metoclopramide may improve gastric emptying but not small bowel motility. Must discontinue if tardive dyskinesia develops.
    • Prucalopride 
    • Erythromycin
  • Endoscopic procedures:
    • Botulinum toxin injection
    • Pyloric dilation
    • Myotomy (G-POEM)
  • Venting gastrostomy: For patients with predominant small bowel distention.
  • Jejunostomy: For long-term enteral nutrition.
  • TPN or small bowel transplantation: For patients unable to maintain adequate enteral nutrition.
  • Glycemic control: Blood glucose levels should be maintained below 200 mg/dL to optimize gastric emptying.

Option B: While it can improve glycemic control, it does not directly address the underlying cause of the delayed gastric emptying and is not considered a primary treatment for diabetic gastroparesis.

Option C: Gastric electrical stimulation: Although effective, this is a more invasive option than prokinetic medications and should only be considered after conservative measures have failed.

Option D: Anticholinergic medications worsen gastroparesis by inhibiting gastric motility and should be avoided. Probiotics, while potentially beneficial, they are not the first-line treatment and their efficacy is not yet fully established.
